headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome ladies and gentlemen, the ARAMARK Corporation First Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded for rebroadcast. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn
componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome ladies and gentlemen, the ARAMARK Corporation First Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded for rebroadcast. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Chris Holland, Senior Vice President, Finance Treasurer. Please go ahead, Chris.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our first quarter fiscal 2012.Here with me today is Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fred and I will present an overview o
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our first quarter fiscal 2012.
Here with me today is Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fred and I will present an overview of our first quarter results and business operations, after which there will be an opportunity for phone-in participants to ask questions.
I'd like to remind you that any recording or other use or transmission of this audio may not be done without the prior written consent of ARAMARK. As we discuss the results, you may want to refer to the Form 10-Q we filed earlier today, which contains our first quarter results for fiscal 2012. This Form 10-Q can be found on our website at www.aramark.com.
In today's discussion of results, we mention certain non-GAAP financial measures. The Form 10-Q, as well as schedules we posted to our website earlier today, include reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most comparable GAAP measures as required by SEC rules.
Our discussion of operating income during today's call will, in each instance, exclude the incremental intangibles amortization and property and equipment depreciation expense resulting from the going private transaction and the impact of stock option expense. These items are detailed in the schedules posted to our website before the call. In addition, the prior-year period results have been recasted to present the results of the Galls business as a discontinued operation as we sold it in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011.
Various remarks that we make in this call relating to matters that are not historical facts, including remarks about future expectations, anticipation, beliefs, estimates, plans and prospects, constitute forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from those expressed or implied as a result of various risks, uncertainties and important factors, including those discussed in the Risk Factors, MD&A and other sections of our Form 10-K and the Form 10-Q filed earlier today. We disclaim any duty to update or revise such forward-looking statements, whether as a result of future events or otherwise.
Now I'd like to turn the program over to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter 2012 results call. I'd like to review our business and operating results and then have Chris cover a few additional details on our performance for this quarter.Overall, we
componenttext:
Thanks, Chris. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter 2012 results call. I'd like to review our business and operating results and then have Chris cover a few additional details on our performance for this quarter.
Overall, we're pleased with our start in fiscal 2012, which has been consistent with our expectations. While the economic environment remains somewhat uncertain, we remain focused on initiatives and investments that positions ARAMARK for balanced long-term growth and success. Our less cyclical businesses have continued to deliver the positive financial results we saw in 2011. While our more economically sensitive businesses have shown stable performance with pockets of strength.
we continue to manage the impact of higher commodity costs and we believe that our ongoing efforts to drive operating efficiencies will positively support our financial results as we move through fiscal 2012. Our balanced portfolio of sectors, clients and geographies also continues to be a source of strength and stability for us and provides us with the solid growth platform for the future.
Now let me turn it to our consolidated results for the quarter. We achieved sales of $3.4 billion, which was up 4% from the prior-year quarter and up 3% on an organic basis. Growth for the quarter was reduced by about 1 percentage point as a result of the NBA lockout this quarter and the fact that we serve the Asian Games in Shanghai in last year's first quarter.
Operating income, again adjusted to exclude the items that Chris mentioned earlier, increased 3% to $211 million from $200 million in the first quarter. Operating income growth was negatively affected by approximately $4 million of planned acquisition-related transition and integration expenses being absorbed in the quarter relative to Masterplan and Filterfresh. As well as the recognition last year of approximately $8 million of income related to a compensation agreement signed with the National Park Service, you may remember that we discussed this in the first quarter last year.
Without these 2 particular items, year-over-year growth on a more comparable basis would've been in the high single digits. In our North American Food and Support Services segment, first quarter sales of $2.4 billion were up 6% on a reported basis and up 3% organically but primarily by growth in Higher Education and Healthcare. As I mentioned, segment sales in growth were reduced due to the NBA lockout in the quarter.
our Business & Industry sector reported a high single-digit sales growth in the quarter, reflecting the positive impact of the Filterfresh office coffee services acquisition, which closed in October, as well as solid base business growth in our facility services business and mid single-digit growth in our legacy refreshment services business.
The Education sector had mid single-digit sales growth, led by strong base business growth in the Higher Education food business and the benefit of new business won in the prior year.
In Healthcare sector, sales grew in the high single digits, driven by the acquisition of Masterplan within our Clinical Technology Services business in March of 2011, as well as solid base business growth across the sector.
Our Sports and Entertainment sector had the sales decline at a low single-digit rate and this is primarily due to the impact of the NBA lockout and fewer major league playoff games for us this October versus last year in those stadiums we provide our services.
Now absent these 2 factors, the sector would have shown positive growth in the quarter, supported by solid attendance growth and very good per capita spending at our NFL and NHL venues compared to the prior year. Adjusted operating income in the North American Food and Support Services segment of $155 million was about flat for the quarter. Strong profit growth and Higher Education and Healthcare was offset by a decline in Business & Industry sector profits by about approximately $4 million of planned transition and integration expenses from the Filterfresh acquisition.
In addition, results for the first quarter of 2011 as I mentioned before included approximately $8 million of other income related to a compensation agreement with the National Park Service, under which they paid down a portion of our possessory interest in one of our concession contracts.
Again, excluding these 2 particular items, the segment would have shown high single-digit profit growth in the quarter.
Now let's turn to the International Food and Support Services segment. First quarter sales of $685 million were up 2% on a reported basis and up 5% organically. Results were led by very strong sales growth in South America and solid growth in Germany and Ireland. China had a reported sales decline in the quarter due to last year's results having benefited as I mentioned before from our serving the Asian Games in Shanghai. Excluding this particular large event, we continued to see excellent sales growth in China, primarily driven by a robust performance in our Healthcare facility services business.
First quarter adjusted operating income was $23.3 million compared to $15.4 million in the prior year, with Germany, South America and the U.K. delivering solid profit growth in the quarter. You may recall that last year's results included expenses related to efficiency and cost reduction initiatives, including severance charges across several of our countries. While a smaller amount of expenses was recorded this year for further cost reduction and efficiency initiatives in the U.K. Without this expenses in both years, the segment would still have shown very good profit growth overall.
In our Uniform and Career Apparel segment, first quarter sales of $341 million were down 1% from the year-ago quarter on a reported and organic basis. Organic sales growth in Uniform rental was offset by a decline in our direct sales business as a result of certain large customer direct sales programs which were launched in last year's first quarter. We are continuing to invest in additional rental sales personnel resources to support accelerated new sales growth, while maintaining a disciplined approach the contract pricing.
We are gaining improved traction in our new sales efforts. And during the first quarter, we were very pleased with the volume of new sales delivered by our sales force, which significantly exceeded both the prior quarter's results and the prior year's first quarter results. And this was driven both by higher sales headcount and by higher sales rep productivity.
The increased sales cost which include upfront installation costs associated with the substantially higher levels of new business are essentially being offset by the successful efficiency initiatives that we've talked about in previous calls. While higher rates of new sales were continued to the first profit growth over the next few quarters as the ramp up continues, we believe these efforts will lead to both improving rental sales and profit growth as we move through 2012.
Uniform segment adjusted operating income was $40 million, down from $42 million in the year-ago quarter. Profit growth -- profit results in the quarter were reduced by costs including severance expense associated with additional organizational efficiency initiatives, following the successful integration of our rental and direct sales operations. And as we mentioned last quarter, the completion of the Galls divestiture, as well as incremental expense from our investment and growing the sales force and the impact of higher energy costs.
Overall, the segment's profit performance was consistent with our expectations as we ramp up our new sales efforts and continue our operating efficiency initiatives. And as I mentioned, we expect that to reestablish profit growth and increasing sales growth as the new sales start to drop profits to the bottom line.
Corporate expenses adjusted to include items Chris mentioned earlier were $7.1 million in the quarter, compared to $8.2 million in the year-ago quarter. Now at this point, let me turn it back to Chris for some additional details.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Fred. I'd like to comment on our capital structure and cash flow. We're pleased that for the trailing 12 months ending December 30, our adjusted EBITDA increased to $1.129 billion, up from $1.10 billion at September 30, 2011, and up from $1.051 bi
componenttext:
Thanks, Fred. I'd like to comment on our capital structure and cash flow. We're pleased that for the trailing 12 months ending December 30, our adjusted EBITDA increased to $1.129 billion, up from $1.10 billion at September 30, 2011, and up from $1.051 billion at December 31, 2010.
Interest and other financing costs were $109 million for the first quarter, just slightly below the prior year's first quarter expense. Approximately 45% of our debt portfolio is at fixed interest rates and our overall weighted average cost of debt at quarter end was approximately 6.3%.
Total reported debt at the end of the quarter was $5.908 billion. Our secured debt, as defined in our credit agreement, totaled $3.831 billion which included a term loan balance of $3.288 billion and the revolver balance of $249 million. Our $250 million accounts receivable securitization facility was also fully utilized as of quarter end.
We continue to enjoy a strong liquidity position. And as of quarter end, we had approximately $395 million of available borrowing capacity under our revolving credit facility. We are pleased that based on our solid growth and trailing EBITDA compared to the same quarter last year, our secured debt ratio improved further to 3.3x as of December 30 compared to 3.47x in the year-ago quarter.
Consistent with our plan, net capital expenditures for the quarter were $74 million compared to $54 million in the prior-year quarter, reflecting growth in both client-related investments as well as investments in our systems and physical infrastructure to support future growth and efficiencies.
In managing our capital budget, we continue to maintain disciplined approach as we evaluate and invest in our opportunities.
For the full year, we do expect that net capital expenditures would be somewhat higher than prior-year levels. Consistent with our historical patterns, working capital was a use of cash for us during the first quarter and was in line with our expectations. For the full year of fiscal 2012, we anticipate net working capital will be a relatively modest use of cash for us overall.
Finally, we spent $150 million on acquisitions in the first quarter primarily related to the previously mentioned purchase of Filterfresh in October. And we funded these acquisitions through a combination of excess cash and revolver borrowings. Now let me turn the call back to Fred

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris. Overall, we're pleased with our start to fiscal 2012, which has been consistent with our expectations. As we moved throughout this year, our teams are focused on driving a number of business wide initiatives aimed at delivering improved org
componenttext:
Thanks, Chris. Overall, we're pleased with our start to fiscal 2012, which has been consistent with our expectations. As we moved throughout this year, our teams are focused on driving a number of business wide initiatives aimed at delivering improved organic growth and continued margin improvement over time. We believe through these initiatives, we can break greater efficiencies and improve the effectiveness of how we serve our clients and customers and how we generate new sales.
We believe our efforts towards process standardization across our businesses and countries will help drive strong financial performance in the coming years. And finally, despite a persistently uncertain economic environment, we continue to be excited about the growth opportunities that we see across the company. Even though certain businesses and geographies may remain more challenged than others, the diversity of our portfolio provides us with a very good balance to continue to mitigate challenges and to grow ARAMARK.
Thank you again for your time this afternoon and for your continued support. At this point, we'd be happy to take your questions.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012

componenttextpreview: This is Fred. We had a slight sales decline in the U.K. challenged economy. We are actually were up decently in Ireland. And there in particular, we've got a good package between facilities and food services through a recent acquisition we made there that
componenttext: This is Fred. We had a slight sales decline in the U.K. challenged economy. We are actually were up decently in Ireland. And there in particular, we've got a good package between facilities and food services through a recent acquisition we made there that's worked in our favor. We had okay growth in Spain, mid-single-digit growth in Spain organically in the quarter. So we were pretty pleased with that given some of the challenges that the Spanish economy is undergoing with very high unemployment rates. And then as we talked about the real Germany was solid, the economy is pretty good there although we think it will -- there will be challenges in Germany in the economy. And then we had very solid growth throughout South America, the countries that we operate in, and in China.

I was wondering if you could give us the growth numbers excluding the acquisitions. And maybe your updated outlook for those segments.

componenttext: Yes, the refreshment services business ex the Filterfresh acquisition, did grow organically in the mid-single digits. The Healthcare business, ex the Masterplan acquisition, grew just below the mid-single digits. So in the low-single digits, with solid base business growth is lapping a couple of lost accounts in the prior-year quarter, but we're continuing to see good solid growth across the sector.

componenttext: Right, but the mid-single-digit sales growth for Healthcare is a little slower than what you experienced last year, if I remember correctly.

componenttext: It may vary from year to year. There's no -- we don't see any particular trend, the pattern of gains and losses. So we think over the next year or so, the Healthcare business will probably grow faster but it's right now, it's probably performing at the lower end of the range but within the range that we target for.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: But there can be some choppiness in new sales in Healthcare. We talked about some of those accounts can be quite large and quite complex and can lead to longer selling cycles. And so there have been periods where we've seen that business growth very nicel
componenttext: But there can be some choppiness in new sales in Healthcare. We talked about some of those accounts can be quite large and quite complex and can lead to longer selling cycles. And so there have been periods where we've seen that business growth very nicely in the high single-digit in some quarters even in the low double digits. But again, the timing of new sales can impact it pretty significantly.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then can you talk about potential additional tuck-in acquisitions if there are assets that are likely to come for sale that would meet your requirements? And then you really haven't spoken much about your Japanese joint venture. Any updated th
componenttext: Got it. And then can you talk about potential additional tuck-in acquisitions if there are assets that are likely to come for sale that would meet your requirements? And then you really haven't spoken much about your Japanese joint venture. Any updated thoughts on that would be appreciated as well.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure, starting with Japan. Again, that's a 50-50 joint venture with Mitsui going back now more than 30 years. The business was down somewhat from the prior year, obviously because of the ongoing impact and the aftermath of the earthquake and the tsunami.
componenttext: Sure, starting with Japan. Again, that's a 50-50 joint venture with Mitsui going back now more than 30 years. The business was down somewhat from the prior year, obviously because of the ongoing impact and the aftermath of the earthquake and the tsunami. It is certainly stable though. It's just that the level of activity in giving some of the conservation requirements that the government has imposed on businesses is just frankly reducing the availability of mealtimes and population in some of the accounts. But the business is stable and generated very solid profits for us in the quarter. And so I don't see that changing as we look out through the rest of this fiscal year, at least. But again, very solid business, it's $1.8 billion business for us on the top line. And again, good balance between Healthcare and business and some good growth in areas like corrections and Sports and Entertainment. Acquisition opportunities, otherwise again, I think Masterplan and Filterfresh were good examples of the kinds of things we're thinking about. We also continue to be focused on continued to broaden and deepen our facility services capability, the acquisition we made in Ireland a couple of years ago I think is a good example of that. And as Fred said, that balance in Ireland actually held us in good stead this quarter with solid growth coming from the facilities business. So things like that in certain countries around the world and in North America are certainly things that fit with what we're looking for strategically. And then in the Uniform business, there's certainly will continue to be over time opportunities likely more regional in nature or local in nature. But as that business has improved and the economy's improved, I would expect that you will over time see some are activity on the Uniform side as well.

I think in the sort of 8x to 9x EBITDA range, pre-synergy is probably the right way -- I mean, obviously, it's going to depend based on the target and based on strategic attractiveness for us. But the high single-digit pre-synergies continues to be what we're seeing. And I don't think there's a necessarily material change in multiples at least from our vantage point over the last 12 months or so.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012

componenttext: Okay, and then just in terms of your capital structure, you commented in your 10-Q that the 5% notes are not being included in short-term debt because they can be refinanced with the credit facility. What about your other bonds are all callable? Any view on whether you consider coming to the market to refinance or how you look at your capital structure from where it stands today?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we are obviously pretty comfortable with the capital structure. We obviously spent a lot of time thinking about it and I think we will continue to be prudent as we manage maturities as we move across time. That $250 million maturity on June 1
componenttext: Yes, I think we are obviously pretty comfortable with the capital structure. We obviously spent a lot of time thinking about it and I think we will continue to be prudent as we manage maturities as we move across time. That $250 million maturity on June 1 is very comfortably fit within our free cash flow and revolver. So we're not compelled to do anything other than that with that maturity. And we like the capital structure. I think we've got a lots of liquidity. We obviously extend our revolver which improved that liquidity. And I think we'll step-by-step deal with it again prudently as I think we have so far.

componenttext: Okay, and then when you look at the quarter view, a number of other companies and in different sectors talked about how the warm weather hurt them. I was wondering what were you seeing from a potential weather impact, was the warm weather actually helping you guys as more people may have been out in about up at about?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think in the foodservice business, it probably I don't think there wasn't a big impact one way or the other. I know that we did it's small for us but I know that we did see some negative effect in our direct sales business, which is part of our overall
componenttext: I think in the foodservice business, it probably I don't think there wasn't a big impact one way or the other. I know that we did it's small for us but I know that we did see some negative effect in our direct sales business, which is part of our overall Uniform segment, the bulk of that is rental but a portion of it is direct sales of work apparel. And that business in our first fiscal quarter the quarter we are talking about this very heavily outerwear oriented those businesses head into the fall and look to directly purchased embroidered jackets and outerwear. And we're seeing quite a negative impact on our outerwear sales consistent with the weather. Now fortunately for us, it's the smaller part of our Uniform business which itself is certainly not the dominant part of the overall company. So it was a blip on the radar for the whole company but we did see that clearly if you look at that component.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012

componenttext: Well, we've seen an improvement in our base business performance over the last couple of years. And right now, we're operating on the base pre the impact of pricing overall about flat to slightly positive. So it's clearly an improvement from where it was 12 and 24 months ago. To be fair, we have not seen any particular spike up over the last 3, 4, 5 months but it's clearly better than it was a year ago.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Over time, we actually think there's a fair amount of opportunity, some of what we've done today has been rationalizing our support structure and making it more efficient. There are additional benefits as we alluded to in the prepared remarks. In the unit
componenttext: Over time, we actually think there's a fair amount of opportunity, some of what we've done today has been rationalizing our support structure and making it more efficient. There are additional benefits as we alluded to in the prepared remarks. In the unit level, and the 2 major costs of the unit level and the food and facilities business whether it's in the U.K. or U.S. or anywhere else, obviously our food and labor. So we've got a number of programs which are really longer-term, frankly multi-year programs to become more efficient and our use of labor and our preparation of food, use of food in preparation of food at the unit level. Again, that takes a while because one's talking about literally thousands of units because we run a very distributed model. So those benefits really are largely still to come.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. When you look at clinical technologies and Filterfresh, I was wondering if you could make some qualitative comments on how the cost and revenue synergies are playing out relative to your expectations?
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. When you look at clinical technologies and Filterfresh, I was wondering if you could make some qualitative comments on how the cost and revenue synergies are playing out relative to your expectations?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think in both cases, they are playing out consistent with our plan. We're much further along obviously with Masterplan -- excuse me, which we're actually coming up with a 12-month mark on so that is in terms of the integration within the operations
componenttext: Yes, I think in both cases, they are playing out consistent with our plan. We're much further along obviously with Masterplan -- excuse me, which we're actually coming up with a 12-month mark on so that is in terms of the integration within the operations, within the sales, within the various infrastructure is essentially behind us and feel very good again, about our position in that market as we talk about where we have a very attractive leadership position as a non-OEM provider of multi-vendor services. Filterfresh, obviously, much more recent, but we are now just about completed with the integration of what was 28 different markets where we're both operating that were now essentially completed in terms of consolidating the operations in those markets. There's still some real estate that we need to work out over time, but in terms of synergy realization, at this point in the process, we feel good about where we are.

componenttext: And I think just to add to that on the revenue side, in the clinical technology business, we preserve the sales health headcount above our CTS legacy operations and Masterplan. And I think as Chris said, we're well-positioned as the largest OEM, non-OEM provider. And so we think there's pretty significant revenue opportunities although the acquisition will be a good acquisition without huge revenue opportunities. And in Filterfresh, we've been pleased that our client retention has been maintained at historic levels. We obviously run a risk in situation like this in client retention actually is reduced for a little while as some clients may be unhappy with the company has been sold but we haven't seen that. So that's actually has been a positive to our expectations.

componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit what's been driving the stronger comps in the U.S. Has it been higher pricing, new accounts or more transactions?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit what's been driving the stronger comps in the U.S. Has it been higher pricing, new accounts or more transactions?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's a combination of both. We certainly have seen actually in 2011 and in 2012 in the first quarter, a very good base business growth and that's a combination of pricing and volume growth. Our Higher Education business, for example,, had a terrific quart
componenttext: It's a combination of both. We certainly have seen actually in 2011 and in 2012 in the first quarter, a very good base business growth and that's a combination of pricing and volume growth. Our Higher Education business, for example,, had a terrific quarter in terms of base business growth and that's again some pricing but more importantly, capturing more of the demand on the campus is that we serve. New -- we continue to generate good levels of new business, stronger in some quarters than others and stronger in some businesses than others. And as I mentioned, our retention rates have continued to track with historical levels. So I think there continues to be more opportunity on the new business front, and we are continuing to make investments in new sales resources. And as we've seen more stability and hopefully an even better economy in the U.S., that should certainly help in terms of driving base business growth to even better levels.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012

componenttext: Okay, great and then in terms of pricing, what have you been seeing in terms of commodity cost increases and food costs? Is there any new developments there?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's really stabilized relative to levels we were seeing towards the end of fiscal '11, where we've seen prices continue to rise over the course of the year into that really 6% to 7% range. That's where we continue to see them today. I think our expectati
componenttext: It's really stabilized relative to levels we were seeing towards the end of fiscal '11, where we've seen prices continue to rise over the course of the year into that really 6% to 7% range. That's where we continue to see them today. I think our expectations would be that they would perhaps begin to moderate from that level and not push any higher. And we certainly hope and expect that to be the case. But that being said, I think as Fred said in his prepared remarks, we continue to manage through pretty effectively those types of cost increases through a combination of pricing, combination of menu engineering and also a combination of delivering better efficiencies through the business and at the unit level. So fortunately, we have a number of different levers to pull that allow was to manage even in levels of somewhat above average rates and inflation.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to the ARAMARK Corporation First Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded for rebroadcast. [Operator Instructions] I will now
componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to the ARAMARK Corporation First Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded for rebroadcast. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Chris Holland, Senior Vice President, Finance Treasurer. Please go ahead, Chris.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our first quarter of fiscal 2012.Here with me today is Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fred and I will present an overvie
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our first quarter of fiscal 2012.
Here with me today is Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fred and I will present an overview of our first quarter results and business operations, after which there will be an opportunity for phone-in participants to ask questions.
I'd like to remind you that any recording or other use or transmission of this audio may not be done without the prior written consent of ARAMARK. As we discuss the results, you may want to refer to the Form 10-Q we filed earlier today, which contains our first quarter results for fiscal 2012. This Form 10-Q can be found on our website at www.aramark.com.
In today's discussion of results, we mention certain non-GAAP financial measures. The Form 10-Q, as well as schedules we posted to our website earlier today, include reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most comparable GAAP measures, as required by SEC rules.
Our discussion of operating income during today's call will, in each instance, exclude the incremental intangibles amortization and property and equipment depreciation expense resulting from the going private transaction and the impact of stock option expense. These items are detailed in the schedules posted to our website before the call. In addition, the prior year period results had been recasted to present the results of the Galls business as a discontinued operation as we sold it in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011.
Various remarks that we make in this call relating to matters that are not historical facts, including remarks about future expectations, anticipation, beliefs, estimates, plans and prospects, constitute forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from those expressed or implied as a result of various risks, uncertainties and important factors, including those discussed in the Risk Factors, MD&A and other sections of our Form 10-K and the Form 10-Q filed earlier today. We disclaim any duty to update or revise such forward-looking statements, whether as a result of future events or otherwise.
Now I'd like to turn the program over to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter 2012 results call. I'd like to review our business and operating results and then have Chris cover a few additional details on our performance for this quarter.Overall, we
componenttext:
Thanks, Chris. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter 2012 results call. I'd like to review our business and operating results and then have Chris cover a few additional details on our performance for this quarter.
Overall, we're pleased with our start in fiscal 2012, which has been consistent with our expectations. While the economic environment remains somewhat uncertain, we remain focused on initiatives and investments that position ARAMARK for balanced long-term growth and success. Our less cyclical businesses have continued to deliver the positive financial results we saw in 2011, while our more economically sensitive businesses have shown stable performance with pockets of strength.
We continue to manage the impact of higher commodity costs, and we believe that our ongoing efforts to drive operating efficiencies will positively support our financial results as we move through fiscal 2012. Our balanced portfolio of sectors, clients and geographies also continues to be a source of strength and stability for us and provides us with a solid growth platform for the future.
Now let me turn to our consolidated results for the quarter. We achieved sales of $3.4 billion, which was up 4% from the prior year quarter and up 3% on an organic basis. Growth for the quarter was reduced by about 1 percentage point as a result of the NBA lockout this quarter and the fact that we served the Asian Games in Shanghai in last year's first quarter.
Operating income, again adjusted to exclude the items that Chris mentioned earlier, increased 3% to $211 million from $200 million in the first quarter. Operating income growth was negatively affected by approximately $4 million of planned acquisition-related transition and integration expenses being absorbed in the quarter relative to Masterplan and Filterfresh, as well as the recognition last year of approximately $8 million of income related to a compensation agreement signed with the National Park Service. You may remember that we discussed this in the first quarter call last year. Without these 2 particular items, year-over-year growth on more a comparable basis would have been in the high single digits. 
In our North American Food and Support Services segment, first quarter sales of $2.4 billion were up 6% on a reported basis and up 3% organically, led primarily by growth in Higher Education and Healthcare. As I mentioned, segment sales in growth were reduced due to the NBA lockout in the quarter.
Our Business & Industry sector reported a high single-digit sales growth in the quarter, reflecting the positive impact of the Filterfresh office coffee services acquisition, which closed in October, as well as solid base business growth in our facility services business and mid-single-digit growth in our legacy refreshment services business.
The Education sector had mid-single-digit sales growth, led by strong base business growth in the Higher Education food business and the benefit of new business won in the prior year.
In Healthcare sector, sales grew in the high single digits, driven by the acquisition of Masterplan within our Clinical Technology Services business in March of 2011, as well as solid base business growth across the sector.
Our Sports & Entertainment sector had a sales decline at a low single-digit rate. This is primarily due to the impact of the NBA lockout and fewer major league playoff games for us this October versus last year in those stadiums where we provide our services. Now absent these 2 factors, the sector would have shown positive growth in the quarter supported by solid attendance growth and very good per capita spending at our NFL and NHL venues compared to the prior year. 
Adjusted operating income in the North American Food and Support Services segment of $155 million was about flat for the quarter. Strong profit growth in Higher Education and Healthcare was offset by a decline in Business & Industry sector profits by about approximately $4 million of planned transition and integration expenses from the Filterfresh acquisition.
In addition, results for the first quarter of 2011, as I mentioned before, included approximately $8 million of other income related to a compensation agreement with the National Park Service, under which they paid down a portion of our possessory interest in one of our concession contracts. Again, excluding these 2 particular items, the segment would have shown high single-digit profit growth in the quarter.
Now let's turn to the International Food and Support Services segment. First quarter sales of $685 million were up 2% on a reported basis and up 5% organically. Results were led by very strong sales growth in South America and solid growth in Germany and Ireland. China had a reported sales decline in the quarter due to last year's results having benefited, as I mentioned before, from our serving the Asian Games in Shanghai. Excluding this particular large event, we continued to see excellent sales growth in China, primarily driven by a robust performance in our Healthcare facility services business.
First quarter adjusted operating income was $23.3 million compared to $15.4 million in the prior year with Germany, South America and the U.K. delivering solid profit growth in the quarter. You may recall that last year's results included expenses related to efficiency and cost reduction initiatives, including severance charges across several of our countries, while a smaller amount of expense was recorded this year for further cost reduction and efficiency initiatives in the U.K. Without these expenses in both years, the segment would still have shown very good profit growth overall.
In our Uniform and Career Apparel segment, first quarter sales of $341 million were down 1% from the year-ago quarter on a reported and organic basis. Organic sales growth in uniform rental was offset by a decline in our direct sales business as a result of certain large customer direct sale programs, which were launched in last year's first quarter. We are continuing to invest in additional rental sales personnel resources to support accelerated new sales growth while maintaining a disciplined approach to contract pricing.
We are gaining improved traction in our new sales efforts. And during the first quarter, we were very pleased with the volume of new sales delivered by our sales force, which significantly exceeded both the prior quarter's results and the prior year's first quarter results. And this was driven both by higher sales headcount and by higher sales rep productivity.
The increased sales cost, which include upfront installation costs associated with the substantially higher levels of new business, are essentially being offset by the successful efficiency initiatives that we've talked about in previous calls. While higher rates of new sales were continued to the first profit growth over the next few quarters as the ramp-up continues, we believe these efforts will lead to both improving rental sales and profit growth as we move through 2012.
Uniform segment adjusted operating income was $40 million, down from $42 million in the year-ago quarter. Profit growth -- profit results in the quarter were reduced by costs, including severance expense associated with additional organizational efficiency initiatives, following the successful integration of our rental and direct sales operations, and as we mentioned last quarter, the completion of the Galls divestiture, as well as incremental expense from our investment and growing the sales force and the impact of higher energy cost.
Overall, the segment's profit performance was consistent with our expectations as we ramp up our new sales efforts and continue our operating efficiency initiatives. And as I mentioned, we expect that to re-establish profit growth and increasing sales growth as the new sales start to drop profits to the bottom line.
Corporate expenses adjusted to include the items Chris mentioned earlier were $7.1 million in the quarter compared to $8.2 million in the year-ago quarter. 
Now at this point, let me turn it back to Chris for some additional details.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Fred. I'd like to comment on our capital structure and cash flow. We are pleased that for the trailing 12 months ending December 30, our adjusted EBITDA increased to $1.129 billion, up from $1.10 billion at September 30, 2011, and up from $1.051 b
componenttext:
Thanks, Fred. I'd like to comment on our capital structure and cash flow. We are pleased that for the trailing 12 months ending December 30, our adjusted EBITDA increased to $1.129 billion, up from $1.10 billion at September 30, 2011, and up from $1.051 billion at December 31, 2010.
Interest and other financing costs were $109 million for the first quarter, just slightly below the prior year's first quarter expense. Approximately 45% of our debt portfolio is at fixed interest rates and our overall weighted average cost of debt at quarter end was approximately 6.3%.
Total reported debt at the end of the quarter was $5.908 billion. Our secured debt, as defined in our credit agreement, totaled $3.831 billion, which included a term loan balance of $3.288 billion and a revolver balance of $249 million. Our $250 million accounts receivable securitization facility was also fully utilized as of quarter end.
We continue to enjoy a strong liquidity position. And as of quarter end, we had approximately $395 million of available borrowing capacity under our revolving credit facility. We are pleased that based on our solid growth and trailing EBITDA compared to the same quarter last year, our secured debt ratio improved further to 3.3x as of December 30 compared to 3.47x in the year-ago quarter.
Consistent with our plan, net capital expenditures for the quarter were $74 million compared to $54 million in the prior year quarter, reflecting growth in both client-related investments, as well as investments in our systems and physical infrastructure to support future growth and efficiencies.
In managing our capital budget, we continue to maintain a disciplined approach as we evaluate and invest in opportunities.
For the full year, we do expect that net capital expenditures would be somewhat higher than prior year levels. Consistent with the historical patterns, working capital was a use of cash for us during the first quarter and was in line with our expectations. For the full year of fiscal 2012, we anticipate net working capital will be a relatively modest use of cash for us overall.
Finally, we spent $150 million on acquisitions in the first quarter primarily related to the previously mentioned purchase of Filterfresh in October. And we funded these acquisitions with a combination of excess cash and revolver borrowings. 
Now let me turn the call back to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris. Overall, we are pleased with our start to fiscal 2012, which has been consistent with our expectations. As we move throughout this year, our teams are focused on driving a number of business-wide initiatives aimed at delivering improved org
componenttext:
Thanks, Chris. Overall, we are pleased with our start to fiscal 2012, which has been consistent with our expectations. As we move throughout this year, our teams are focused on driving a number of business-wide initiatives aimed at delivering improved organic growth and continued margin improvement over time. We believe through these initiatives, we can break greater efficiencies and improve effectiveness of how we serve our clients and customers and how we generate new sales.
We believe our efforts towards process standardization across our businesses and countries will help drive strong financial performance in the coming years. And finally, despite a persistently uncertain economic environment, we continue to be excited about the growth opportunities that we see across the company. Even though certain businesses and geographies may remain more challenged than others, the diversity of our portfolio provides us with a very good balance to continue to mitigate challenges and to grow ARAMARK.
Thank you again for your time this afternoon and for your continued support. At this point, we'd be happy to take your questions.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Reza Vahabzadeh with Barclays Capital.

componenttext: Reza, this is Fred. We had a slight sales decline in the U.K. challenged economy. We actually were up decently in Ireland. And there in particular, we've got a good package between facilities and food services through a recent acquisition we made there that's worked in our favor. We had okay growth in Spain, mid-single-digit growth in Spain organically in the quarter. So we were pretty pleased with that given some of the challenges that the Spanish economy is undergoing with very high unemployment rates. And then as we talked about the real -- Germany was solid. The economy is pretty good there, although there's -- we think it will -- there will be challenges in Germany in the economy. And then we had very solid growth throughout South America, the countries that we operate in, and in China.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012

componenttext: It may vary, some, from year to year. There's no -- we don't see any particular trend. It's the pattern of gains and losses. But it's -- right now, it's probably performing at the lower end of the range but within the range that we target for.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012

componenttext: But there can be some choppiness in new sales in Healthcare. We talked about some of those accounts can be quite large and quite complex and can lead to longer selling cycles. headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012

componenttext: Got it. And then can you talk about potential additional tuck-in acquisitions if there are assets that are likely to come for sale that would meet your requirements? headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. Starting with Japan, again, that's a 50-50 joint venture with Mitsui going back now more than 30 years. The business was down somewhat from the prior year, obviously, because of the ongoing impact and the aftermath of the earthquake and the tsunami.
componenttext: Sure. Starting with Japan, again, that's a 50-50 joint venture with Mitsui going back now more than 30 years. The business was down somewhat from the prior year, obviously, because of the ongoing impact and the aftermath of the earthquake and the tsunami. It is certainly stable though. It's just that the level of activity in giving some of the conservation requirements that the government has imposed on businesses is just frankly reducing the availability of meal times and the population in some of the accounts. But the business is stable and generated very solid profits for us in the quarter. And so I don't see that changing as we look out through the rest of this fiscal year, at least. But again, very solid business. It's $1.8 billion business for us on the top line. And again, good balance between Healthcare and -- business and some good growth in areas like corrections and Sports & Entertainment. Acquisition opportunities, otherwise, again, I think Masterplan and Filterfresh were good examples of the kinds of things we're thinking about. We also continue to be focused on continuing to broaden and deepen our facility services capability. The acquisition we made in Ireland a couple of years ago, I think, is a good example of that. And as Fred said, that balance in Ireland actually held us in good stead this quarter with solid growth coming from the facilities business. So things like that in certain countries around the world and in North America are certainly things that fit with what we're looking for strategically. And then in the Uniform business, there certainly will continue to be, over time, opportunities, likely more regional in nature or local in nature. But as that business has improved and the economy's improved, I would expect that you will, over time, see some are activity on the Uniform side as well.

I think in the sort of 8x to 9x EBITDA range pre-synergy is probably the right way to -- I mean, obviously, it's going to depend based on the target and based on it's strategic attractiveness for us. And I don't think there's a necessarily material change in multiples, at least from our vantage point over the last 12 months or so.

componenttext: Okay. And then just in terms of your capital structure, you commented in your 10-Q that the 5% notes are not being included in short-term debt because they can be refinanced with the credit facility. What about -- your other bonds are all callable. Any view on whether you consider coming to the market to refinance? Or how do you look at your cap structure? headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we are obviously pretty comfortable with the capital structure. We obviously spent a lot of time thinking about it, and I think we'll continue to be prudent as we manage maturities as we move across time. The $250 million maturity on June 1 i
componenttext: Yes, I think we are obviously pretty comfortable with the capital structure. We obviously spent a lot of time thinking about it, and I think we'll continue to be prudent as we manage maturities as we move across time. The $250 million maturity on June 1 is very comfortably fit within our free cash flow and revolver. So we're not compelled to do anything other than that with that maturity. And we like the capital structure. We think we have a lot of liquidity. We obviously extended the revolver, which improves that liquidity. And I think we'll step-by-step deal with it, again prudently, as I think we have so far.

I was wondering, what were you seeing from a potential weather impact? Was the warm weather actually helping you guys as more people may have been out and about?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think in the food service business, it probably -- I don't think there was any big impact one way or the other. I know that we did -- it's small for us, but I know that we did see some negative effect in our direct sales business, which is part of our o
componenttext: I think in the food service business, it probably -- I don't think there was any big impact one way or the other. I know that we did -- it's small for us, but I know that we did see some negative effect in our direct sales business, which is part of our overall Uniform segment. The bulk of that is rental but a portion of it is direct sales of work apparel. And that business in the -- our first fiscal quarter, the quarter that we're talking about, is very heavily outerwear oriented as businesses head into the fall and then look to directly purchase embroidered jackets and outerwear. And we're seeing quite a negative impact on our outerwear sales consistent with the weather. Now fortunately for us, it's the smaller part of our Uniform business, which itself is certainly not the dominant part of the overall company. So it was a blip on the radar for the whole company, but we did see that clearly if you look at that component.

componenttext: Well, we've seen an improvement in our base business performance over the last couple of years. And right now, we're operating on the base pre the impact of pricing overall about flat to slightly positive. So it's clearly an improvement from where it was 12 and 24 months ago. To be fair, we have not seen any particular spike-up over the last 3, 4, 5 months, but it's clearly better than it was a year ago.

componenttext: There's -- over time, we actually think there's a fair amount of opportunity, some of what we've done today has been rationalizing our support structure and making it more efficient. At the unit level -- in the unit level and the 2 major -- at the unit level and the food and facilities business, whether it's in the U.K. or U.S. or anywhere else, obviously our food and labor. So we've got a number of programs, which are really longer-term, frankly, multi-year programs, to become more efficient and our use of labor and our preparation of food -- use of food and preparation of food at the unit level. Again, that takes a while because one's talking about literally thousands of units because we run a very distributed model. So those benefits, really, are largely still to come.

componenttext: Yes. I think in both cases, they are playing out consistent with our plan. We're much further along, obviously, with Masterplan -- excuse me, which we're actually coming up with a 12-month mark-on. So that is in terms of the integration within the operations, within the sales, within the various infrastructure is essentially behind us and feel very good again about our position in that market as we talk about where we have a very attractive leadership position as a non-OEM provider of multi-vendor services. In Filterfresh, obviously, much more recent, but we are now just about completed with the integration of what was 28 different markets where we're both operating that were now essentially completed in terms of consolidating the operations in those markets. There's still some real estate that we need to work out over time, B.ut in terms of synergy realization, at this point in the process, we feel good about where we are.

componenttext: And I think just to add to that on the revenue side, in the Clinical Technology business, we preserve the sales health headcount above our CTS legacy operations and Masterplan. And I think as Chris said, we're well positioned as the largest OEM -- non-OEM provider. And so we think they're pretty significant revenue opportunities, although the acquisition will be a good acquisition without huge revenue opportunities. And in Filterfresh, we've been pleased that our client retention has been maintained at historic levels. You always run a risk in an acquisition like this that your client retention actually is reduced for a little while as some clients may be unhappy with the -- that the company has been sold. But we haven't seen that. So that actually has been a positive to our expectations.

componenttext: Yes. That was actually a very discrete situation, Bryan. That was, by far -- that was the largest Filterfresh client that had already been in the middle of a rebid process as we approached signing of the acquisition. As Fred said, by and large across the portfolio, we've now touched all of the key client relationships, and our retention rates so far in the Filterfresh portfolio has exceeded our expectations.

componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about what's been driving, really, the strong comps in the U.S. Has it been mostly higher pricing, new accounts or more transactions?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's a combination of both. We certainly have seen actually in 2011 and in 2012 in the first quarter a very good base business growth, and that's a combination of pricing and volume growth. Our Higher Education business, for example, had a terrific quarte
componenttext: It's a combination of both. We certainly have seen actually in 2011 and in 2012 in the first quarter a very good base business growth, and that's a combination of pricing and volume growth. Our Higher Education business, for example, had a terrific quarter in terms of base business growth. And that's, again, some pricing, but very importantly, capturing more of the demand on the campuses that we serve. New -- we continue to generate good levels of new business, stronger in some quarters than others and stronger in some businesses than others. And as I mentioned, our retention rates have continued to track with historical levels. So I think there continues to be more opportunity on the new business front, and we're continuing to make investments in new sales resources. And as we've seen more stability and hopefully an even better economy in the U.S., that should certainly help in terms of driving base business growth to even better levels.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then in terms of pricing, I mean, what have you been seeing in terms of commodity cost increases and food costs? Is there any new developments there?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then in terms of pricing, I mean, what have you been seeing in terms of commodity cost increases and food costs? Is there any new developments there?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's really stabilized relative to levels we were seeing towards the end of fiscal '11 where we've seen prices continue to rise over the course of the year into that really 6% to 7% range. And that's where we continue to see them today. I think our expect
componenttext: It's really stabilized relative to levels we were seeing towards the end of fiscal '11 where we've seen prices continue to rise over the course of the year into that really 6% to 7% range. And that's where we continue to see them today. I think our expectations would be that they would perhaps begin to moderate from that level and not push any higher. And we certainly hope and expect that to be the case. But that being said, I think as Fred said in his prepared remarks, we continue to manage through pretty effectively those types of cost increases through a combination of pricing, a combination of menu engineering and also a combination of delivering better efficiencies through the business and at the unit level. So fortunately, we have a number of different levers to pull that allow us to manage even in levels of somewhat above average rates and inflation.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012

componenttext: I think not directly. And the government in general is a pretty small part of our portfolio. So I think as we look at the pipeline and the opportunities, within the pressure is that government at large is under -- may indeed help drive higher rates of new sales in a couple of the sectors.
