componenttextpreview: Yes, absolutely. So typically in the first quarter, you're in the 98%, 99% range, which is where we are. And we would, at this point, expect to deliver another year of mid-90s retention for the full year.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about what's been driving, really, the strong comps in the U.S. Has it been mostly higher pricing, new accounts or more transactions?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about what's been driving, really, the strong comps in the U.S. Has it been mostly higher pricing, new accounts or more transactions?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's a combination of both. We certainly have seen actually in 2011 and in 2012 in the first quarter a very good base business growth, and that's a combination of pricing and volume growth. Our Higher Education business, for example, had a terrific quarte
componenttext: It's a combination of both. We certainly have seen actually in 2011 and in 2012 in the first quarter a very good base business growth, and that's a combination of pricing and volume growth. Our Higher Education business, for example, had a terrific quarter in terms of base business growth. And that's, again, some pricing, but very importantly, capturing more of the demand on the campuses that we serve. New -- we continue to generate good levels of new business, stronger in some quarters than others and stronger in some businesses than others. And as I mentioned, our retention rates have continued to track with historical levels. So I think there continues to be more opportunity on the new business front, and we're continuing to make investments in new sales resources. And as we've seen more stability and hopefully an even better economy in the U.S., that should certainly help in terms of driving base business growth to even better levels.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then in terms of pricing, I mean, what have you been seeing in terms of commodity cost increases and food costs? Is there any new developments there?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then in terms of pricing, I mean, what have you been seeing in terms of commodity cost increases and food costs? Is there any new developments there?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's really stabilized relative to levels we were seeing towards the end of fiscal '11 where we've seen prices continue to rise over the course of the year into that really 6% to 7% range. And that's where we continue to see them today. I think our expect
componenttext: It's really stabilized relative to levels we were seeing towards the end of fiscal '11 where we've seen prices continue to rise over the course of the year into that really 6% to 7% range. And that's where we continue to see them today. I think our expectations would be that they would perhaps begin to moderate from that level and not push any higher. And we certainly hope and expect that to be the case. But that being said, I think as Fred said in his prepared remarks, we continue to manage through pretty effectively those types of cost increases through a combination of pricing, a combination of menu engineering and also a combination of delivering better efficiencies through the business and at the unit level. So fortunately, we have a number of different levers to pull that allow us to manage even in levels of somewhat above average rates and inflation.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2012 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012

I think in certain parts of the government sector, K-12, for example, corrections market, for example, which are really small g government, continue to look at outsourcing and I think higher rate than they have historically as a result of their budget pressures that those institutions and those municipalities are under. So I think as we look at the pipeline and the opportunities, we think the pressures that government at large is under -- may indeed help drive higher rates of new sales in a couple of the sectors.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon and welcome, ladies and gentlemen to the ARAMARK Corporation Second Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded for rebroadcast and that all participants are in a listen-
componenttext: Good afternoon and welcome, ladies and gentlemen to the ARAMARK Corporation Second Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded for rebroadcast and that all participants are in a listen-only mode. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Chris Holland, Senior Vice President, excuse me, Finance Treasurer. Please proceed, Chris.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kim, and welcome, everyone to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our operations for the second quarter of fiscal 2012. Here with me today are Joe Neubauer, our Chairman; and Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice Presid
componenttext:
Thank you, Kim, and welcome, everyone to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our operations for the second quarter of fiscal 2012. Here with me today are Joe Neubauer, our Chairman; and Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fred and I will present an overview of our second quarter and year-to-date results and business operations. After which, Joe will provide a few closing comments. There will be an opportunity for phone-in participants to ask questions following Joe's remarks.
I'd like to remind you that any recording or other use or transmission of this audio may not be done without the prior written consent of ARAMARK. As we discuss the results, you may want to refer to the Form 10-Q we filed earlier today, which contains our second quarter and year-to-date results for fiscal 2012. This Form 10-Q can be found on our website at www.aramark.com.
In today's discussion of results, we mention certain non-GAAP financial measures. The Form 10-Q, as well as schedules we posted to our website prior to the call include reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most comparable GAAP measures as required by SEC rules.
Our discussion of operating income during today's call will, in each instance, exclude intangible amortization and property and equipment depreciation expense resulting from the going private transaction and the impact of stock option expense. All of these items are detailed in the schedules posted to our website before the call. In addition, the prior year period results have been restated to present the results of the galls business as a discontinued operation, as we sold it in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011.
Various remarks that we may make in this call relating to matters that are not historical facts, including remarks about future expectations, anticipation, beliefs, estimates, plans and prospects, constitute forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from those expressed or implied as a result of various risks, uncertainties and important factors, including those discussed in the Risk Factors, MD&A and other sections of our Form 10-K and the Form 10-Q filed earlier today. We disclaim any duty to update or revise such forward-looking statements, whether as a result of future events or otherwise.
Now let me turn the program over to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter 2012 results call. I'd like to review our business and operating results and then have Chris cover a few additional details on our performance.I'm pleased to report results for our seco
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter 2012 results call. I'd like to review our business and operating results and then have Chris cover a few additional details on our performance.
I'm pleased to report results for our second fiscal quarter that further extends this trend of solid operating performance that we have seen in recent quarters. While the economic environment remains a bit uncertain, we believe that our focus on initiatives and investments that position ARAMARK for long-term growth contributed to our strong results for the quarter of continuing to build a solid foundation for the future.
Overall, our performance in the quarter was balanced as our less cyclical businesses delivered another quarter of solid results, and our more economically sensitive businesses continued to show signs of improvement. While higher commodity cost remained a headwind for us for the quarter, the impact on a year-over-year basis has been moderating. Our ongoing efforts to improve our operating efficiencies continue to allow us to leverage our top line sales growth into solid performance earnings performance.
Now turning to our overall results for the second quarter. We reported sales of $3.3 billion, up 4% on a reported basis and an organic basis. Adjusted operating income of $177 million was up 8% from the prior year level. For the first half of 2012, sales grew by 4% to $6.8 billion or up 3% organically. As we discussed in our first quarter results, sales in the half was reduced somewhat by the impact of the first quarter -- in the first quarter of the NBA lockout and by our serving of the Asian Games in last year's first quarter. The first half adjusted operating income increased by 5% to $388 million. Also, as we discussed last quarter, operating income growth was negatively affected by approximately $4 million planned acquisition-related transition and integration expenses that were absorbed in the first quarter, as well as the recognition last year of approximately $8 million of income related to a compensation agreement signed with the National Park Service, under which they paid down a portion of our possessory interest in one of our concession contracts. And without these 2 particular items, year-over-year profit growth for the first half would've been in the high single digits.
In our North American food and support service services segment, second quarter sales of $2.3 million were up 6% on a reported basis and 4% on an organic basis and primarily by strong growth in our Higher Education business and health care and S&E sectors. The first half reported sales of $4.7 billion were up 6% versus the prior year and up 4% organically. Overall sales performance for the first half was led by solid growth in higher education and health care.
The Business & Industry sector reported a mid single-digit sales increase in the quarter. The single-digit increase for the half, reflecting the positive impact from the Filterfresh Office Coffee Services acquisition, which closed in October 2011. The sector also benefited from solid-based and new business growth in our new Facilities Services Business and our Refreshment Services business. 
Sales in our Education sector were up mid-single digits for the quarter and for the year-to-date, led primarily by continued strong base and new business growth in our higher education food business, as well as solid growth in our K-12 food business.
In the Healthcare sector, sales grew in the high single digits for the quarter and for the year-to-date, due primarily by the acquisition of Masterplan within our health care technologies business in March 2011, as well as solid base business growth. Sports & Entertainment sales grew in the mid-single digits in the quarter led by solid attendance and positive per capita spending trends in both our NHL and NBA venues. For the year-to-date, sales growth was limited to the low single digits, as a result as I mentioned of the NBA lockout during the first quarter, as well as the impact of fewer major league baseball playoff games in October, versus last year in those regions where we provide our services.
Adjusted operating income in the North American Food and Support Services segment was up 11% in the quarter to $130 million. Nearly all segments contributed to profit growth in the quarter, led by strong contributions from higher education and health care. In the first half, segment adjusted operating income grew by 4% to $285 million.
Previously noted, results in the first quarter were negatively affected by approximately $4 million of planned transition and integration expenses for the Filterfresh acquisition. In addition, results for the first quarter of 2011 included approximately eight $8 million of other income related to the compensation agreement with the National Park Service as I mentioned earlier. Including these 2 particular items, growth for the first half would've been in the high single digits.
Turning to the international Food and Support Services segment. Second quarter reported sales of $672 million were down slightly on a reported basis but up 4% organically versus the year-ago quarter. Organic growth in the quarter was led by strong performance in Germany, South America and China. For the first half, reported sales in international were up 1% and up 5% organically. The first half sales growth also was driven by strong results in Germany, Spain, South America and also Ireland.
Second quarter adjusted operating income for international of $25 million was up 10% versus the prior year. Results in the second quarter of 2011, you may recall, benefited from a gain from the sale of a small noncore subsidiary in Chile and the receipt of the AT income in the U.K, partially offset by severance charges in Chile related to the divestiture and a write-down of goodwill in India. Excluding these items from the prior year, profit growth would've been even stronger in the quarter, led by solid performance in Germany, Spain and Chile, partially offset by profit decline in our AIM joint venture in Japan. The first half adjusted operating income was $48 million, up from $38 million in the prior year. 
In addition to the items I just mentioned, 2011 results also included expenses related to efficiency and cost reduction initiatives including severance charges across several of our countries in the first quarter of 2011. While smaller amount of expenses recorded in the first half of 2012 further caused reduction in efficiency.
Excluding these expenses in both years, the segment would've still experienced strong income growth in the first half. 
In our Uniform and Career Apparel business, second quarter sales of $337 million were up 2% on a reported and organic basis. Improving organic growth rates in the uniform rental business for the quarter were offset by softness in direct sales, partly reflecting large customer direct sale programs that were launched in the first half of 2011 and that has not been repeated in 2012. For the year-to-date, sales of $678 million were about flat as compared to the same period in the prior year on both an as reported and organic basis. We're continuing to invest in additional rental sales personnel resources to support accelerated sales growth, while maintaining a disciplined approach to contract pricing. We are gaining improved traction in our new sales efforts. During the second quarter and in the first half, volume of new sales delivered by our sales force significantly exceeded the prior year's results, driven both by higher sales force headcount and higher sales rep productivity.
The increased cost, including installation costs associated with substantially higher levels of new business are largely being offset by the successful efficiency initiatives that we have discussed in previous calls. A higher cost related to the increased rates of new sales will continue to repress profit growth over the next few quarters. We believe these efforts will lead to both improving rental sales and profit growth as we move through 2012 and into 2013.
The segment's second quarter adjusted operating income was $30.3 million, down from $32.7 million the prior quarter, primarily reflecting the incremental expense from our investment in growing sales force garment and isolation cost from the acceleration of the business and the impact of higher energy costs.
In the first half, adjusted operating income was $70 million, down from $74.8 million in the prior year's first half, reflecting all of the items that I just mentioned, as well as severance expense incurred in the first quarter associated with some additional organizational efficiency initiatives following the successful integration of our rental and direct sales operations and the completion of the Galls divestiture.
Corporate expenses, excluding the items Chris mentioned earlier, were $7.5 million in the quarter compared to $8.2 million in the year-ago quarter. First half expenses were $14.6 million compared to $16.5 million in the prior year.
Finally, on a personal note, I'd like to thank Chris Holland for his 8 years of dedicated service as a key member of our finance team. While we all hate to see him go, we recognize the terrific opportunity to be CFO of a very highly respected Fortune 500 company, particularly one located in the same geographical area. It's just too good an opportunity to turn down. We at ARAMARK share in his success. We feel that Chris represented very good, solid raw material when we brought him here and he was trained well, and so we're very proud of him. We're also pleased to elevate Karen Wallace to VP and Treasure. I know many of you in the call know Karen. Karen's worked side-by-side with Chris for the last 7 years on all of our financing. She's well-positioned to fill some pretty big shoes that were worn by Chris. At this point, let me turn it back over to Chris for some additional details on the quarter and on the half.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, Fred, for that comment. I greatly appreciate it. I'd like to now spend a few minutes on our financing capital structure and cash flow. Our adjusted EBITDA for the trailing 12 months ending March 30 was $1.136 billion, up from $1.129 bill
componenttext:
Thanks very much, Fred, for that comment. I greatly appreciate it. I'd like to now spend a few minutes on our financing capital structure and cash flow. Our adjusted EBITDA for the trailing 12 months ending March 30 was $1.136 billion, up from $1.129 billion at December 30, 2011, and up from $1.1 billion even at September 30, 2011. Interest and other financing costs were $119 million for the second quarter compared to $93 million in the prior year. Results for the quarter included approximately $11 million of expenses related to the term loan extension we completed in March. We are very appreciative of the broad support that the extension transaction received from many of you, our investors, and we believe that the success of the extension further enhances our financial and capital structure flexibility.
Also contributing to the year-over-year variance was the recognition in the second quarter of 2011 of interest income of approximately $14 million related to the settlement of U.K. VAT claims in prior years. In the first half, interest and other financing costs were $227 million compared to $202 million in the prior-year, primarily reflecting the 2 items just mentioned. Including the impact of interest rate hedges, approximately 50% of our debt portfolio is at fixed interest rates, and our overall weighted average cost of debt is approximately 5.2%.
Total reported debt at the end of the second quarter was $5.817 billion as compared to $5.739 billion at the end of last year's second quarter. Our secured debt, as defined in our credit agreement, totaled $3.733 billion, including the term loan balance of $3.291 billion and a revolver balance of $173 million. Our accounts receivable securitization facility had $224 million utilized at the quarter's end.
We continue to enjoy a strong liquidity position overall and at quarter end, had approximately $473 million of available borrowing capacity under our $665 million revolving credit facility and $101 million of balance sheet cash. Based on a trailing adjusted EBITDA, our secured debt ratio improved to 3.22x as of March 30 as compared to 3.33x as of December 30, 2011, and also 3.33x as of April 1, 2011.
Net capital expenditures for the quarter were $71 million compared to $66 million in the prior-year quarter. For the year-to-date, net capital expenditures totaled $145 million, up from $120 million last year as we make appropriate and prudent investments in our physical system and infrastructure and in support of growth. As expected and consistent with historical patterns, working capital was the use of cash flows during the first half of our fiscal year. While some reinvestment in working capital is required in certain sectors and countries in particular improved levels of sales growth, we will continue to maintain a sharp focus on working capital management as we move through the balance of fiscal 2012. For the year-to-date, we've spend a total of $150 million on acquisitions compared to $155 million in the prior-year period. This year's spending, as you know, relates primarily to the acquisition of Filterfresh on the first day of the fiscal year. We do continue to evaluate strategic investment opportunities in certain sectors and geographies, and as we do so, we'll maintain a prudent and disciplined approach in pursuit of these opportunities. Now let me turn the call over to Joe Neubauer.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and again, my personal congratulations to you on your new assignment. As you heard from Fred and Chris, we're coming off a very solid quarter and truly gaining both top line and bottom line momentum in our businesses. A systematic focus
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and again, my personal congratulations to you on your new assignment. As you heard from Fred and Chris, we're coming off a very solid quarter and truly gaining both top line and bottom line momentum in our businesses. A systematic focus on growth and our key operational processes is beginning to pay off and we look for study and continuing progress over the next several years. In the way of transition, I'm sure you've all heard aware by now that after nearly 30 years of CEO of ARAMARK, I'll be turning these responsibilities over, actually, I have turned them over, to Eric Foss. I will remain as Chairman involved in the business and clearly continue to be a significant investor in Aramark as I have been since our original going private transaction way back in 1984. Eric is an outstanding leader with a solid track record of performance in global enterprises. Most recently, Eric was CEO of Pepsi Beverages Company, a $20 billion division of PepsiCo with over 80,000 employees operating in various countries, a private acquisition of Pepsi Bottling Group by PepsiCo. This was one of the 2 acquisitions that they had eight of the bottling business, Eric was the Chairman and CEO of the larger one, Pepsi Bottling Group, an independent publicly owned company with revenues of about $13 billion and operating in about 25 countries.
I'm very proud of the solid management team that we have built here at ARAMARK. Under Eric's leadership, along with Fred and Lynn Mckey, our EVP of Human Resources and the rest of our talented executive team, I'm sure I'm certain that ARAMARK will continue to achieved very high levels of success. I want to personally thank you for your continued support of ARAMARK and assure you that our team will continue to work diligently to earn your confidence and to make this great company even more successful. Thank you.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: I saw on your Q that it looks like you're planning to repay the 5% notes just with your revolver can you tell us what you're thinking with regard to the 8.5% growth in North and the floating rate notes that are due in 2015?
componenttext: I saw on your Q that it looks like you're planning to repay the 5% notes just with your revolver can you tell us what you're thinking with regard to the 8.5% growth in North and the floating rate notes that are due in 2015?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jordan. As we said for some time, the intention was to repay those with the revolver and free cash flow as we work through the second half of the fiscal year. We haven't made any decisions with respect to the 8.5% nor with the floaters at this point
componenttext: Sure, Jordan. As we said for some time, the intention was to repay those with the revolver and free cash flow as we work through the second half of the fiscal year. We haven't made any decisions with respect to the 8.5% nor with the floaters at this point in time. But as you can imagine, we'll continue to validate the capital structure as we move forward and make an appropriate decision about each of those on a timeline that makes sense for us.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Fred. The U.K. continues to be very challenging market, we believe, not only for us but for the other major companies operating in the food and facilities business in that market. And we're actually have improved our earnings in the U.K. year-over
componenttext: This is Fred. The U.K. continues to be very challenging market, we believe, not only for us but for the other major companies operating in the food and facilities business in that market. And we're actually have improved our earnings in the U.K. year-over-year but as we talked about in the earlier calls, we did have a few account losses last year, and that those carry in losses have had a negative impact on our sales this year. But actually, operationally, we've improved the operations in the U.K. quite a bit. Now we're looking forward to getting the U.K. business back on the growth track.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: As you recall, about a year ago, the terrible earthquake and tsunami hit Japan and so the country overall has continued to be impacted by much higher commodity costs, driven by some of the poison-related issues and the food shortage issues, as well as the
componenttext: As you recall, about a year ago, the terrible earthquake and tsunami hit Japan and so the country overall has continued to be impacted by much higher commodity costs, driven by some of the poison-related issues and the food shortage issues, as well as the number of the energy restrictions that the government is placing on business. So dayparts are shorter, workdays are shorter, food costs are higher. I think the team is doing a great job in a challenging environment but we're feeling the effects of the fact that the environment is very different than it was in the preceding quarter a year ago.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012

componenttext: I think what we said on the first couple of calls this year, we won't give you a number but as we said, we're continuing to make investments in our systems infrastructure at a bit of a higher rate than we had historically and with the uniform business back on the growth curve, we're reinvesting in that business in a more typical fashion. So CapEx will be higher than prior year and I think you saw that in the first half and that's something that you should continue to expect to see in the second half.

componenttext: I think we've said our outlook for Europe is guarded. Our southern exposure, if you will, is limited to Spain. Spain has, as you know, a 20% plus unemployment rate. But our business in Spain is mostly focused in education and health care. So we have right now, I think mid-single-digit top line growth in Spain. So we're satisfied with that. I mentioned the U.K., Germany had a mid-single-digit growth rate in the quarter. They had a -- so they're performing both on top and bottom line. On Ireland, while not same robust growth, they're certainly performing better than it did last year. Those are our key countries in Europe.

componenttext: Okay, great. componenttext: Well, we're looking for 20, 30 basis points annual improvement in the margin across the businesses. We've, on a comparable basis, achieved that in the second quarter. We're hopeful we can continue to achieve that during the year, and we're fairly optimistic that we'll be able to continue to achieve that sort of year-over-year performance for the next couple of years. The initiatives are the same related to the major cost drivers in the business, food and labor and the food facilities business and labor/plant cost and merchandise amortization route cost in the uniform business. And we continue to get traction through those initiatives, particularly in the uniform business that you saw our earnings were down slightly year-over-year but that's in the face of significant leads. As I mentioned, significantly higher cost of installation, amortization associated with new merchandise being put in service and higher fuel costs, which were up pretty significantly year-over-year. So it was offsetting that there's a significant improvement in the other operating costs through those efficiency initiatives. So we feel pretty good about it.

And our long-term target in the uniform business is to have more like 50 basis points plus improvement.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon and welcome, ladies and gentlemen to the ARAMARK Corporation's Second Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded for rebroadcast and that all participants are in a liste
componenttext: Good afternoon and welcome, ladies and gentlemen to the ARAMARK Corporation's Second Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded for rebroadcast and that all participants are in a listen-only mode. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Chris Holland, Senior Vice President, Vice -- excuse me, Finance Treasurer. Please proceed, Chris.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kim, and welcome, everyone to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our operations for the second quarter of fiscal 2012. Here with me today are Joe Neubauer, our Chairman; and Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice Presid
componenttext:
Thank you, Kim, and welcome, everyone to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our operations for the second quarter of fiscal 2012. Here with me today are Joe Neubauer, our Chairman; and Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fred and I will present an overview of our second quarter and year-to-date results and business operations. After which, Joe will provide a few closing comments. There will be an opportunity for phone-in participants to ask questions following Joe's remarks.
I'd like to remind you that any recording or other use or transmission of this audio may not be done without the prior written consent of ARAMARK. As we discuss the results, you may want to refer to the Form 10-Q we filed earlier today, which contains our second quarter and year-to-date results for fiscal 2012. Form 10-Q can be found on our website at www.aramark.com.
In today's discussion of results, we mention certain non-GAAP financial measures. The Form 10-Q, as well as schedules we posted to our website prior to the call include reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most comparable GAAP measures as required by SEC rules.
Our discussion of operating income during today's call will, in each instance, exclude the incremental intangibles amortization and property and equipment depreciation expense resulting from the going private transaction and the impact of stock option expense. All of these items are detailed in the schedules posted to our website before the call. In addition, the prior year period results have been restated to present the results of the Galls business as a discontinued operation, as we sold it in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011.
Various remarks that we may make in this call relating to matters that are not historical facts, including remarks about future expectations, anticipation, beliefs, estimates, plans and prospects, constitute forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from those expressed or implied as a result of various risks, uncertainties and important factors, including those discussed in the Risk Factors, MD&A and other sections of our Form 10-K and the Form 10-Q filed earlier today. We disclaim any duty to update or revise such forward-looking statements, whether as a result of future events or otherwise.
Now let me turn the program over to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter 2012 results call. I'd like to review our business and operating results and then have Chris cover a few additional details on our performance.I'm pleased to report results for our seco
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter 2012 results call. I'd like to review our business and operating results and then have Chris cover a few additional details on our performance.
I'm pleased to report results for our second fiscal quarter that further extends this trend of solid operating performance that we have seen in recent quarters. While the economic environment remains a bit uncertain, we believe that our focus on initiatives and investments that position ARAMARK for long-term growth contributed to our strong results for the quarter, continuing to build a solid foundation for the future.
Overall, our performance in the quarter was balanced as our less cyclical businesses delivered another quarter of solid results and our more economically-sensitive businesses continued to show signs of improvement. While higher commodity cost remained a headwind for us in the quarter, the impact on a year-over-year basis has been moderating. Our ongoing efforts to improve our operating efficiencies continue to allow us to leverage our top line sales growth into solid earnings performance.
Now turning to our overall results for the second quarter. We reported sales of $3.3 billion, up 4% on a reported basis and an organic basis. Adjusted operating income of $177 million was up 8% from the prior year level. For the first half of 2012, sales grew by 4% to $6.8 billion or up 3% organically. As we discussed in our first quarter results, sales in the half was reduced somewhat by the impact of the first quarter -- in the first quarter of the NBA lockout and by our serving of the Asian Games in last year's first quarter. The first half adjusted operating income increased by 5% to $388 million. Also, as we discussed last quarter, operating income growth was negatively affected by approximately $4 million planned acquisition-related transition and integration expenses that were absorbed in the first quarter, as well as the recognition last year of approximately $8 million of income related to a compensation agreement signed with the National Park Service, under which, they paid down a portion of our possessory interest in one of our concession contracts. Without these 2 particular items, year-over-year profit growth for the first half would have been in the high single digits.
In our North American Food and Support Services segment, second quarter sales of $2.3 million were up 6% on a reported basis and 4% on an organic basis and primarily by strong growth in our Higher Education business and Health Care and S&E sectors. The first half reported sales of $4.7 billion were up 6% versus the prior year and up 4% organically. Overall sales performance for the first half was led by solid growth in Higher Education and Health Care.
The Business & Industry sector reported a mid single-digit sales increase in the quarter, a single-digit sales increase for the half, reflecting the positive impact from the Filterfresh Office Coffee Services acquisition, which closed in October 2011. The sector also benefited from solid-based and new business growth in our new Facilities Services Business and in our Refreshment Services business. 
Sales in our Education sector were up mid-single digits for the quarter and for the year-to-date, led primarily by continued strong base and new business growth in our Higher Education Food business, as well as solid growth in our K-12 food business.
In the Healthcare sector, sales grew in the high single digits for the quarter and for the year-to-date, driven primarily by the acquisition of Masterplan within our Health Care Technologies business in March 2011, as well as solid base business growth. Sports & Entertainment sales grew in the mid-single digits in the quarter led by solid attendance and positive per capita spending trends in both our NHL and NBA venues. For the year-to-date, sales growth was limited to the low single digits, as a result as I mentioned, of the NBA lockout during the first quarter, as well as the impact of fewer major league baseball playoff games in October versus last year in those stadiums where we provide our services.
Adjusted operating income in the North America Food and Support Services segment was up 11% in the quarter to $130 million. Nearly all segments contributed to profit growth in the quarter, led by strong contributions from higher education and health care. In the first half, segment adjusted operating income grew by 4% to $285 million.
Previously noted, results in the first quarter were negatively affected by approximately $4 million of planned transition and integration expenses for the Filterfresh acquisition. In addition, results for the first quarter of 2011 included approximately eight $8 million of other income related to the compensation agreement with the National Park Service as I mentioned earlier. Excluding these 2 particular items, growth for the first half would've been in the high single digits.
Turning to the International Food and Support Services segment, second quarter reported sales of $672 million were down slightly on a reported basis but up 4% organically versus the year-ago quarter. Organic growth in the quarter was led by strong performance in Germany, South America and China. For the first half, reported sales in International were up 1% and up 5% organically. The first half sales growth also was driven by strong results in Germany, Spain, South America and also, Ireland.
Second quarter adjusted operating income for International of $25 million was up 10% versus the prior year. Results in the second quarter of 2011, you may recall, benefited from a gain from the sale of a small non-core subsidiary in Chile and the receipt of the VAT income in the U.K., partially offset by severance charges in Chile related to the divestiture and a write-down of goodwill in India. Excluding these items from the prior year, profit growth would've been even stronger in the quarter, led by solid performance in Germany, Spain and Chile, partially offset by a profit decline in our AIM joint venture in Japan. The first half adjusted operating income was $48 million, up from $38 million in the prior year. 
In addition to the items I just mentioned, 2011 results also included expenses related to efficiency and cost reduction initiatives including severance charges across several of our countries in the first quarter of 2011 while a smaller amount of expense was recorded in the first half of 2012 further caused reduction and efficiency.
Excluding these expenses in both years, the segment would've still experienced strong income growth in the first half. 
In our Uniform and Career Apparel segment, second quarter sales of $337 million were up 2% on a reported and organic basis. Improving organic growth rates in the Uniform Rental business for the quarter were offset by softness in direct sales, partly reflecting large customer direct sale programs that were launched in the first half of 2011 and that has not been repeated in 2012. For the year-to-date, sales of $678 million were about flat as compared to the same period as in the prior year on both as reported and organic basis. We're continuing to invest in additional rental sales personnel resources to support accelerated sales growth, while maintaining a disciplined approach to contract pricing. We are gaining improved traction in our new sales efforts. During the second quarter and in the first half, volume of new sales delivered by our sales force significantly exceeded the prior year's results, driven both by higher sales force headcount and higher sales rep productivity.
The increased cost, including installation costs associated with substantially higher levels of new business are largely being offset by the successful efficiency initiatives that we have discussed in previous calls. A higher cost related to the increased rates of new sales will continue to depress profit growth over the next few quarters. We believe these efforts will lead to both improving rental sales and profit growth as we move through 2012 and into 2013.
The segment's second quarter adjusted operating income was $30.3 million, down from $32.7 million the prior year quarter, primarily reflecting the incremental expense from our investment in growing the sales force, our garment and isolation cost from the acceleration of new business and the impact of higher energy costs.
In the first half, adjusted operating income was $70 million, down from $74.8 million in the prior year's first half, reflecting all of the items that I just mentioned, as well as severance expense incurred in the first quarter associated with some additional organizational efficiency initiatives following the successful integration of our rental and direct sales operations and the completion of the Galls divestiture.
Corporate expenses, excluding the items Chris mentioned earlier, were $7.5 million in the quarter compared to $8.2 million in the year-ago quarter. First half expenses were $14.6 million compared to $16.5 million in the prior year.
Finally, on a personal note, I'd like to thank Chris Holland for his 8 years of dedicated service as a key member of our finance team. While we all hate to see him go, we recognize the terrific opportunity to be CFO of a very highly respected Fortune 500 company, particularly one located in the same geographical area. It's just too good an opportunity to turn down. We at ARAMARK share in his success. We feel that Chris represent a very good, solid raw material when they brought him here and he was trained well. And so, we're very proud of him. We're also pleased to elevate Karen Wallace to VP and Treasurer. I know many of you on the call know Karen. Karen's worked side-by-side with Chris for the last 7 years on all of our financing. She's well-positioned to fill some pretty big shoes that were worn by Chris. At this point, let me turn it back over to Chris for some additional details on the quarter and on the half.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, Fred, for that comment. I greatly appreciate it. I'd like to now spend a few minutes on our financing capital structure and cash flow. Our adjusted EBITDA for the trailing 12 months ending March 30 was $1.136 billion, up from $1.129 bill
componenttext:
Thanks very much, Fred, for that comment. I greatly appreciate it. I'd like to now spend a few minutes on our financing capital structure and cash flow. Our adjusted EBITDA for the trailing 12 months ending March 30 was $1.136 billion, up from $1.129 billion at December 30, 2011, and up from $1.1 billion even at September 30, 2011. Interest and other financing costs were $119 million for the second quarter compared to $93 million in the prior year. Results for the quarter included approximately $11 million of expenses related to the term loan extension we completed in March. We are very appreciative of the broad support that the extension transaction received from many of you, our investors, and we believe that the success of the extension further enhances our financial and capital structure flexibility.
Also contributing to the year-over-year variance was the recognition in the second quarter of 2011 of interest income of approximately $14 million related to the settlement of U.K. VAT claims from prior years. In the first half, interest and other financing costs were $227 million compared to $202 million in the prior-year, primarily reflecting the 2 items just mentioned. Including the impact of interest rate hedges, approximately 50% of our debt portfolio is at fixed interest rates, and our overall weighted average cost of debt is approximately 5.2%.
Total reported debt at the end of the second quarter was $5.817 billion as compared to $5.739 billion at the end of last year's second quarter. Our secured debt, as defined in our credit agreement, totaled $3.733 billion, including the term loan balance of $3.291 billion and a revolver balance of $173 million. Our accounts receivable securitization facility had $224 million utilized at the quarter's end.
We continue to enjoy a strong liquidity position overall and at quarter end, had approximately $473 million of available borrowing capacity under our $665 million revolving credit facility and $101 million of balance sheet cash. Based on our trailing adjusted EBITDA, our secured debt ratio improved to 3.22x as of March 30 as compared to 3.33x as of December 30, 2011, and also 3.33x as of April 1, 2011.
Net capital expenditures for the quarter were $71 million compared to $66 million in the prior-year quarter. For the year-to-date, net capital expenditures totaled $145 million, up from $120 million last year as we make appropriate and prudent investments in our physical and system infrastructure and in support of growth. As expected and consistent with historical patterns, working capital was the use of cash flows during the first half of our fiscal year. While some reinvestment in working capital is required at certain sectors and countries in particular improved levels of sales growth, we will continue to maintain a sharp focus on working capital management as we move through the balance of fiscal 2012. For the year-to-date, we've spent a total of $150 million on acquisitions compared to $155 million in the prior-year period. This year's spending, as you know, relates primarily to the acquisition of Filterfresh on the first day of the fiscal year. We do continue to evaluate strategic investment opportunities in certain sectors and geographies, and as we do so, we'll maintain a prudent and disciplined approach in pursuit of these opportunities. Now let me turn the call over to Joe Neubauer.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris, and again, my personal congratulations to you on your new assignment. As you heard from Fred and Chris, we're coming off a very solid quarter and clearly gaining both top line and bottom line momentum in our businesses. A systematic focu
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris, and again, my personal congratulations to you on your new assignment. As you heard from Fred and Chris, we're coming off a very solid quarter and clearly gaining both top line and bottom line momentum in our businesses. A systematic focus on growth in our key operational processes is beginning to pay off and we look for steady and continuing progress over the next several years. In the way of transition, I'm sure you've all heard, aware by now that after nearly 30 years as CEO of ARAMARK, I'll be turning these responsibilities over, actually, I have turned them over to Eric Foss. I will remain as Chairman, involved in the business and clearly, continue to be a significant investor in Aramark as I have been since our original going private transaction way back in 1984. Eric is an outstanding leader with a solid track record of performance in global enterprises. Most recently, Eric was CEO of Pepsi Beverages Company, a $20 billion division of PepsiCo with over 80,000 employees operating in various countries. A private acquisition of Pepsi Bottling Group by PepsiCo, this was one of the 2 acquisitions that they had made of the bottling business, Eric was the Chairman and CEO of the larger one, Pepsi Bottling Group, an independent publicly-owned company with revenues of about $13 billion and operating in about 25 countries.
I'm very proud of the solid management team that we have built here at ARAMARK. Under Eric's leadership, along with Fred and Lynn Mckee, our EVP of Human Resources and the rest of our talented executive team, I'm certain that ARAMARK will continue to achieve very high levels of success. I want to personally thank you for your continued support of ARAMARK and assure you that our team will continue to work diligently to earn your confidence and to make this great company even more successful. Thank you.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: I saw on your Q that it looks like you're planning to repay the 5% notes just with your revolver and can you tell us what you're thinking with regard to the 8.5% notes and the floating rate notes that are due in 2015?
componenttext: I saw on your Q that it looks like you're planning to repay the 5% notes just with your revolver and can you tell us what you're thinking with regard to the 8.5% notes and the floating rate notes that are due in 2015?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jordan, yes. As we said for some time, the intention was to repay those with the revolver and free cash flow as we work through the second half of the fiscal year. We haven't made any decisions with respect to the 8.5% nor with the floaters at this
componenttext: Sure, Jordan, yes. As we said for some time, the intention was to repay those with the revolver and free cash flow as we work through the second half of the fiscal year. We haven't made any decisions with respect to the 8.5% nor with the floaters at this point in time. But as you can imagine, we'll continue to valuate the capital structure as we move forward and make an appropriate decision about each of those on a timeline that makes sense for us.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then it looked like you noticed some weakness in the International segment in the U.K. Can you talk a little bit about what may have caused that?
componenttext: And then it looked like you noticed some weakness in the International segment in the U.K. Can you talk a little bit about what may have caused that?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Fred. The U.K. continues to be a very challenging market, we believe, not only for us but for the other major companies operating in the Food and Facilities business in that market. And we're actually -- have improved our earnings in the U.K. year
componenttext: This is Fred. The U.K. continues to be a very challenging market, we believe, not only for us but for the other major companies operating in the Food and Facilities business in that market. And we're actually -- have improved our earnings in the U.K. year-over-year but as we talked about in the earlier calls, we did have a few account losses last year, and that those carry-in losses have had a negative impact on our sales this year. But actually, operationally, we've improved the operations in the U.K. quite a bit. Now we're looking forward to getting the U.K. business back on the growth track.

componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And in Japan, you mentioned that well, AIM had a gross dollar decline, not a ton but just about $1 million and then gross margin rate was down about 130 basis points. What caused the weakness there or I guess, the year-over-year decline?
componenttext: Okay, great. And in Japan, you mentioned that well, AIM had a gross dollar decline, not a ton but just about $1 million and then gross margin rate was down about 130 basis points. What caused the weakness there or I guess, the year-over-year decline?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: As you recall, about a year ago, the terrible earthquake and tsunami hit Japan and so the country overall has continued to be impacted by much higher commodity costs, driven by some of the poison-related issues and the food shortage issues, as well as a n
componenttext: As you recall, about a year ago, the terrible earthquake and tsunami hit Japan and so the country overall has continued to be impacted by much higher commodity costs, driven by some of the poison-related issues and the food shortage issues, as well as a number of the energy restrictions that the government is placing on business. So day parts are shorter, workdays are shorter, food costs are higher. I think the team is doing a great job in a challenging environment but we're feeling the effects of the fact that the environment is very different than it was in the preceding quarter a year ago.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then lastly just on CapEx, what CapEx are you looking at for the fiscal year?

componenttext: I think what we said on the first couple of calls this year, we won't give you a number but as we said, we're continuing to make investments in our systems infrastructure at a bit of a higher rate than we had historically. And with the Uniform business back on the growth curve, we're reinvesting in that business in a more typical fashion. So CapEx will be higher than prior year and I think you saw that in the first half and that's something that you should continue to expect to see in the second half.

componenttext: Seriously, best of luck. First question is, when you look at your European operations overall, did you notice a difference in the sales momentum, particularly in the southern part of the continent? And can you just talk about the overall momentum in Europe?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think we'd say, our outlook for Europe is guarded. Our southern exposure, if you will, is limited to Spain. Spain has, as you know, a 20% plus unemployment rate. But our business in Spain is mostly focused in Education and Health Care. So we have, right
componenttext: I think we'd say, our outlook for Europe is guarded. Our southern exposure, if you will, is limited to Spain. Spain has, as you know, a 20% plus unemployment rate. But our business in Spain is mostly focused in Education and Health Care. So we have, right now, I think, mid single-digit top line growth in Spain. So we're satisfied with that. I mentioned the U.K., Germany had a mid single-digit growth rate in the quarter. They had a -- so they're performing well both on top and bottom line. And Ireland, well not same robust growth but certainly, performing better than it did last year. Those are our key countries in Europe.

componenttext: I'd say the pace of opportunities is pretty standard or pretty consistent with what it was a year ago. And evaluations are also pretty consistent. We certainly haven't seen any big uptick. And as you expect often, the valuations are a function of how unique the particular company's position is and what the potential synergies are on the part of an acquirer. But outside of that, it hasn't -- I don't think it has really changed much in the last 12 months.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's pretty comparable, Bryan. It is, because we operate some very large buildings, they can actually year-to-year, be impacted by just the fact that some of these huge shows rotate around the country. And so, you can have noise year-to-year
componenttext: Yes, I think it's pretty comparable, Bryan. It is, because we operate some very large buildings, they can actually year-to-year, be impacted by just the fact that some of these huge shows rotate around the country. And so, you can have noise year-to-year because a huge electronics show is in one of our venues 1 year and it just isn't the next year. And so, if you strip that out, the business has been, I think, pretty stable now here for the last 24 to 36 months, frankly.

componenttext: And then you've got the Olympics coming up in London. Is there a number you can throw around the potential revenue impact? I know it's usually not a big margin contributor at the end of the day but can you give us an idea of what type of numerical impact it could have to revenues?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think -- certainly, to the overall company, it's immaterial. It's in the $50 million range on the top line and I think as we talked historically, we don't do these to make a lot of money. It's a usually complex operation that we're very proud of, a
componenttext: Yes, I think -- certainly, to the overall company, it's immaterial. It's in the $50 million range on the top line and I think as we talked historically, we don't do these to make a lot of money. It's a usually complex operation that we're very proud of, and have a great track record in doing. It's a great way to motivate our teams and a great accomplishment for the company overall. But as a financial event per se certainly, for the company, it's relatively immaterial.

componenttext: And I'll add one more question. When you look -- I guess coming out of fiscal '11 into fiscal '12, I think a round lot number was that you all had booked incremental business that could contribute roughly $1 billion worth of revenue. Has that run rate of bookings changed at all?

componenttext: Well, we don't typically -- I don't think we've disclosed the run rate of new business in the past. I mean, what I can tell you though is that the annualized run rate -- the annualized sales of new business signed year-to-date this year is ahead of last year by double digits. So we're feeling pretty good about that. The new -- the value [ph] the annualized sales, those with new contracts signed is up year-to-date versus last year and lost business is actually down year-to-date versus last year.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Can you bring us up-to-date on your initiatives around operating efficiencies? If you've achieved a higher run rate here in your March quarter, what your targets might be directionally for the balance of the year and the next couple of years? What steps a
componenttext: Can you bring us up-to-date on your initiatives around operating efficiencies? If you've achieved a higher run rate here in your March quarter, what your targets might be directionally for the balance of the year and the next couple of years? What steps are being rolled out? I know you've talked about it in the last couple of quarters but it seems like a sizable opportunity.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, we're looking for 20, 30 basis points of annual improvement in the margin across the businesses. We've, on a comparable basis, achieved that in the second quarter. We're hopeful we can continue to achieve that during the year and we're fairly optimi
componenttext: Well, we're looking for 20, 30 basis points of annual improvement in the margin across the businesses. We've, on a comparable basis, achieved that in the second quarter. We're hopeful we can continue to achieve that during the year and we're fairly optimistic that we'll be able to continue to achieve that sort of year-over-year performance for the next couple of years. The initiatives are the same related to the major cost drivers in the business, food and labor in the food facilities business and labor/plant cost and merchandise amortization around cost in the uniform business. And we continue to get traction through those initiatives, particularly in the uniform business that you saw our earnings were down slightly year-over-year but that's in the face of significantly, as I mentioned, significantly a higher cost of installation, amortization associated with new merchandise being put in service and higher the fuel costs, which were up pretty significantly year-over-year. So it was offsetting that as a significant improvement in the other operating costs through those efficiency initiatives. So we feel pretty good about it.

componenttextpreview: And the 20 to 30 basis points, that's company-wide and is it about the same in each of the major segments or is there a bigger opportunity in USFS because it's a larger business, so a bigger pool of costs?
componenttext: And the 20 to 30 basis points, that's company-wide and is it about the same in each of the major segments or is there a bigger opportunity in USFS because it's a larger business, so a bigger pool of costs?

componenttext: I have to be careful since I have oversight responsibility for the Uniform business and the Chairman's sitting here as we talk about where the margin improvement is going to be, I have a -- I'm in a conflict here. But having said that, between -- I think it's fair to say between the domestic and international Food and Facilities business, we have similar expectations. On the one hand, the initiatives are further along in North America. On the other hand, the margins are somewhat lower in International and there's -- we're working at those things to try to get better scale across countries which is not so much an opportunity in the U.S. because we've -- it's essentially 1 business. In the Uniform business, we expect better margin improvement and in the Food and Facilities business, if you think about the margin, it's about double. And our long-term target in the Uniform business is to have more like 50 basis points plus improvement.

componenttext: But in general, I would say that on the food support side, it's proportional to our volumes throughout the world. Clearly, North America is the biggest part that we have and we would expect the most movement there and it spreads out because the uniform business is a higher margin business. You would expect improvements to be significantly higher there. It's proportionate to both the sales and the margin.

componenttext: Okay. You mentioned that with the scale that you have in the U.S. businesses, are there some segments in the U.S. or other businesses that you can square out to acquisitions, improved scale or actually get some scale to get the efficiency that you are achieving? And are there increased activity as far as potential targets that would be of interest to you?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, May 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, the acquisitions in North America would be driven more by a combination of wanting to strategically build out a portion of the business, the strength in a particular service, major service line or to achieve attractive synergies associated with the
componenttext: Well, the acquisitions in North America would be driven more by a combination of wanting to strategically build out a portion of the business, the strength in a particular service, major service line or to achieve attractive synergies associated with the combination. So it's not that the acquisitions themselves, apart from the synergies, operational synergies, don't scale. And driving more scale in North America in general, is not a big benefit for us. It would be more specific synergies related to that acquisition or the coagulation of the 2 companies.
