headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon and welcome, ladies and gentlemen to the ARAMARK Corporation Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded for rebroadcast and that all participants are in a lis
componenttext: Good afternoon and welcome, ladies and gentlemen to the ARAMARK Corporation Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded for rebroadcast and that all participants are in a listen-only mode. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Karen Wallace, Vice President and Treasurer. Please go ahead, Karen.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you and welcome to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our operations for the third quarter of fiscal 2012. Here with me today is Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fred and I will p
componenttext:
Thank you and welcome to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our operations for the third quarter of fiscal 2012. Here with me today is Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fred and I will present an overview of our third quarter and year-to-date results and business operations, after which, there'll be an opportunity for phone in participants to ask questions.
I'd like to remind you that any recording or other use or transmission of this audio may not be done without the prior written consent of ARAMARK. As we discuss the results, you may want to refer to the Form 10-Q we filed earlier today, which contains our second quarter results for fiscal 2012. This Form 10-Q can be found on our website at www.aramark.com. Fred and I
In today's discussion of results, we mention certain non-GAAP financial measures. The Form 10-Q, as well as schedules we posted to our website prior to the call, include reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most comparable GAAP measures as required by SEC rules. Our discussion of operating income during today's call will, in each instance, exclude the incremental intangibles amortization and property and equipment depreciation expense resulting from the going private transaction, the impact of stock option expense and the impact on the change in fair value related to our gasoline and diesel fuel agreements. All of these items are detailed in the schedules posted to our website before the call. In addition, the prior year period results have been restated to present the results of the Galls business as a discontinued operation, as we sold it in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011.
Various remarks that we make in this call relating to matters that are not historical facts, including remarks about future expectations, anticipation, beliefs, estimates, plans and prospects, constitute forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from those expressed or implied as a result of various risks, uncertainties and important factors, including those discussed in the Risk Factors, MD&A and other sections of our Form 10-K and the Form 10-Q filed earlier today. We disclaim any duty to update or revise such forward-looking statements, whether as a result of future events or otherwise.
I will now turn the program over to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everybody and thanks for joining us for our third quarter 2012 results call. As we've done in prior quarters, I'd like to review our business and operating results, and then Karen will cover a few additional details on our performance focu
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everybody and thanks for joining us for our third quarter 2012 results call. As we've done in prior quarters, I'd like to review our business and operating results, and then Karen will cover a few additional details on our performance focused on cash flow and the balance sheet.
During the quarter, we saw significant slowing in U.S. job growth and continued economic uncertainty in Europe. Our organic growth rate declined slightly in part due to the normal seasonal mix shift between our higher growing education business and our slower growing business in Sports & Entertainment sectors. We continue to see positive growth trend in certain of our sectors as a result of contributions from both base business and new business wins. Year-to-date, our new customer sales are growing in the double digits and net new business results are also quite strong. Our client retention rates have been consistent with our expectations and better than prior year's results. But with the economic and environment weakening as the year progresses, we remain cautious and continue to maintain a very tight focus on efficiently managing our operations and our cost structure.
So now turning to our overall results for the third quarter, we achieved sales of $3.3 billion, which was up 2% as reported from the prior-year quarter. Organic sales growth, which I mentioned earlier, and excludes the impact of currency translations and acquisitions and divestitures, was up 3% in the quarter. Adjusted operating income was $157 million, up 2% versus the prior year. For the first 9 months of fiscal 2012, sales were $10.1 billion, up 3% over the prior year period on both a reported and on a nonorganic growth basis. Our adjusted operating income of $544 million was up 4% from the prior year.
Now turning to our North American Food and Support Services segment, third quarter reported sales are up 2% of $2.3 billion, primarily by growth rate in the Higher Education business and Business & Industry and Sports & Entertainment sectors. Organic sales growth was 3% in the quarter. For the 9 months, reported sales were up 5% to $7.1 billion an organic growth of 3%. Year-to-date performance was also led by solid growth in most sectors and particularly strong growth in higher education.
Turning now to the sectors within North America, our Business & Industry sector had a mid-single digit sales increase for the quarter and high single-digit sales increase for the 9 months. This reflects the positive impact from the Filterfresh acquisition, which closed on 2011, October 2011. Our B&I facilities business also contributed to the increase in the quarter with our remote services growth primarily in Canada and our business dine-in operations during the year was pretty much flat year-over-year.
The Education sector had low single-digit sales growth for the quarter and mid-single-digit sales growth for the 9 months, with growth in our Higher Education Food business resulting from a good combination of base business growth and strong new sales from contract wins in prior periods.
In our Health Care sector, we saw a slight decline in the quarter and mid-single-digit sales growth for the 9 months. The sales declined in the quarter was a result of modest base business growth that was offset by lower net new business. The growth for the 9-month period was primarily a result of the acquisition in March 2011 of Masterplan within our Health Care Technologies business.
Our Sports & Entertainment sector had low single-digit sales growth for the quarter and for the 9 months. But for the quarter, we've seen pretty solid performance in our Major League Baseball venues, with growth in both the tenants and per capita spending and good growth in our amphitheater future business, with a significant increase in the number of shows and attendance growth. Our growth over the nine-month period was negatively in impacted by the NDA strike in the first quarter but that was offset more or less by solid results during the NHL season and recent strength in NOV performance as I mentioned. Adjusted operating income in the North American Food services segment 5% in the quarter to $130 million, led by profit growth in our Higher Education business. For the 9 months, segment adjusted operating income grew 5% to $388 million, again led by strong profit growth in Higher Education business and Health Care sector, offset by profit decline in our Business & Industry sector. Our results for the 9 months were reduced by approximately $4 million of planned acquisition-related transition and integration cost absorbed in the first quarter, as well as the recognition as we mentioned last year -- during last year of approximately $8 million of income related to a compensation agreement signed with the National Park Service under which they paid down a portion of our possessed reinterest in light of our concession contracts. Without these 2 particular items, year-over-year profit growth for the 9 months would have been in the high single digits.
Now turning to the International Food and Support Services segment, third quarter reported sales of $674 million were down 3% from the prior year period, primarily due to the strengthening of the U.S. dollar. Organic sales growth for the quarter was actually 4% due to positive growth in Ireland, South America and China that was partially offset by sales declines in the U.K. and Spain. For the 9 months, reported sales of $2 billion decreased 1% compared to the prior year, also primarily due to the stronger dollar. Organic growth was 4%, again led primarily by growth in Germany, Ireland, South America and China, which more than offset a sales decline in U.K. and Belgium.
Third quarter adjusted operating income was $25 million, which was about even when compared to the prior-year quarter. But currency translation negatively affected profit growth by approximately 8 percentage points. Results in the quarter primarily reflects improving profit performance in the U.K, Ireland in Chile, offsetting a profit decline in Continental Europe. For the 9 months, adjusted operating income was $74 million, up from $64 million in the prior year. Growth was driven by the U.K, Ireland, Germany, Spain, Chile and China, partially offset by Belgium and by our AIM joint venture in Japan. Currency translation also negatively affected profit growth by approximately 3 percentage points.
You may recall there are a number of unusual items last year and a couple this year in the International segment. In 2012, we recorded 7 related charges in VAT income in the U.K. and in 2011, the results included a gain of the sale of a noncore subsidiary in Chile, through the receipt of the VAT income in the U.K, gain on the sale of land in Chile, severance related charges and the write-down on that of the goodwill and other intangible assets relating to our operations in India. Adjusting for currency translation and these unusual items in both years, adjusted operating income would've grown by double digits versus last year.
In our Uniform and Career Apparel segment, third quarter sales were $343 million were up 3% from the year-ago quarter on both a reported and organic basis. Improving organic growth rates in the uniform rental business, which were in the mid-single digits for the quarter, were offset by softness in our direct sale business, partially reflecting large customer direct sale programs, which were launched in the first half of 2011 that have not been repeated in 2012. And for the 9 months, segment sales of $1 billion were up 1% for the prior year on a reported and organic basis. We continue to invest in additional rental sales personnel resources to support accelerated new sales growth while maintaining a disciplined approach to contract pricing. We are gaining improved traction in our new sales efforts and continue to gain momentum as the volume of new sales in the third quarter and for the 9 months delivered by our sales force significantly exceeded the prior year results, driven by both higher sales headcount and higher sales productivity. The segment's third quarter adjusted operating income was $37 million, which was about even with the same period last year and for the 9 months. Adjusted operating income was $107 million, down from $112 million for the same period last year. As we have discussed in previous quarters, the increased sales costs, including installation costs associated with substantially higher levels of new business and higher merchandise amortization will continue to press profit growth in the near term. But we of course, believe these efforts will lead to both improving rental sales and profit growth as we move forward.
Corporate expenses, excluding the items that Karen mentioned earlier, were $9 million in the quarter compared to $7.2 million a year ago. And for the 9 months, expenses were $24.9 million compared to $23.7 million in the prior year. To this point, let me turn it back to Karen for some additional details on the quarter and our year-to-date performance.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Fred. I'd like to comment on our financing, capital structure and cash flow. Our adjusted EBITDA for the trailing 12 months ending June 29 was $1.136 billion, which was about equal to the $1.136 billion we reported as of March 31, 2012, and up fro
componenttext:
Thanks, Fred. I'd like to comment on our financing, capital structure and cash flow. Our adjusted EBITDA for the trailing 12 months ending June 29 was $1.136 billion, which was about equal to the $1.136 billion we reported as of March 31, 2012, and up from $1.1 billion at September 30, 2011. Interest and other financing costs were $88 million for the third quarter compared to $113 million in the prior year. Our interest expense in the quarter was lower primarily as a result of a number of interest rate swaps that matured at the end of March, 2012. For the 9 months, interest and other financing costs were $315 million, equal to the prior year's expense.
In the second quarter of 2012, we recorded approximately $11 million of expenses related to the term loan extension we completed that quarter. In 2011, we had interest income of approximately $14 million recorded related to the settlement of U.K. VAT claims from prior period. Including the impact of interest rate hedges, approximately 50% of our total debt portfolio is at fixed interest rates and our overall weighted average cost of debt is approximately 5.1%.
Total reported debt at the end of the third quarter was $5.782 billion. Our secured debt, as defined in our credit agreement, totaled $3.953 billion, including a term loan balance of $3.281 billion and a revolver balance of $375 million. In June 2012, we amended our accounts receivable securitization facility, increasing the maximum amount from $250 million to $300 million and extending the maturity date to January 2015. The facility had $253 million utilized at quarter-end. During the quarter, our $250 million, 5% note matured and were repaid with revolver borrowings, which did not increase our total debt. We had approximately $273 million of available capacity under our revolving credit facility as of quarter-end. Based on our trailing adjusted EBITDA, our secured debt ratio was 3.41x as of June 29, up modestly from 3.22x as of March 30, 2012, and equal to the 3.41x reported as  of July 1, 2011. This slight increase in the ratio from March 30, reflects a utilization of the revolver to fund the 5% note redemption. Overall, we are pleased with our EBITDA growth and our ratio momentum and we anticipate further ratio improvement over time. Net capital expenditures for the quarter were $74 million compared to $60 million in the prior-year quarter. For the year-to-date, net capital expenditures totaled $219 million compared to $180 million in the same period last year as we focused on making prudent investments in growth opportunities and in our infrastructure.
As expected and consistent with historical patterns, working capital was a use of cash flows during the first 9 months of our fiscal year. We are continuing to maintain a focused on working capital management as we move through the fourth quarter, which is our strongest seasonal period from a working capital and free cash flow standpoint. For the year-to-date, we have spent a total of $151 million on acquisitions compared to $157 million in the prior year period. This year's spending related primarily to the acquisition of Filterfresh within our North American refreshment services business in October of 2011. We continue to evaluate and seek to make strategic investments in certain sectors and geographies but will be prudent and disciplined in the pursuit of these opportunities. Now let me turn the call back over to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Karen. So summing up our performance so far this year, for Global Food and Support Services business has delivered solid organic growth with strong profit growth. The Uniform Rental business is gaining traction from the significant investment we'v
componenttext:
Thanks, Karen. So summing up our performance so far this year, for Global Food and Support Services business has delivered solid organic growth with strong profit growth. The Uniform Rental business is gaining traction from the significant investment we've made over the past several quarters and accelerating new sales and now is performing at the mid-single-digit growth levels. As we look forward, while we will be working to deliver improving organic growth rates and continued margin improvement, slowing economic growth will clearly pose a challenge to certain sectors and countries. We believe that there are many attractive growth opportunities in front of us despite the economic climate as many of our sectors remain significantly under penetrated. We remain excited about pursuing these opportunities.
Overall, we continue to benefit from our portfolio of sectors, geographies and clients, which we feel provide us with good balance. We plan to invest appropriately in the pursuit of these many opportunities in the months and years ahead, while still managing our cost structure and cash flow in a very disciplined manner. Thank you again, for your time this afternoon and for your support of ARAMARK as always. We would now be happy to take questions.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  And our first question today will come from Carla Casella with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  And our first question today will come from Carla Casella with JPMorgan.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you can talk about the U.K. business and if you have any impact on the Olympic -- of the Olympics. We are hearing that businesses have been encouraging employees to work from home during the Olympics and wondering if this has an impact on
componenttext: I'm wondering if you can talk about the U.K. business and if you have any impact on the Olympic -- of the Olympics. We are hearing that businesses have been encouraging employees to work from home during the Olympics and wondering if this has an impact on you.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Carla, we really have 2 impacts. One is the Olympics themselves, as you I'm sure know, we are the food service provider to the athletes for the summer games as we have been since 1968 in Mexico City. And then there's a negative impact, which is the one yo
componenttext: Carla, we really have 2 impacts. One is the Olympics themselves, as you I'm sure know, we are the food service provider to the athletes for the summer games as we have been since 1968 in Mexico City. And then there's a negative impact, which is the one you mentioned. And I think it's fair to say we're feeling both of those. So our base U.K. business is the only some negative effect from the Olympics, as you know, there was quite a bit of controversy about the traffic and the setup of the special dedicated traffic lanes for VIPs and the like. And our sense is that many people, particularly focused on taking vacation at this time. On the other hand, we will clearly have sales associated with what's going to be a incredibly successful performance by us in feeding athletes at the Olympic Games. If not, as you know really very much in the way of profit for us but it does -- it creates a fair amount of sales, which I'm sure from a sales point of view would more than offset the weakness in our base U.K. operations.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then on the Uniform business, can you talk about how much of that now there is rental?
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then on the Uniform business, can you talk about how much of that now there is rental?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: About 90%, between 85% and 90% of our total sales are rental. And the direct sale is the balance.
componenttext: About 90%, between 85% and 90% of our total sales are rental. And the direct sale is the balance.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then on the commodity cost front, can you talk about how you expect that to flow through your numbers with the increasing commodities and what changes you can make to offset that?
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then on the commodity cost front, can you talk about how you expect that to flow through your numbers with the increasing commodities and what changes you can make to offset that?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. Based on our overall market basket, we've seen relatively benign levels of food cost increases so far this year. And in the low single-digit range. We haven't seen any major uptick in that right now. We're obviously, keeping a close eye on it. I thi
componenttext: Sure. Based on our overall market basket, we've seen relatively benign levels of food cost increases so far this year. And in the low single-digit range. We haven't seen any major uptick in that right now. We're obviously, keeping a close eye on it. I think next year, our forecast is to have price increases more in the 4%, 4.5% range overall of our basket. And as you know we have tremendous flexibility on our operations to manage against this, since we have pretty much in most of our operations outside of the corrections business, which is relatively small, significant control over the menus, how those menus are in engineered -- the items are engineered, the mix of items on the menus. So we're focused on it. I think we'll probably make even a greater, more focused effort as we move into next year in both our retail and our contract pricing. And we'll be on top of it from a mix perspective.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think there are always opportunities. We -- we're particularly focused on Refreshment Services and what we now call Health Care Technologies, the clinical equipment management business, which those 2 acquisitions were to further solidify our lead p
componenttext: Yes, I think there are always opportunities. We -- we're particularly focused on Refreshment Services and what we now call Health Care Technologies, the clinical equipment management business, which those 2 acquisitions were to further solidify our lead positions in those markets. And we're pleased overall, with those acquisitions and they certainly put us in the market -- in a strong market position as we have targeted. Outside of that, the opportunities are always around acquisitions in the Uniform business. The potential to expand our facilities business around the world and then a couple of countries potentially we'd like to be in that we're not being. So I wouldn't expect the acquisition opportunity in the next 12 months to be really significant. But there are a couple of things in the pipeline that may come to fruition over the next 9 to 12 months.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, our German business is flattened somewhat in the third quarter. So to be fair, I would say that Germany is not as strong as it was earlier in the year. So I take that as our -- what we're seeing to be pretty consistent with what you hear with respec
componenttext: Well, our German business is flattened somewhat in the third quarter. So to be fair, I would say that Germany is not as strong as it was earlier in the year. So I take that as our -- what we're seeing to be pretty consistent with what you hear with respect to the German economy overall. And in Spain, it's a challenge. It's a real challenge. We have a benefit -- we have an advantage and a bit of a disadvantage. The advantage in Spain is we're not really very strong at all in the business -- in the B&I market. We're strong in education, particularly K-12, and that's been solid. But we also have a pretty decent sized business in health care, in some portion of that or public health care institutions. And those are typically funded at the state levels. And as you know in Spain, there's quite a bit of back and forth between the space and the Federal Government with respect to funding. So that's clearly put some pressure on our Health Care clients. So, yes, I'd say in Spain, it's a challenge. Now fortunately for us, Spain is not a huge operation.

componenttext: Yes, Reza. We've pushed out the vast majority of our term loans for the next significant maturity we've got coming up of roughly $650 million of nonextended term loan that would be maturing in January 2014. So we kind of got a little bit of time here before we need to address that. But generally speaking, we're in good shape.

componenttext: In terms of the acquisition part, maybe reverse that. Are there parts of your business that you would look to perhaps exit, or perhaps the growth isn't there or the economic challenges makes the opportunities more difficult than you thought?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think it's difficult to answer that question definitively. Let's start with the U.S. I mean, clearly, our -- we have business that are growing in different growth rates and some have more potential than others. All of our -- we operate in pretty high re
componenttext: I think it's difficult to answer that question definitively. Let's start with the U.S. I mean, clearly, our -- we have business that are growing in different growth rates and some have more potential than others. All of our -- we operate in pretty high return on investment businesses. And so all of our businesses are more than earning their cost of capital. So I think generally, in North America, which is of course, the bulk of our overall sales, frequently you can include uniform. I don't think it's primarily a matter of exiting certain businesses, I think it's more of a matter of internal resource allocation, capital allocation, sales resource and those sorts of things. And I think you'll find its probably more discriminating in that sense in that regard than we have been. Overall, outside of the U.S. in our base countries, our big countries, even though a couple of them are struggling because of the economy, we see those as long-term -- generally, as long-term plays in countries which at least over the intermediate term, we think we can add value we want to stay in. The smaller ones we're always evaluating but it sort of hard to make a specific statement on the smaller ones.

componenttext: Okay. And with those economies that have been struggling, or is that creating opportunities that you see to enter new markets, perhaps with a longer-term viewpoint?

componenttext: It does. I have to say that we haven't been very aggressive about that. I think in part because we're happy with the business that we have. But given the longer-term uncertainty, I think we'd like to see a few more cards played to see how some of these economies really level out and how they level out before we would be contributing really, investing more capital in those countries, the ones that are struggling.

componenttext: Well, it's hard to tell. I mean, we can all speculate. But let me put it this way, we're-- our current thinking is that there's no reason to believe that 2013 is going to be substantially different from where we sit today. And could it be a little weaker? My guess is the chances are -- chances of being a little weaker or stronger is probably higher. So we're -- as we start to think forward to October, which is the beginning of our next fiscal year, and I can tell you we're not intrinsically counting on some pickup on the overall economy. And so we're planning in accordance with that.

componenttext: Yes, I don't think at this point there's anything that need to be immediately addressed. Our next significant debt maturities is not until January of 2014. I think we're fairly comfortable with where we sit right now.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon and welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to the ARAMARK Corporation Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded for rebroadcast and that all participants are in a li
componenttext: Good afternoon and welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to the ARAMARK Corporation Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded for rebroadcast and that all participants are in a listen-only mode. At the request of the company, we will open the conference up for questions after the presentation. I will now turn the call over to Karen Wallace, Vice President and Treasurer. Please go ahead, Karen.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you and welcome to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our operations for the third quarter of fiscal 2012. Here with me today is Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fred and I will p
componenttext:
Thank you and welcome to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our operations for the third quarter of fiscal 2012. Here with me today is Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fred and I will present an overview of our third quarter and year-to-date results and business operations, after which, there will be an opportunity for phone in participants to ask questions.
I would like to remind you that any recording or other use or transmission of this audio may not be done without the prior written consent of ARAMARK. As we discuss the results, you may want to refer to the Form 10-Q we filed earlier today, which contains our third quarter results for fiscal 2012. This Form 10-Q can be found on our website at www.aramark.com.
In today's discussion of results, we mention certain non-GAAP financial measures. The Form 10-Q, as well as schedules we posted to our website prior to the call, include reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most comparable GAAP measures as required by SEC rules. Our discussion of operating income during today's call will, in each instance, exclude the incremental intangibles amortization and property and equipment depreciation expense resulting from the going private transaction, the impact of stock option expense and the impact on the change in fair value related to our gasoline and diesel fuel agreements. All of these items are detailed in the schedules posted to our website before this call. In addition, the prior year period results have been restated to present the results of the Galls business as a discontinued operation, as we sold it in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011.
Various remarks that we make in this call relating to matters that are not historical facts, including remarks about future expectations, anticipation, belief, estimates, plans and prospects, constitute forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from those expressed or implied as a result of various risks, uncertainties and important factors, including those discussed in the Risk Factors, MD&A and other sections of our Form 10-K and the Form 10-Q filed earlier today. We disclaim any duty to update or revise such forward-looking statements, whether as a result of future events or otherwise.
I will now turn the program over to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everybody and thanks for joining us for our third quarter 2012 results call. As we've done in prior quarters, I'd like to review our business and operating results, and then Karen will cover a few additional details on our performance focu
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everybody and thanks for joining us for our third quarter 2012 results call. As we've done in prior quarters, I'd like to review our business and operating results, and then Karen will cover a few additional details on our performance focused on cash flow and the balance sheet.
During the quarter, we saw significant slowing in U.S. job growth and continued economic uncertainty in Europe. Our organic growth rate declined slightly in part due to the normal seasonal mix shift between our higher growing Education business and our slower growing business in Sports & Entertainment sectors. We continue to see positive growth trends in certain of our sectors as a result of contributions from both base business and new business wins. Year-to-date, our new customer sales are growing in the double digits and net new business results are also quite strong. Our client retention rates have been consistent with our expectations and better than prior year's results. But with the economic and environment weakening as the year progresses, we remain cautious and continue to maintain a very tight focus on efficiently managing our operations and our cost structure.
So now turning to our overall results for the third quarter, we achieved sales of $3.3 billion, which was up 2% as reported from the prior year quarter. Organic sales growth, which I mentioned earlier, and excludes the impact of currency translations and acquisitions and divestitures, was up 3% in the quarter. Adjusted operating income was $157 million, up 2% versus the prior year. For the first 9 months of fiscal 2012, sales were $10.1 billion, up 3% over the prior year period on both a reported and an organic growth basis. Our adjusted operating income of $544 million was up 4% from the prior year.
Now turning to our North America Food and Support Services segment, third quarter reported sales were up 3% to $2.3 billion, led primarily by growth in the Higher Education business and Business & Industry and Sports & Entertainment sectors. Organic sales growth was 3% in the quarter. For the 9 months, reported sales were up 5% to $7.1 billion on organic growth of 3%. Year-to-date performance was also led by solid growth in most sectors and particularly strong growth in Higher Education.
Turning now to the sectors within North America, our Business & Industry sector had a mid-single digit sales increase for the quarter and a high single-digit sales increase for the 9 months. This reflects the positive impact from the Filterfresh acquisition, which closed on 2011, October of 2011. Our B&I facilities business also contributed to the increase in the quarter with our remote services growth primarily in Canada, and our business dining operations during the year were pretty much flat year-over-year.
The Education sector had low single-digit sales growth for the quarter and mid-single-digit sales growth for the 9 months, with growth in our Higher Education food business resulting from a good combination of base business growth and strong new sales from contract wins in prior periods.
In our Healthcare sector, we saw a slight decline in the quarter and mid-single-digit sales growth for the 9 months. The sales decline in the quarter was a result of modest base business growth that was offset by lower net new business. The growth for the 9-month period was primarily a result of the acquisition in March 2011 of Masterplan within our Healthcare Technologies business.
Our Sports & Entertainment sector had low single-digit sales growth for the quarter and for the 9 months. But for the quarter, we've seen pretty solid performance in our Major League Baseball venues, with growth in both the tenants and per capita spending and good growth in our amphitheater business, with a significant increase in the number of shows and attendance growth. Our growth for the 9-month period was negatively affected by the NBA strike in our first quarter, but that was offset more or less by solid results during the NHL season and recent strength in MLB performance as I mentioned. Adjusted operating income in the North American Food and Support Services segment increased by 5% in the quarter to $103 million, led by profit growth in our Higher Education business. For the 9 months, segment adjusted operating income grew 5% to $388 million, again led by strong profit growth in Higher Education business and the Healthcare sector, offset by profit decline in our Business & Industry sector. Our results for the 9 months were reduced by approximately $4 million of planned acquisition-related transition and integration cost absorbed in the first quarter, as well as the recognition as we mentioned last year -- during last year of approximately $8 million of income related to a compensation agreement signed with the National Park Service under which they paid down a portion of our possessed reinterest in one of our concession contracts. Without these 2 particular items, year-over-year profit growth for the 9 months would have been in the high single digits.
Now turning to the International Food and Support Services segment, third quarter reported sales of $674 million were down 3% from the prior year period, primarily due to the strengthening of the U.S. dollar. Organic sales growth for the quarter was actually 4% due to positive growth in Ireland, South America and China, that was partially offset by sales declines in the U.K. and Spain. For the 9 months, reported sales of $2 billion decreased 1% compared to the prior year, also primarily due to the stronger dollar. Organic growth was 4%, again led primarily by growth in Germany, Ireland, South America and China, which more than offset a sales decline in the U.K. and Belgium.
Third quarter adjusted operating income was $25 million, which was about even when compared to the prior year quarter. But currency translation negatively affected profit growth by approximately 8 percentage points. Results in the quarter primarily reflect the improving profit performance in the U.K, Ireland and Chile, offsetting a profit decline in continental Europe. For the 9 months, adjusted operating income was $74 million, up from $64 million in the prior year. Growth was driven by the U.K, Ireland, Germany, Spain, Chile and China, partially offset by Belgium and by our AIM joint venture in Japan. Currency translation also negatively affected profit growth by approximately 3 percentage points.
You may recall, there are a number of unusual items last year and a couple this year in the International segment. In 2012, we recorded severance-related charges and VAT income in the U.K. and in 2011, the results included a gain on the sale of a non-core subsidiary in Chile, the receipt of VAT income in the U.K, a gain on the sale of land in Chile, severance-related charges and the write-down of the goodwill and other intangible assets relating to our operations in India. Adjusting for currency translation and these unusual items in both years, adjusted operating income would've grown by double digits versus last year.
In our Uniform and Career Apparel segment, third quarter sales of $343 million were up 3% from the year ago quarter on both a reported and organic basis. Improving organic growth rates in the uniform rental business, which were in the mid-single digits for the quarter, were offset by softness in our direct sale business, partially reflecting large customer direct sale programs, which were launched in the first half of 2011 that have not been repeated in 2012. And for the 9 months, segment sales of $1 billion were up 1% from the prior year on a reported and organic basis. We continue to invest in additional rental sales personnel resources to support accelerated new sales growth, while maintaining a disciplined approach to contract pricing. We are gaining improved traction in our new sales efforts and continue to gain momentum as the volume of new sales in the third quarter and for the 9 months delivered by our sales force significantly exceeded the prior year results, driven by both higher sales headcount and higher sales rep productivity. The segment's third quarter adjusted operating income was $37 million, which was about even with the same period last year and for the 9 months. Adjusted operating income was $107 million, down from $112 million for the same period last year. As we have discussed in previous quarters, the increased sales costs, including installation costs associated with substantially higher levels of new business and higher merchandise amortization will continue to depress profit growth in the near term. But we, of course, believe these efforts will lead to both improving rental sales and profit growth as we move forward.
Corporate expenses, excluding the items that Karen mentioned earlier, were $9 million in the quarter compared to $7.2 million a year ago. And for the 9 months, expenses were $24.9 million compared to $23.7 million in the prior year.
So at this point, let me turn it back to Karen for some additional details in the quarter and our year-to-date performance.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Fred. I'd like to comment on our financing, capital structure and cash flow. Our adjusted EBITDA for the trailing 12 months ending June 29 was $1.136 billion, which was about equal to the $1.136 billion we reported as of March 30, 2012, and up fro
componenttext:
Thanks, Fred. I'd like to comment on our financing, capital structure and cash flow. Our adjusted EBITDA for the trailing 12 months ending June 29 was $1.136 billion, which was about equal to the $1.136 billion we reported as of March 30, 2012, and up from $1.1 billion at September 30, 2011. Interest and other financing costs were $88 million for the third quarter compared to $113 million in the prior year. Our interest expense in the quarter was lower, primarily as a result of a number of interest rate swaps that matured at the end of March 2012. For the 9 months, interest and other financing costs were $315 million, equal to the prior year's expense.
In the second quarter of 2012, we recorded approximately $11 million of expenses related to the term loan extension we completed that quarter. In 2011, we had interest income of approximately $14 million recorded related to the settlement of U.K. VAT claims from prior periods. Including the impact of interest rate hedges, approximately 50% of our total debt portfolio is at fixed interest rates, and our overall weighted average cost of debt is approximately 5.1%.
Total reported debt at the end of the third quarter was $5.782 billion. Our secured debt, as defined in our credit agreement, totaled $3.953 billion, including a term loan balance of $3.281 billion and a revolver balance of $375 million. In June 2012, we amended our accounts receivable securitization facility, increasing the maximum amount from $250 million to $300 million and extending the maturity date to January 2015. The facility had $253 million utilized at quarter end. During the quarter, our $250 million, 5% notes matured and were repaid with revolver borrowings, which did not increase our total debt. We had approximately $273 million of available capacity under our revolving credit facility as of quarter end. Based on our trailing adjusted EBITDA, our secured debt ratio was 3.41x as of June 29, up modestly from 3.22x as of March 30, 2012, and equal to the 3.41x reported as of July 1, 2011. This slight increase in the ratio from March 30 reflects our utilization of the revolver to fund the 5% note redemption. Overall, we are pleased with our EBITDA growth and our ratio momentum, and we anticipate further ratio improvement over time. Net capital expenditures for the quarter were $74 million compared to $60 million in the prior year quarter. For the year-to-date, net capital expenditures total $219 million compared to $180 million in the same period last year as we focused on making prudent investments in growth opportunities and in our infrastructure.
As expected and consistent with historical patterns, working capital was a use of cash for us during the first 9 months of our fiscal year. We are continuing to maintain our focus on working capital management as we move through the fourth quarter, which is our strongest seasonal period from a working capital and free cash flow standpoint. For the year-to-date, we have spent a total of $151 million on acquisitions compared to $157 million in the prior year period. This year's spending related primarily to the acquisition of Filterfresh within our North American refreshment services business in October of 2011. We continue to evaluate and seek to make strategic investments in certain sectors and geographies, but will be prudent and disciplined in the pursuit of these opportunities.
Now let me turn the call back over to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Karen. So summing up our performance so far this year, our global Food and Support Services business has delivered solid organic growth with strong profit growth. The uniform rental business is gaining traction from the significant investment we h
componenttext:
Thanks, Karen. So summing up our performance so far this year, our global Food and Support Services business has delivered solid organic growth with strong profit growth. The uniform rental business is gaining traction from the significant investment we have made over the past several quarters in accelerating new sales and now is performing at the mid-single-digit growth levels. As we look forward, while we will be working to deliver improving organic growth rates and continued margin improvement, slowing economic growth will clearly pose a challenge to certain sectors and countries. We believe that there are many attractive growth opportunities in front of us despite the economic climate as many of our sectors remain significantly underpenetrated. We remain excited about pursuing these opportunities.
Overall, we continue to benefit from our portfolio of sectors, geographies and clients, which we feel provide us with good balance. We plan to invest appropriately in the pursuit of these many opportunities in the months and years ahead, while still managing our cost structure and cash flow in a very disciplined manner.
Thank you again, for your time this afternoon and for your support of ARAMARK as always. We would now be happy to take questions.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question today will come from Carla Casella with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question today will come from Carla Casella with JPMorgan.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you can talk about the U.K. business and if you have any impact on the Olympic -- of the Olympics. We are hearing that businesses have been encouraging employees to work from home during the Olympics and wondering if this was an impact on
componenttext: I'm wondering if you can talk about the U.K. business and if you have any impact on the Olympic -- of the Olympics. We are hearing that businesses have been encouraging employees to work from home during the Olympics and wondering if this was an impact on you.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Carla, we have really 2 impacts. One is the Olympics themselves, where as you I'm sure know, we are the food service provider to the athletes for the summer games as we have been since 1968 in Mexico City. And then there's a negative impact, which is the
componenttext: Carla, we have really 2 impacts. One is the Olympics themselves, where as you I'm sure know, we are the food service provider to the athletes for the summer games as we have been since 1968 in Mexico City. And then there's a negative impact, which is the one you mentioned. And I think it's fair to say we're feeling both of those. So our base U.K. business is feeling some negative effect from the Olympics. As you know, there was quite a bit of controversy about the traffic and the setup of the special dedicated traffic lanes for VIPs and the like. And our sense is that many people, particularly focused on taking vacation at this time. On the other hand, we will clearly have sales associated with what's proving to be a incredibly successful performance by us in feeding athletes at the Olympic Games. It's not, as you know, really very much in the way of profit for us, but it does -- it create a fair amount of sales, which I'm sure just from a sales point of view would more than offset the weakness in our base U.K. operations.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then on the uniform business, can you talk about how much of that now is rental?
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then on the uniform business, can you talk about how much of that now is rental?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: About 90%, between 85% and 90% of our total sales are rental. And the direct sale is the balance.
componenttext: About 90%, between 85% and 90% of our total sales are rental. And the direct sale is the balance.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then on the commodity cost front, can you just talk about how you expect that to flow through your numbers with the increasing commodities and what changes you can make to offset that?
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then on the commodity cost front, can you just talk about how you expect that to flow through your numbers with the increasing commodities and what changes you can make to offset that?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. Based on our overall market basket, we've seen relatively benign levels of food cost increases so far this year and in the low single-digit range. We haven't seen any major uptick in that right now. We're obviously keeping a close eye on it. I think
componenttext: Sure. Based on our overall market basket, we've seen relatively benign levels of food cost increases so far this year and in the low single-digit range. We haven't seen any major uptick in that right now. We're obviously keeping a close eye on it. I think next year, our forecast is to have price increases more in the 4%, 4.5% range overall of our basket. And as you know, we have tremendous flexibility in our operations to manage against this, since we have pretty much in most of our operations outside of the corrections business, which is relatively small, significant control over the menus, how those menus are -- the items are engineered, the mix of items on the menus. So we're focused on it. I think we'll probably make even a greater, more focused effort as we move into next year in both our retail and our contract pricing. And we'll be on top of it from a mix perspective.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: And next we'll go to Reza Vahabzadeh with Barclays.
componenttext: And next we'll go to Reza Vahabzadeh with Barclays.

componenttextpreview: So as far as spend per capita and traffic in your locations in the North America business, especially the discretionary businesses, I mean, how would you characterize your June quarter performance as you went through the quarter, as well as sequentially f
componenttext: So as far as spend per capita and traffic in your locations in the North America business, especially the discretionary businesses, I mean, how would you characterize your June quarter performance as you went through the quarter, as well as sequentially from your March quarter?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say, it depends on the individual market segment. We continue to see growth in our Higher Education business. Now it's not -- the Higher Education business is not as significant in the June quarter, as I mentioned earlier. So we continue to
componenttext: Well, I would say, it depends on the individual market segment. We continue to see growth in our Higher Education business. Now it's not -- the Higher Education business is not as significant in the June quarter, as I mentioned earlier. So we continue to drive our base business growth there. We have seen in our business locations, clearly, some falloff.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: And the falloff is spend as well as traffic, or one or the other?
componenttext: And the falloff is spend as well as traffic, or one or the other?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think it's more spend than traffic, because the unemployment rate has been -- as you know, it's been pretty constant.
componenttext: I think it's more spend than traffic, because the unemployment rate has been -- as you know, it's been pretty constant.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. One of the challenges is the economy in the North America or U.S. is not generating jobs month by month at the level that it was towards the end of last calendar year. But we're -- I don't think we're being significantly negatively affected by traf
componenttext: Right. One of the challenges is the economy in the North America or U.S. is not generating jobs month by month at the level that it was towards the end of last calendar year. But we're -- I don't think we're being significantly negatively affected by traffic.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. And in the Sports & Entertainment business, that's been also constant or no?
componenttext: Right. And in the Sports & Entertainment business, that's been also constant or no?

componenttextpreview: No, it's been positive, actually.
componenttext: No, it's been positive, actually.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Positive. Okay. And then as far as acquisitions, the last batch of acquisitions from our vantage point seem pretty successful, Filterfresh, and the health care one. Are there more opportunities of that kind do you think in the next 6 to 12 months?
componenttext: Positive. Okay. And then as far as acquisitions, the last batch of acquisitions from our vantage point seem pretty successful, Filterfresh, and the health care one. Are there more opportunities of that kind do you think in the next 6 to 12 months?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think there are always opportunities. We -- we're particularly focused on refreshment services and what we now call Health Care Technologies, the clinical equipment management business, which those 2 acquisitions were to further solidify our lead p
componenttext: Yes, I think there are always opportunities. We -- we're particularly focused on refreshment services and what we now call Health Care Technologies, the clinical equipment management business, which those 2 acquisitions were to further solidify our lead positions in those markets. And we're pleased overall, with those acquisitions and they've certainly put us in the market -- in a strong market position as we had targeted. Outside of that, the opportunities are always around add-on acquisitions in the uniform business. The potential to expand our facilities business around the world and then a couple of countries potentially we'd like to be in that we're not in. So I wouldn't expect the acquisition activity in the next 12 months to be really significant. But there are a couple of things in the pipeline that may come to fruition over the next 9 to 12 months.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. And then how is your non-U.K. European business, especially in say, Germany and Spain?
componenttext: Right. And then how is your non-U.K. European business, especially in say, Germany and Spain?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, say that again?
componenttext: I'm sorry, say that again?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: How's your business in Germany and Spain?
componenttext: How's your business in Germany and Spain?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, our German business is flattened somewhat in the third quarter. So to be fair, I would say that Germany is not as strong as it was earlier in the year. So I take that as our -- what we're seeing to be pretty consistent with what you hear with respec
componenttext: Well, our German business is flattened somewhat in the third quarter. So to be fair, I would say that Germany is not as strong as it was earlier in the year. So I take that as our -- what we're seeing to be pretty consistent with what you hear with respect to the German economy overall. And in Spain, it's a challenge. It's a real challenge. We have a benefit -- we have an advantage and a bit of a disadvantage. The advantage in Spain is we're not really very strong at all in the -- in the B&I market. We're strong in education, particularly K-12, and that's been solid. But we also have a pretty decent sized business in health care, and some portion of that are public health care institutions. And those are typically funded at the state levels. And as you know, may know in Spain, there's quite a bit of back and forth between the states and the federal government with respect to funding. So that's clearly put some pressure on our health care clients. So yes, I'd say in Spain, it's a challenge. Now fortunately for us, Spain is not a huge operation.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. And then lastly, you're happy with your debt maturity profile and your cap structure right now?
componenttext: Right. And then lastly, you're happy with your debt maturity profile and your cap structure right now?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, Reza. We've pushed out the vast majority of our term loan. Sort of our next significant maturity we've got coming up is roughly $650 million of non-extended term loan that would be maturing in January of 2014. So we kind of got a little bit of time h
componenttext: Yes, Reza. We've pushed out the vast majority of our term loan. Sort of our next significant maturity we've got coming up is roughly $650 million of non-extended term loan that would be maturing in January of 2014. So we kind of got a little bit of time here before we need to address that. But generally speaking, we're in good shape.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: And next we'll go to Karru Martinson with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And next we'll go to Karru Martinson with Deutsche Bank.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: In terms of the acquisition part, I thought maybe reverse that. Are there parts of your business that you would look to perhaps exit, or perhaps the growth isn't there or the economic challenges make the opportunities more difficult than you thought?
componenttext: In terms of the acquisition part, I thought maybe reverse that. Are there parts of your business that you would look to perhaps exit, or perhaps the growth isn't there or the economic challenges make the opportunities more difficult than you thought?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think it's difficult to answer that question definitively. Let's start with the U.S. I mean, clearly, our -- we have business that are growing at different growth rates and some have more potential than others. All of our -- we operate in pretty high re
componenttext: I think it's difficult to answer that question definitively. Let's start with the U.S. I mean, clearly, our -- we have business that are growing at different growth rates and some have more potential than others. All of our -- we operate in pretty high return on investment businesses. And so all of our businesses are more than earning their cost of capital. So I think generally, in North America, which is of course, the bulk of our overall sales, particularly if you include uniform. I don't think it's primarily a matter of exiting certain businesses. I think it's more of a matter of internal resource allocation, capital allocation, sales resources and those sorts of things. And I think you'll find us probably be more discriminating in that sense in that regard than we have been. Overall, outside of the U.S. in our base countries, our big countries, even though a couple of them are struggling because of the economy, we see those as long term -- generally, as long-term plays in countries which at least over the intermediate term, we think we can add value, we'd want to stay in. The smaller ones we're always evaluating, but it's really sort of hard to make a specific statement on the smaller ones.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And with those economies that have been struggling or -- is that creating opportunities that you see to enter new markets, perhaps with a longer-term viewpoint?
componenttext: Okay. And with those economies that have been struggling or -- is that creating opportunities that you see to enter new markets, perhaps with a longer-term viewpoint?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: It does. I have to say that we haven't been very aggressive about that. I think in part because we're happy with the business that we have. But given the longer-term uncertainty, I think we'd like to see a few more cards played to see how some of these ec
componenttext: It does. I have to say that we haven't been very aggressive about that. I think in part because we're happy with the business that we have. But given the longer-term uncertainty, I think we'd like to see a few more cards played to see how some of these economies -- where they level out and how they level out before we would be contributing really, investing more capital in those countries, the ones that are struggling.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. And when you talk about the job growth here in the United States, kind of us not really adding to the new jobs and you look at the weakening economic environment, is the view in terms of your planning that, that will change once the election is comp
componenttext: Okay. And when you talk about the job growth here in the United States, kind of us not really adding to the new jobs and you look at the weakening economic environment, is the view in terms of your planning that, that will change once the election is complete or is this more of a longer-term trend that you're seeing here?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, it's hard to tell. I mean, we can all speculate. Let me put it this way, we're -- our current thinking is that there is no reason to believe that 2013 is going to be substantially different from where we sit today. And could it be a little weaker? M
componenttext: Well, it's hard to tell. I mean, we can all speculate. Let me put it this way, we're -- our current thinking is that there is no reason to believe that 2013 is going to be substantially different from where we sit today. And could it be a little weaker? My guess is the chances are -- chances of it being a little weaker and a little stronger are probably higher. So we're -- as we start to think forward to October, which is the beginning of our next fiscal year, I mean, I can tell you we're not intrinsically counting on some pickup on the overall economy. And so we're planning in accordance with that.
