headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon and welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to the ARAMARK Corporation Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded for rebroadcast and that all participants are in a li
componenttext: Good afternoon and welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to the ARAMARK Corporation Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded for rebroadcast and that all participants are in a listen-only mode. At the request of the company, we will open the conference up for questions after the presentation. I will now turn the call over to Karen Wallace, Vice President and Treasurer. Please go ahead, Karen.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you and welcome to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our operations for the third quarter of fiscal 2012. Here with me today is Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fred and I will p
componenttext:
Thank you and welcome to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our operations for the third quarter of fiscal 2012. Here with me today is Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fred and I will present an overview of our third quarter and year-to-date results and business operations, after which, there will be an opportunity for phone-in participants to ask questions.
I would like to remind you that any recording or other use or transmission of this audio may not be done without the prior written consent of ARAMARK. As we discuss the results, you may want to refer to the Form 10-Q we filed earlier today, which contains our third quarter results for fiscal 2012. This Form 10-Q can be found on our website at www.aramark.com.
In today's discussion of results, we mention certain non-GAAP financial measures. The Form 10-Q, as well as schedules we posted to our website prior to this call, include reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most comparable GAAP measures as required by SEC rules. Our discussion of operating income during today's call will in each instance, exclude the incremental intangibles amortization and property and equipment depreciation expense resulting from the going private transaction, the impact of stock option expense and the impact on the change in fair value related to our gasoline and diesel fuel agreements. All of these items are detailed in the schedules posted to our website before this call. In addition, the prior year period results have been restated to present the results of the Galls business as a discontinued operation, as we sold it in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011.
Various remarks that we make in this call relating to matters that are not historical facts, including remarks about future expectations, anticipation, belief, estimates, plans and prospects, constitute forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from those expressed or implied as a result of various risks, uncertainties and important factors, including those discussed in the Risk Factors, MD&A and other sections of our Form 10-K and the Form 10-Q filed earlier today. We disclaim any duty to update or revise such forward-looking statements, whether as a result of future events or otherwise.
I will now turn the program over to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everybody and thanks for joining us for our third quarter 2012 results call. As we've done in prior quarters, I'd like to review our business and operating results, and then Karen will cover a few additional details on our performance focu
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everybody and thanks for joining us for our third quarter 2012 results call. As we've done in prior quarters, I'd like to review our business and operating results, and then Karen will cover a few additional details on our performance focused on cash flow and the balance sheet.
During the quarter, we saw significant slowing in U.S. job growth and continued economic uncertainty in Europe. Our organic growth rate declined slightly in part due to the normal seasonal mix shift between our higher growing Education business and our slower growing business in Sports & Entertainment sectors. We continue to see positive growth trends in certain of our sectors as a result of contributions from both base business and new business wins. Year-to-date, our new customer sales are growing in the double digits and net new business results are also quite strong. Our client retention rates have been consistent with our expectations and better than prior year's results. But with the economic environment weakening as the year progresses, we remain cautious and continue to maintain a very tight focus on efficiently managing our operations and our cost structure.
So now turning to our overall results for the third quarter, we achieved sales of $3.3 billion, which was up 2% as reported from the prior year quarter. Organic sales growth, which I mentioned earlier, and excludes the impact of currency translations and acquisitions and divestitures, was up 3% in the quarter. Adjusted operating income was $157 million, up 2% versus the prior year. For the first 9 months of fiscal 2012, sales were $10.1 billion, up 3% over the prior year period on both a reported and an organic growth basis. Our adjusted operating income of $544 million was up 4% from the prior year.
Now turning to our North America Food and Support Services segment, third quarter reported sales were up 3% to $2.3 billion, led primarily by growth in the Higher Education business and Business & Industry and Sports & Entertainment sectors. Organic sales growth was 3% in the quarter. For the 9 months, reported sales were up 5% to $7.1 billion on organic growth of 3%. Year-to-date performance was also led by solid growth in most sectors and particularly strong growth in Higher Education.
Turning now to the sectors within North America, our Business & Industry sector had a mid-single digit sales increase for the quarter and a high single-digit sales increase for the 9 months. This reflects the positive impact from the Filterfresh acquisition, which closed on 2011, October of 2011. Our B&I facilities business also contributed to the increase in the quarter with our remote services growth primarily in Canada, and our business dining operations during the year were pretty much flat year-over-year.
The Education sector had low single-digit sales growth for the quarter and mid-single-digit sales growth for the 9 months, with growth in our Higher Education food business resulting from a good combination of base business growth and strong new sales from contract wins in prior periods.
In our Healthcare sector, we saw a slight decline in the quarter and mid-single-digit sales growth for the 9 months. The sales decline in the quarter was a result of modest base business growth that was offset by lower net new business. The growth for the 9-month period was primarily a result of the acquisition in March 2011 of Masterplan within our Healthcare Technologies business.
Our Sports & Entertainment sector had low single-digit sales growth for the quarter and for the 9 months. But for the quarter, we've seen pretty solid performance in our Major League Baseball venues, with growth in both the tenants and per capita spending and good growth in our amphitheater business, with a significant increase in the number of shows and attendance growth. Our growth for the 9-month period was negatively affected by the NBA strike in our first quarter, but that was offset more or less by solid results during the NHL season and recent strength in MLB performance as I mentioned. Adjusted operating income in the North American Food and Support Services segment increased by 5% in the quarter to $103 million, led by profit growth in our Higher Education business. For the 9 months, segment adjusted operating income grew 5% to $388 million, again led by strong profit growth in Higher Education business and the Healthcare sector, offset by profit decline in our Business & Industry sector. Our results for the 9 months were reduced by approximately $4 million of planned acquisition-related transition and integration cost absorbed in the first quarter, as well as the recognition as we mentioned last year -- during last year of approximately $8 million of income related to a compensation agreement signed with the National Park Service under which they paid down a portion of our possessed reinterest in one of our concession contracts. Without these 2 particular items, year-over-year profit growth for the 9 months would have been in the high single digits.
Now turning to the International Food and Support Services segment, third quarter reported sales of $674 million were down 3% from the prior year period, primarily due to the strengthening of the U.S. dollar. Organic sales growth for the quarter was actually 4% due to positive growth in Ireland, South America and China, that was partially offset by sales declines in the U.K. and Spain. For the 9 months, reported sales of $2 billion decreased 1% compared to the prior year, also primarily due to the stronger dollar. Organic growth was 4%, again led primarily by growth in Germany, Ireland, South America and China, which more than offset a sales decline in the U.K. and Belgium.
Third quarter adjusted operating income was $25 million, which was about even when compared to the prior year quarter. But currency translation negatively affected profit growth by approximately 8 percentage points. Results in the quarter primarily reflect improving profit performance in the U.K, Ireland and Chile, offsetting a profit decline in continental Europe. For the 9 months, adjusted operating income was $74 million, up from $64 million in the prior year. Growth was driven by the U.K, Ireland, Germany, Spain, Chile and China, partially offset by Belgium and by our AIM joint venture in Japan. Currency translation also negatively affected profit growth by approximately 3 percentage points.
You may recall, there are a number of unusual items last year and a couple this year in the International segment. In 2012, we recorded severance-related charges and VAT income in the U.K. and in 2011, the results included a gain on the sale of a non-core subsidiary in Chile, the receipt of VAT income in the U.K, a gain on the sale of land in Chile, severance-related charges and the write-down of the goodwill and other intangible assets relating to our operations in India. Adjusting for currency translation and these unusual items in both years, adjusted operating income would've grown by double digits versus last year.
In our Uniform and Career Apparel segment, third quarter sales of $343 million were up 3% from the year ago quarter on both a reported and organic basis. Improving organic growth rates in the uniform rental business, which were in the mid-single digits for the quarter, were offset by softness in our direct sale business, partially reflecting large customer direct sale programs, which were launched in the first half of 2011 that have not been repeated in 2012. And for the 9 months, segment sales of $1 billion were up 1% from the prior year on a reported and organic basis. We continue to invest in additional rental sales personnel resources to support accelerated new sales growth, while maintaining a disciplined approach to contract pricing. We are gaining improved traction in our new sales efforts and continue to gain momentum as the volume of new sales in the third quarter and for the 9 months delivered by our sales force significantly exceeded the prior year results, driven by both higher sales headcount and higher sales rep productivity. The segment's third quarter adjusted operating income was $37 million, which was about even with the same period last year and for the 9 months. Adjusted operating income was $107 million, down from $112 million for the same period last year. As we have discussed in previous quarters, the increased sales costs, including installation costs associated with substantially higher levels of new business and higher merchandise amortization will continue to press profit growth in the near term. But we, of course, believe these efforts will lead to both improving rental sales and profit growth as we move forward.
Corporate expenses, excluding the items that Karen mentioned earlier, were $9 million in the quarter compared to $7.2 million a year ago. And for the 9 months, expenses were $24.9 million compared to $23.7 million in the prior year.
So at this point, let me turn it back to Karen for some additional details in the quarter and our year-to-date performance.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Fred. I'd like to comment on our financing, capital structure and cash flow. Our adjusted EBITDA for the trailing 12-months ending June 29 was $1.136 billion, which was about equal to the $1.136 billion we reported as of March 30, 2012, and up fro
componenttext:
Thanks, Fred. I'd like to comment on our financing, capital structure and cash flow. Our adjusted EBITDA for the trailing 12-months ending June 29 was $1.136 billion, which was about equal to the $1.136 billion we reported as of March 30, 2012, and up from $1.1 billion at September 30, 2011. Interest and other financing costs were $88 million for the third quarter compared to $113 million in the prior year. Our interest expense in the quarter was lower, primarily as a result of a number of interest rate swaps that matured at the end of March 2012. For the 9 months, interest and other financing costs were $315 million, equal to the prior year's expense.
In the second quarter of 2012, we recorded approximately $11 million of expenses related to the term loan extension we completed that quarter. In 2011, we had interest income of approximately $14 million recorded related to the settlement of U.K. VAT claims from prior periods. Including the impact of interest rate hedges, approximately 50% of our total debt portfolio is at fixed interest rates, and our overall weighted average cost of debt is approximately 5.1%.
Total reported debt at the end of the third quarter was $5.782 billion. Our secured debt, as defined in our credit agreement, totaled $3.953 billion, including a term loan balance of $3.281 billion and a revolver balance of $375 million. In June 2012, we amended our accounts receivable securitization facility, increasing the maximum amount from $250 million to $300 million and extending the maturity date to January 2015. The facility had $253 million utilized at quarter end. During the quarter, our $250 million, 5% note matured and were repaid with revolver borrowings, which did not increase our total debt. We had approximately $273 million of available capacity under our revolving credit facility as of quarter end. Based on our trailing adjusted EBITDA, our secured debt ratio was 3.41x as of June 29, up modestly from 3.22x as of March 30, 2012, and equal to the 3.41x reported as of July 1, 2011. This slight increase in the ratio from March 30 reflects our utilization of the revolver to fund the 5% note redemption. Overall, we are pleased with our EBITDA growth and our ratio momentum, and we anticipate further ratio improvement over time. Net capital expenditures for the quarter were $74 million compared to $60 million in the prior year quarter. For the year-to-date, net capital expenditures total $219 million compared to $180 million in the same period last year as we focused on making prudent investments in growth opportunities and in our infrastructure.
As expected and consistent with historical patterns, working capital was a use of cash for us during the first 9 months of our fiscal year. We are continuing to maintain a focus on working capital management as we move through the fourth quarter, which is our strongest seasonal period from a working capital and free cash flow standpoint. For the year-to-date, we have spent a total of $151 million on acquisitions compared to $157 million in the prior year period. This year's spending related primarily to the acquisition of Filterfresh within our North American refreshment services business in October of 2011. We continue to evaluate and seek to make strategic investments in certain sectors and geographies, but will be prudent and disciplined in the pursuit of these opportunities.
Now let me turn the call back over to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Karen. So summing up our performance so far this year, our global Food and Support Services business has delivered solid organic growth with strong profit growth. The uniform rental business is gaining traction from the significant investment we h
componenttext:
Thanks, Karen. So summing up our performance so far this year, our global Food and Support Services business has delivered solid organic growth with strong profit growth. The uniform rental business is gaining traction from the significant investment we have made over the past several quarters in accelerating new sales and now is performing at the mid-single-digit growth levels. As we look forward, while we will be working to deliver improving organic growth rates and continued margin improvement, slowing economic growth will clearly pose a challenge to certain sectors and countries. We believe that there are many attractive growth opportunities in front of us despite the economic climate as many of our sectors remain significantly underpenetrated. We remain excited about pursuing these opportunities.
Overall, we continue to benefit from our portfolio of sectors, geographies and clients, which we feel provide us with good balance. We plan to invest appropriately in the pursuit of these many opportunities in the months and years ahead, while still managing our cost structure and cash flow in a very disciplined manner.
Thank you again for your time this afternoon and for your support of ARAMARK as always. We would now be happy to take questions.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question today will come from Carla Casella with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question today will come from Carla Casella with JPMorgan.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you can talk about the U.K. business and if you have any impact on the Olympic -- of the Olympics. We are hearing that businesses have been encouraging employees to work from home during the Olympics and wondering if this was an impact on
componenttext: I'm wondering if you can talk about the U.K. business and if you have any impact on the Olympic -- of the Olympics. We are hearing that businesses have been encouraging employees to work from home during the Olympics and wondering if this was an impact on you.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Carla, we have really 2 impacts. One is the Olympics themselves, where as you I'm sure know, we are the food service provider to the athletes for the summer games, as we have been since 1968 in Mexico City. And then there's the negative impact, which is t
componenttext: Carla, we have really 2 impacts. One is the Olympics themselves, where as you I'm sure know, we are the food service provider to the athletes for the summer games, as we have been since 1968 in Mexico City. And then there's the negative impact, which is the one you mentioned. And I think it's fair to say we're feeling both of those. So our base U.K. business is feeling some negative effect from the Olympics. As you know, there was quite a bit of controversy about the traffic and the setup of the special dedicated traffic lanes for VIPs and the like. And our sense is that many people, particularly focused on taking vacation at this time. On the other hand, we will clearly have sales associated with what's proving to be an incredibly successful performance by us in feeding the athletes at the Olympic Games. It's not, as you know, really very much in the way of profit for us, but it does -- it create a fair amount of sales, which I'm sure just from a sales point of view would more than offset the weakness in our base U.K. operations.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then on the uniform business, can you talk about how much of that now is rental?
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then on the uniform business, can you talk about how much of that now is rental?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: About 90%, between 85% and 90% of our total sales are rental. And the direct sale is the balance.
componenttext: About 90%, between 85% and 90% of our total sales are rental. And the direct sale is the balance.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then on the commodity cost front, can you just talk about how you expect that to flow through your numbers with the increasing commodities and what changes you can make to offset that?
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then on the commodity cost front, can you just talk about how you expect that to flow through your numbers with the increasing commodities and what changes you can make to offset that?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. Based on our overall market basket, we've seen relatively benign levels of food cost increases so far this year and in the low single-digit range. We haven't seen any major uptick in that right now. We're obviously keeping a close eye on it. I think
componenttext: Sure. Based on our overall market basket, we've seen relatively benign levels of food cost increases so far this year and in the low single-digit range. We haven't seen any major uptick in that right now. We're obviously keeping a close eye on it. I think next year, our forecast is to have price increases more in the 4%, 4.5% range overall of our basket. And as you know, we have tremendous flexibility in our operations to manage against this, since we have pretty much in most of our operations outside of the corrections business, which is relatively small, significant control over the menus, how those menus are -- the items are engineered, the mix of items on the menus. So we're focused on it. I think we'll probably make even a greater, more focused effort as we move into next year in both our retail and our contract pricing. And we'll be on top of it from a mix perspective.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012

componenttext: And next we'll go to Reza Vahabzadeh with Barclays.

componenttext: So as far as spend per capita and traffic in your locations in the North America business, especially the discretionary businesses, I mean, how would you characterize your June quarter performance as you went through the quarter, as well as sequentially from your March quarter?

componenttext: Well, I would say, it depends on the individual market segment. We continue to see growth in our Higher Education business. Now it's not -- the Higher Education business is not as significant in the June quarter, as I mentioned earlier. So we continue to drive our base business growth there. We have seen in our business locations, clearly, some falloff.

componenttext: Right. One of the challenges is the economy in North America or U.S. is not generating jobs month by month at the level that it was towards the end of last calendar year. But we're -- I don't think we're being significantly negatively affected by traffic.

componenttextpreview: Positive. Okay. And then as far as acquisitions, the last batch of acquisitions from our vantage point seem pretty successful, Filterfresh, and the health care one. Are there more opportunities of that kind do you think in the next 6 to 12 months?
componenttext: Positive. Okay. And then as far as acquisitions, the last batch of acquisitions from our vantage point seem pretty successful, Filterfresh, and the health care one. Are there more opportunities of that kind do you think in the next 6 to 12 months?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think there are always opportunities. We -- we're particularly focused on refreshment services and what we now call Health Care Technologies, the clinical equipment management business, which those 2 acquisitions were to further solidify our lead p
componenttext: Yes, I think there are always opportunities. We -- we're particularly focused on refreshment services and what we now call Health Care Technologies, the clinical equipment management business, which those 2 acquisitions were to further solidify our lead positions in those markets. And we're pleased overall, with those acquisitions and they've certainly put us in the market -- in a strong market position as we had targeted. Outside of that, the opportunities are always around add-on acquisitions in the uniform business. The potential to expand our facilities business around the world and then a couple of countries potentially we'd like to be in that we're not in. So I wouldn't expect the acquisition activity in the next 12 months to be really significant. But there are a couple of things in the pipeline that may come to fruition over the next 9 to 12 months.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012

componenttext: Right. And then how is your non-U.K. European business, especially in say, Germany and Spain?

componenttext: I'm sorry, say that again?

componenttext: How's your business in Germany and Spain?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, our German business is flattened somewhat in the third quarter. So to be fair, I would say that Germany is not as strong as it was earlier in the year. So I take that as our -- what we're seeing to be pretty consistent with what you hear with respec
componenttext: Well, our German business is flattened somewhat in the third quarter. So to be fair, I would say that Germany is not as strong as it was earlier in the year. So I take that as our -- what we're seeing to be pretty consistent with what you hear with respect to the German economy overall. And in Spain, it's a challenge. It's a real challenge. We have a benefit -- we have an advantage and a bit of a disadvantage. The advantage in Spain is we're not really very strong at all in the -- in the B&I market. We're strong in education, particularly K-12, and that's been solid. But we also have a pretty decent size business in health care, and some portion of that are public health care institutions. And those are typically funded at the state levels. And as you know, may know in Spain, there's quite a bit of back and forth between the states and the federal government with respect to funding. So that's clearly put some pressure on our health care clients. So yes, I'd say in Spain, it's a challenge. Now fortunately for us, Spain is not a huge operation.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012

componenttext: Right. And then lastly, you're happy with your debt maturity profile and your cap structure right now?

componenttext: Yes, Reza. We've pushed out the vast majority of our term loan. Sort of our next significant maturity we've got coming up is roughly $650 million of non-extended term loan that would be maturing in January of 2014. So we kind of got a little bit of time here before we need to address that. But generally speaking, we're in good shape.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: In terms of the acquisition part[ph] , I thought maybe reverse that. Are there parts of your business that you would look to perhaps exit, or perhaps the growth isn't there or the economic challenges make the opportunities more difficult than you thought?
componenttext: In terms of the acquisition part[ph] , I thought maybe reverse that. Are there parts of your business that you would look to perhaps exit, or perhaps the growth isn't there or the economic challenges make the opportunities more difficult than you thought?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think it's difficult to answer that question definitively. Let's start with the U.S. I mean, clearly, our -- we have businesses that are growing at different growth rates and some have more potential than others. All of our -- we operate in pretty high
componenttext: I think it's difficult to answer that question definitively. Let's start with the U.S. I mean, clearly, our -- we have businesses that are growing at different growth rates and some have more potential than others. All of our -- we operate in pretty high return on investment businesses. And so all of our businesses are more than earning their cost of capital. So I think generally, in North America, which is of course, the bulk of our overall sales, particularly if you include uniform. I don't think it's primarily a matter of exiting certain businesses. I think it's more of a matter of internal resource allocation, capital allocation, sales resources and those sorts of things. And I think you'll find us probably be more discriminating in that sense -- in that regard than we have been. Overall, outside of the U.S. in our base countries, our big countries, even though a couple of them are struggling because of the economy, we see those as long term -- generally, as long-term plays in countries which at least over the intermediate term, we think we can add value, we'd want to stay in. The smaller ones we're always evaluating, but it's really sort of hard to make a specific statement on the smaller ones.

And when you talk about the job growth here in the United States, kind of us not really adding to the new jobs and you look at the weakening economic environment, is the view in terms of your planning that, that will change once the election is complete or is this more of a longer-term trend that you're seeing here?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q3 2012 Earnings Call, Aug 09, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, it's hard to tell. I mean, we can all speculate. Let me put it this way, we're -- our current thinking is that there is no reason to believe that 2013 is going to be substantially different from where we sit today. And could it be a little weaker? M
componenttext: Well, it's hard to tell. I mean, we can all speculate. Let me put it this way, we're -- our current thinking is that there is no reason to believe that 2013 is going to be substantially different from where we sit today. And could it be a little weaker? My guess is the chances are -- chances of it being a little weaker rather than a little stronger are probably higher. So we're -- as we start to think forward to October, which is the beginning of our next fiscal year, I mean, I can tell you we're not intrinsically counting on some pickup on the overall economy. And so we're planning in accordance with that.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Pleased stand by, we're about to begin. Good afternoon and welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to the ARAMARK Corporation Fourth Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded for rebroadc
componenttext: Pleased stand by, we're about to begin. Good afternoon and welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to the ARAMARK Corporation Fourth Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded for rebroadcast and that all participants are in a listen-only mode. At the request of the company, we will open the conference up for questions after the presentation. I will now turn the call over to Karen Wallace, Vice President and Treasurer.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Daniel, and welcome, everyone to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our operations for the fourth quarter and full year fiscal 2012. Here with me today is Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financia
componenttext:
Thanks, Daniel, and welcome, everyone to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our operations for the fourth quarter and full year fiscal 2012. Here with me today is Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fred and I will present an overview of our fourth quarter and full-year results and business operations. After which, there will be an opportunity for phone-in participants to ask questions.
I wouldI'd like to remind you that any recording or other use or transmission of this audio may not be done without the prior written consent of ARAMARK. As we discuss the results, you may want to refer to the Form 8-K we filed earlier today, which contains our fourth quarter and full year results for fiscal 2012. This Form 8-K can be found on our website at www.aramark.com.
In today's discussion of results, we mention certain non-GAAP financial measures. The Form 10-Q, as well as schedules we posted to our website prior to the call, include reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most comparable GAAP measures as required by SEC rules. Our discussion of operating income during today's call will, in each instance, exclude the incremental intangibles amortization and property and equipment depreciation expense resulting from the going private transaction, the impact of stock option expense and the impact on the changing. The ability to our gasoline and diesel fuel agreements. All of these items are detailed in the schedules posted to our website before this call. In addition the prior year period results have been restated to present the results of the galls business as a discontinued operation as we sold it in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011.
Various remarks that we may make in this call relating to matters that are not historical facts, including remarks about future expectations, anticipation, beliefs, estimates, plans and prospects, constitute forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from those expressed or implied as a result of various risks, uncertainties and important factors, including those discussed in the Risk Factors, MD&A and other sections of our Form 10-K and the Form 10-Q filed earlier today. We disclaim any duty to update or revise such forward-looking statements, whether as a result of future events or otherwise.
I will now turn the program over to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everybody and thanks for joining us as we review our fiscal 2012 fourth quarter and our full-year results. As in prior quarters, I'd like to review our business and operating results and then ask Karen to cover a few additional details on
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everybody and thanks for joining us as we review our fiscal 2012 fourth quarter and our full-year results. As in prior quarters, I'd like to review our business and operating results and then ask Karen to cover a few additional details on our performance. Overall, our results for fiscal 2012 were in line with the economic conditions in the countries in which we operate. Our operations in China and South America are continuing to grow at significantly higher rates than our total portfolio of businesses. And we're excited about the opportunities that lie ahead for these regions. As you would expect, Continental Europe results were more mixed as our operations in Spain and Belgium struggled, while Germany continued to deliver solid performance. Our U.K. and Ireland operations realize the benefit of substantial cost reduction efforts in prior years. In North America, our Higher Education business continues to lead our overall growth.
2012 was a record year for us in terms of new sales across our food facilities and uniform businesses. With the new sales contracted our installed up over 30% over the prior year, providing us with a strong carrying rate of business for 2013. If you see -- SEC in the financial statement released earlier today, our free cash flow for the year was also very strong led by our continued emphasis on working capital and earnings growth for the year.
One of our proudest accomplish this year was our success -- is the exclusive catering provider to more than 15,000 athletes, officials and staff in the Athletes' Village over the duration of duration of the Olympic and Paralympic Games in London this summer. During the games, our staff of over 3,500 underground in London served over 1.5 million meals peaking at 65,000 meals per day. London was ARAMARK's 16 Olympic Games.
We were also proud to have posted delegates and other attendees at the Republican national convention in Tampa Bay September, serving nearly 15,000 meals over the span of 5 days. And earlier in the summer, we served baseball fans attending the major league baseball All-Star game in Kansas City. We deeply appreciate the trust our clients place in us to serve at these very important events.
Now turning to the details of our results for the year, I'd like to first take you through our overall financial performance and then I'll discuss our business. We reported fiscal 2012 fourth quarter sales of $3.4 billion, up 3% from the prior-year quarter. Organic sales growth, which as you know, excludes the impact of currency translation and acquisitions and divestitures was 4% in the quarter. Adjusted operating income 2012 was $206 million, up 5% versus the prior fourth year. For the full fiscal year 2012, sales were $13.5 billion, up 3% over the prior period on a reported basis and 4% on an organic growth basis. Our adjusted operating income of $750 million was up 4% the prior year.
Now turning to our North America Food and Support Services segment, fourth quarter reported sales were up 3% to $2.4 billion led primarily by growth in the Higher Education business and our Business & Industry sector. Organic sales growth was 3% in the quarter. For the full-year 2012, reported sales were up 4% to $9.4 billion with organic growth of 3%. Year-to-date performance was led by solid growth in all sectors and particularly, strong growth in our Higher Education sector. Now taking a closer look at the sectors within North America, our Business & Industry sector has a high single-digit sales increase for the quarter and for the full-year, reflecting the positive impact sectors from the Filterfresh acquisition, which, as you may recall, close in early October of 2011. So the very beginning of the business of business of fiscal year 2012.
Growth in the quarter was port about improved base business growth in our Refreshment Services business, while our B&I facilities business also contributed to the increase at both the quarter and for the full year, primarily due to strong growth in our remote services operations in Canada. Our business operations dining divisions experienced a slight sales declined 2012 versus the prior year for both the quarter and the full fiscal year. Our by the Education sector had low single-digit sales growth for the quarter and mid-single-digit sales growth of the fiscal year, primarily driven by higher growth in average in our higher education food business, resulting from a combination of these business growth and very solid new sales from contract wins in prior periods.
In our Healthcare sector, we experienced low single-digit sales growth in the quarter and for the full year. The sales growth in the quarter was a result of base business within our health care technologies business, as well as new business with that health care hospitality. The growth of the full-year fiscal 2012 was primarily a result of base business growth and the acquisition and March of 2011 of Masterplan within our health care technologies business.
Powersports and Entertainment Center had a low single-digit sales increase in the quarter and for the full year. For the quarter, we reported growth in our amphitheater business, somewhat offset by timing of Major League Baseball gains in the early effects of the NHL lockout, which the defect September. Our growth for fiscal 2012 was negatively affected by the NBA strike earlier in the year but that impact was offset by solid results during the NHL season last year and the strength of Major League Baseball.
Adjusted operating income in the North America Food and Support Services segment increased by 7% in the quarter to $153 million, led by profit growth in our Business & Industry and sports event payment sectors. Profit for the fourth quarter included recognition of approximately $7 million of income related to a compensation agreement with the National Park Service, bridge they paid down a portion of our interest at one of our terminated life locations.
For fiscal 2012, segment adjusted operating income grew 5% to $541 million, led by strong profit growth in our Higher Education business and the Healthcare sector. Results for fiscal 2011 included the recognition of approximately $8 million of income in the first quarter, also related similarly to a compensation agreement signed with the National Park Service, under which they paid down a portion of our recessionary inter- support of our concession contracts.
Turning to the international Food and Support Services segment, fourth quarter reported sales of $699 million were up 3% on a reported basis and 11% on an organic basis. Sales growth in the quarter was due to positive growth in Ireland, South America and China, as well as the sales impact from our role as exclusive food service provider in the Athletes' Village  for the London Olympics games. This growth was partially offset by sales declines in the U.K.-based business and Spain. But fiscal year 2012, our reported sales of $2.7 million reflect compared to the prior year on a reported basis primarily due to the impact a the stronger dollar.
Organic growth was 6%, again led primarily by the Olympic Games but also due to growth in Germany, Ireland, South America and China, which more than offset the sales decline in the U.K.-based business in Spain and in Belgium.
Fourth quarter adjusted operating income was $27 million, which was down about 3% when compared to the prior-year quarter, with currency translation negatively affecting profit growth by approximately 4 percentage points. Results in the quarter primarily reflects improving profit performance in the U.K. and in Ireland, of which I think is particularly admirable in a very difficult economic environment, which was offset by a profit decline in Continental Europe.
For the first -- for the full fiscal year 2012, adjusted operating income was $100 million, up from $91 million in the prior year. Growth was driven by the U.K., Ireland, Germany, Chili in China and partially offset by Belgium and our AIF joint venture in Japan. Currency translation also negatively affected profit growth by about 4 percentage points.
 
In our Uniform and Career Apparel segment, fourth quarter sales of $342 million were up 3% from the year-ago quarter on both a reported and an organic basis. Improving organic growth rates in the uniform rental business, which in the fourth quarter were in the mid-single digits, were offset by softness in our direct sale business. For the fiscal year 2012, segment sales of $1.4 billion were up 2% from the prior year on both a reported and organic basis. We're continuing to invest in additional rental sales personnel resources to support accelerated new sales growth. We're gaining improved traction in our new sales efforts as where accounts continue to grow. Our new business installed in 2012 was up over 20% for the full year as a result of both a larger sales force and increased sales productivity. And of course, we're paying the price that the bids on both our sales expense and our merchandise amortization.
The segments fourth quarter adjusted operating income was $38 million. This compares to fourth quarter 2011 adjusted operating income of $34 million. Results from 2011 included restructuring expenses following our divestiture of our call subsidiary in September of 2011. Excluding these costs from the prior year, adjusted operating income in the fourth quarter of 2012 would've been up invincible digits, which is an improvement from recent quarters. For the full fiscal year, adjusted operating income was $145 million, down slightly from the $146 million in the prior year. And as I mentioned, increased sales cost of the expansion of the sales force and a significant increase in our merchandise amortization cost associated with substantially higher levels of new business have had a negative impact on profit growth in the year. But we firmly believe that over the intermediate term, these efforts are leading to both improving rental sales and profit growth as we look further into 2013.
Corporate expenses, which excludes the items Karen mentioned earlier were $11.5 million in the quarter compared to $8.5 million a rental. And for the fiscal year 2012, expenses were $36.4 million compared to $32.2 million in the prior year. Now let me turn it back over to Karen from some additional details in the quarter and the fiscal year.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Fred. Like to comment on our financing, capital structure and cash flow. Our adjusted EBITDA for the trailing 12 months ending September 28 was $1.136 billion, equal to the figure we reported as of June 29, 2012, and up from the $1.1 billion as of
componenttext:
Thanks, Fred. Like to comment on our financing, capital structure and cash flow. Our adjusted EBITDA for the trailing 12 months ending September 28 was $1.136 billion, equal to the figure we reported as of June 29, 2012, and up from the $1.1 billion as of September 30, 2011. Interest and other financial costs were $87 million from the fourth quarter compared to $111 million in the prior year. Our interest expense in the quarter was lower financing primarily as a result of the number of interest rate swaps swaps that matured at the end of March 2012. For the fiscal year 2012, interest and other financing costs were $402 million, down from the prior year's expense of $426 million. In the second quarter of 2012, we reported approximately $11 million of expenses related to the term loan extension we  during the quarter. In 2011, we had interest income of approximately $14 million recorded that was related to the settlement of U.K. VAT claims from prior periods. Including the impact of interest rate hedges, approximately 50% of our total debt portfolio is at fixed interest rates in our overall weighted average cost of that is approximately 5.1%.
Total reported debt at the end of fiscal year 2012 was $5.413 billion. Our secured debt, as defined in our credit agreement, totaled $3.602 billion, including a term loan balance of $3.29 billion and a revolver balance that was 0. In June 2012, we amended our accounts receivable securitization facility, increasing the maximum amount from $250 million to $300 million and extended the maturity date to January of 2015. That facility had $264 million utilized at year-end. We also had approximately $649 million of available capacity under our revolving credit facility as of year-end.
Based on our trailing adjusted EBITDA, our secured debt ratio was 3.11 ask as of September 28, which is down from the 3.41x group reported as of June 29, 2012, and that 3.17x we reported that the end of September 30, 2011.
During 2012, we utilized $250 million of free cash flow to fund the repayment of our 5% notes. And without this maturity, we would've utilized free cash flow to pay down secured debt, and we would've seen a more substantial improvement in our secured debt ratio, consistent with our strong cash flow performance of the year. Our ratio of total debt to adjusted EBITDA the end of fiscal 2012 was 4.76x, and this compares to 5.09x at the end of the third quarter and 5.13x as of the end of fiscal 2011.
Overall, we're pleased with our EBITDA growth and our ratio momentum, and we anticipate for the Rachel improvement over time.
Net capital expenditures for the quarter were $124 million compared to $92 million in the prior-year quarter. For the fiscal year, net capital expenditures totaled $343 million compared to $272 million in the same period last year. This higher level of spending reflects planned investment in our infrastructure, as well as our sales growth objectives.
Consistent with our historical patterns, working capital was a source of cash restaurant the fourth quarter. Individual good working capital as a relatively moderate stores of cash over and over the years. We would anticipate that we will potentially more typical pattern in fiscal 2013, with working capital requiring a modest bump level of investments.
For the year, we're very pleased with our free cash flow performance before acquisitions and divestitures. As we generated approximately $403 million of free cash flow in fiscal 2012, a total debt exceeded our plan and reflects our growth in operating income and continued strong focus on working capital this plan.
For the fiscal year, we spent a total of $152 million on acquisitions compared to $167 million in the prior year period. This year's spending related primarily to the acquisition of Filterfresh and our North American Refreshment Services business, which closed in October of 2011. We continue to evaluate in seek to make strategic investments in certain sectors and geographies but we plan to be prudent and disciplined in the pursuit of these opportunities. Now let me turn the call back over to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Karen. So summing up our performance for this fiscal year, our global Food and Support Services business has delivered solid organic growth, with slightly stronger profit growth. Our uniform rental business is gaining traction from a significant i
componenttext: Thanks, Karen. So summing up our performance for this fiscal year, our global Food and Support Services business has delivered solid organic growth, with slightly stronger profit growth. Our uniform rental business is gaining traction from a significant investments we've made of the past several quarters and accelerating their sales. As we look forward, we have strength that the need to leverage. We have strong positions and attractive sectors, great people with the pride and passion, strong valleys and desire to do the right thing and a focus on client service. We believe there are many attractive growth opportunities in front of us despite economic client decline -- economic climate as many of our factors remain significantly underpenetrated. Remain excited about pursuing those opportunities. We need to create growth really positions as we start to become the most valued part to our plant and consumers. And on the cost side, we see additional opportunities to prove our performance. In late 2011, we initiatives aimed at delivering or improved organic growth and continued margin improvement in the company in the coming years. These activities have already delivered benefit for 2012, but we are committed to continue to improve our standards processes and systems, bringing efficiency and improve effectiveness to how we serve our clients a customer 70 around the world. During 2013, we're planning to further accelerate this process standardization, which we believe will help us not ongoing margin improvement. So thank you again for your time this afternoon and for your support of ARAMARK. And I'll now happy to take your questions.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay and pivoting to just -- looking at your mix part-time versus full-time employees with election behind us and some implementation of the Affordable Care Act, can you give us any insight into your discussions about any -- how you would plan to
componenttext: Got it. Okay and pivoting to just -- looking at your mix part-time versus full-time employees with election behind us and some implementation of the Affordable Care Act, can you give us any insight into your discussions about any -- how you would plan to implement implement that legislation, whether that means change in the mix of employees, changing our benefits offerings, what type of quantify the impact of this legislation on your business at this time?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's difficult to early quantify the impact. We were, estimate this at the registry legislation, one of our concerns was whether this -- the requirement of at least 30 hours a week to qualify for health care benefits, how that would imply up like a s
componenttext: Yes, it's difficult to early quantify the impact. We were, estimate this at the registry legislation, one of our concerns was whether this -- the requirement of at least 30 hours a week to qualify for health care benefits, how that would imply up like a seasonal workers. And because we had particularly let's say in Sports & Entertainment and our higher education operations, we have lots and lots of seasonal workers and apply so we had some concern about that on average the work less than 30 hours a you a week but we don't work less than 30 hours of the company. That's just the regulations that up just on that and it appears that our concern about having a huge increase in eligibility as a result of seasonal workers who average over below 30 hours a week be eligible is not found. So we're heartened by that. And as a result, the impact on us is less significant than we feared that it would be might be. So we're still working through all the details. As you know there's still regulations, clarifications coming out as we speak. There are -- clearly other actions that we can take in some other companies have started to do or talked about which is changing the mix between part-time and full-time workers. So it's difficult to quantify the impact. I guess I would say it's not -- it's not insignificant but it doesn't rise to the level of potentially a major EB I impact as we had in a little bit concerned about it as looked at it a year ago. So we're looking at something in the tens of millions before mitigation.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure that -- we're not sure believe that the legislation itself will drive incremental growth in health care. It certainly puts a lot of additional strains on the system and some of those follow-on contract service providers to hospitals. I guess
componenttext: I'm not sure that -- we're not sure believe that the legislation itself will drive incremental growth in health care. It certainly puts a lot of additional strains on the system and some of those follow-on contract service providers to hospitals. I guess our -- having said that, our view is that health care is clearly a growth market. As you know it's one that's relatively underpenetrated I contractors. We have -- we have a Barry Vogel offering there across the food service traditional facilities and clinical equipment, maintenance Spectrum. So we have a very full offering in that market. and we view that as a very full as a very attractive growth markets and expect that over time, that business will grow higher than the average for us.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll handle your question with respect to the capital structure. I mean, I think general speaking, we're always looking at the market. Clearly the leveraged finance markets are extremely strong right now, which does provide plenty of opportunity gene
componenttext: Yes, I'll handle your question with respect to the capital structure. I mean, I think general speaking, we're always looking at the market. Clearly the leveraged finance markets are extremely strong right now, which does provide plenty of opportunity generally to look at different refinancing alternatives and we continue to look at those. Historically, I think we've always been very prudent and conservative in terms of aggressively refinancing our debt well in advance of maturity. We pushed a lot of our debt out already and I'm sure as we get into early 2013, we'll be continuing to look at the market and look for opportunities to further push out those maturities.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think on the M&A front, I think it's fair to say that there are no businesses we're that we're not pleased with and think have potential over time. So I think as you know, over the last couple of years, we repositioned our uniform business. I think
componenttext: Yes, I think on the M&A front, I think it's fair to say that there are no businesses we're that we're not pleased with and think have potential over time. So I think as you know, over the last couple of years, we repositioned our uniform business. I think we're very comfortable on that. On the acquisition side, I think we'll continue to look for both on acquisitions. Those could be to expand bolt-on our services not way off of where we are right now but in some adjacent areas in either food service or facility services. And the other -- the other opportunity I think for acquisitions is to look at some of the faster growing economies in the world. As I mentioned, when we started out, we're growing at midteens to high teens rates in certain markets in Asia and South America. And certainly, we don't have full coverage in those regions of the world. So I think we'll selectively look there as well.

componenttext: Yes, our -- the annualized -- the way we look at it sort of at the forefront of how we're doing, is the annualized value of contracts that we signed up and the annualized value of contracts that we've lost. Now those are not nationals are reflected in our P&L over time as contract actually come out or as contracts are at it and we start to operate them. And for 2012, as I mentioned briefly in my opening remarks, we had a pretty strong performance overall, and this is -- both the North American food service business, the food facilities business, and the International business in the uniform business and the annualized value -- in the annualized sales value of new contracts that we were awarded sometime during the year was up around 20% or so. And that of course is something that will grow into the financial statements as those contracts are started off. And our -- the dollar value of the contracts that we lost during the year was down I think about between 5% and 10%. So the net new business as a result since the new business was up, loss business was down, the net new business was up a fair amount. And so we were fairly -- fairly pleased on that. We've been more focused particularly on adding new business. We've been adding sales resources, standardizing some of our sales processes and we are pretty encouraged by the results we saw in 2012 [indiscernible] our client retention rate in 2012, I think, was right around 95%.

componenttext: Yes, your in the office in Midtown. So the downtime operation suffered more. So we did feel an impact from Sandy. Some of those operations are still not open or still not fully operational. We had some impact on the uniform services business. We had a -- our plant, our uniform services plant, that services the New York metropolitan area is located in Newark, and we have a depot in Long Island and we have another satellite in Union, New Jersey. And those were the Newark plant was without power 5 or 6 days. We also lost power in Cherry Hill and in writing, Pennsylvania. So we anticipate readying, clearly that there will be some impact on the first quarter of Sandy. It's not -- I think the revenue was in the tens of millions of dollars and I think the EBIT is in the maybe $10 million or less range as we see it right now. And hopefully beyond the first quarter, there won't be any lingering impact. I guess on the upside, we're -- although this is a very small offset, we're at Citi Field, that's one of the staging areas for utility crews from outside of the area and we're feeding them because we have a contract that say field.

componenttext: Now, we have business interruption insurance. So we have property insurance and we have business interruption insurance. And often, when -- whether it was Katrina or any other disasters, often our claim on the business interruption side is higher than our claim on the asset side because JPMorgan, for example, we don't really have any assets other than if there would be inventory -- than we would have that. But often its business interruption.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess I'd expand on that. I mean we're clearly struggling in Spain, and that's pretty much the economy. Now having said that as I think you know, or as we said before, our mix of business in Spain is more favorable. We have a relatively low percent
componenttext: Yes, I guess I'd expand on that. I mean we're clearly struggling in Spain, and that's pretty much the economy. Now having said that as I think you know, or as we said before, our mix of business in Spain is more favorable. We have a relatively low percentage of our business in Spain, just Business & Industry focus, industry clients so we're focused mostly on health care, which is frankly not without some challenges just in terms of being paid because many of them are connected with the government. But we also have a pretty good position in the education market there. So there's -- and those markets is not so much demand problem it's just being sure that you're going to get paid for this service you provide. But Spain is a challenge. Belgium we have relatively small operations in Belgium. That's been a challenge. Germany, as you picked up from the primary marks on the fourth quarter, did okay. I mean, the economy has cooled off in Germany and so it's a difficult environment going forward. In the U.K. as I mentioned, we did actually quite well in the profit side, because the management there has been pretty aggressive in repositioning the business even some of the economic issues. But we're not growing in the U.K And the in Ireland, where we have a very good position and a very balanced mix of food and facilities, we've actually come back pretty well. Yes, we're fortunate that we're not -- we don't have a significant amount of our -- either our European business on the order our total business along the southern -- in the southern part of Europe.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012

Is the -- is the business roughly sequentially stable or have you seen any change in the tone of business, whether its in terms of traffic or mix?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think if you break the -- we're pretty consistent between the third quarter and the fourth quarter. So over that period, we haven't seen much. If you look at the first half of 2012 versus the second half, our growth is a bit lower. And I'd say we're cau
componenttext: I think if you break the -- we're pretty consistent between the third quarter and the fourth quarter. So over that period, we haven't seen much. If you look at the first half of 2012 versus the second half, our growth is a bit lower. And I'd say we're cautious about 2013. Given the 2012 be impacted -- the unemployment rate doesn't seem to be going down. Like obviously, the fiscal cliff is an issue. The various projections being about the potential impact, how many dollars its going to stock, $600 billion out of the economy, increase unemployment by 1 percentage point. So hopefully, the government will model their way through that. I guess I'll just summarize by saying the business -- as we look into '13, the business is certainly not stronger going into '13 that it was going into '12. It's and if anything, it's a little bit weaker. And so while we think we're in a good position for 2013, we're cautious.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: We do. Most of those initiatives are centered around 2 big buckets of cost, food cost and unit labor cost. And we have programs in both areas in the food side. It's around standardizing menus, standardizing the products, the items that we have on our stab
componenttext: We do. Most of those initiatives are centered around 2 big buckets of cost, food cost and unit labor cost. And we have programs in both areas in the food side. It's around standardizing menus, standardizing the products, the items that we have on our stable, providing our front-line live better and more automated tools to manage the production and minimize waste. In labor, it's providing our front-line with better tools to do appropriately schedule labor and manage labor to a schedule to become more efficient. And those are multiyear programs. It just -- it takes quite a while to roll these programs out later in the that thousands of individual units that operate in nonstandard physical locations. So we have -- we have very specific programs that are in rollout. Benefits are identified by location, and are built into our expectations. And are in there really -- certainly to try to improve the overall profitability of the business, but also to make sure that to the extent that we see some drop in base business growth, which is possible, that we thought some contingencies.

componenttext: I did not mention the outlook. So how much spending year that have around that? So is it going to be a large upfront cost or is it going to be spread out over the next year or so as far as implementing the cost saves?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, we typically have expressed a target on prudent labor savings. But there is a multiyear benefit. Our food cost generally runs in the low 30% of our sales. Our labor cost run in the 40% range of our sales. And we're looking to over time, over a multiy
componenttext: Yes, we typically have expressed a target on prudent labor savings. But there is a multiyear benefit. Our food cost generally runs in the low 30% of our sales. Our labor cost run in the 40% range of our sales. And we're looking to over time, over a multiyear period, have a meaningful impact on those costs. So it's we view it as something meaningful in the context of our overall P&L I mean, I mean, given that we're essentially in a 5.5% to 6% margin business. The cost associated with it, there really 2 buckets of cost of cost:one is ask Erin alluded to, we need to increase our IT in infrastructure spending. So some of it is systems there's a couple expenditure that's got some be a now applications and depreciation. It's not something that just drastically changes our overall capital budget. So it's not of that order of magnitude. And then there's an ongoing P&L component as well as we standardize and centralize some of these processes, you just need people to be able to execute that, and roll that out across literally thousands of units. So their period cost associated with that. It's a net positive. It's meaningful for 2013 and we expect to continue to reap benefit from it year-after-year for at least the next 2 to 3 years.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012

componenttext: Okay. Great. And then just lastly, you have a target or leverage number for the business. I know you said that of comfortable with the capital structure you look to take advantage of the market maybe early next year. But do you have a target ratio in mind?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: We don't have a target. We finished the year at just over 5x as Karen mentioned, I think 5.3x. We started at 6.5x, 6.6x. As you saw in a normal year where we make some modest acquisitions, our debt ratio tends to go down by 3/10 or 4/10s of ocean of both
componenttext: We don't have a target. We finished the year at just over 5x as Karen mentioned, I think 5.3x. We started at 6.5x, 6.6x. As you saw in a normal year where we make some modest acquisitions, our debt ratio tends to go down by 3/10 or 4/10s of ocean of both free cash flow that which reduces that. So absent that, a higher than normal acquisitions. I think it's reasonable to expect that that's what would have been. We don't target a particular debt ratio but we look to improve our debt ratio over time. But we've also been very clear that if we have the right acquisition that we think strategically is important, these are moved into a fast-growing region of the world or to expand our service capability to make us a stronger player in the market, we will do that. But as you've seen over the last 5 or 6 years, we've done that in the context of maintaining a sound capital structure.

componenttext: That's right, that's right. I mean, within the context of making sure we don't -- that we maintain a capital structure that's -- it's going to be leveraged. But we're we want to make sure that it's reasonable. That the management your -- we've got a broad group of management that has a lot of stuff. So this is high leverage for decades. But we're prudent about it.
