headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to the ARAMARK Corporation Fourth Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded for rebroadcast and that all participants are in a
componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to the ARAMARK Corporation Fourth Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded for rebroadcast and that all participants are in a listen-only mode. At the request of the company, we will open the conference for questions after the presentation. I will now turn the call over to Karen Wallace, Vice President and Treasurer.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Danielle, and welcome, everyone, to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our operations for the fourth quarter and full year fiscal 2012. Here with me today is Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Finan
componenttext:
Thanks, Danielle, and welcome, everyone, to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our operations for the fourth quarter and full year fiscal 2012. Here with me today is Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fred and I will present an overview of our fourth quarter and full-year results and business operations, after which, there will be an opportunity for phone-in participants to ask questions.
I would like to remind you that any recording or other use or transmission of this audio may not be done without the prior written consent of ARAMARK. As we discuss the results, you may want to refer to the Form 8-K we filed earlier today, which contains our fourth quarter and full-year results for fiscal '12. This Form 8-K can be found on our website at www.aramark.com. In today's discussion of results, we mention certain non-GAAP financial measures and as required by SEC rules, reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most comparable GAAP measures are available on our website.
Our discussion of operating income during today's call will, in each instance, exclude the incremental intangibles amortization and property and equipment depreciation expense resulting from the going private transaction, the impact of stock option expense and the impact on the change in fair value related to our gasoline and diesel fuel agreements. All of these items are detailed in the schedules posted to our website before this call. In addition, the prior year period results have been restated to present the results of the Galls business as a discontinued operation as we sold it in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011.
Various remarks that we may make in this call relating to matters that are not historical facts, including remarks about future expectations, anticipation, beliefs, estimates, plans and prospects constitute forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from those expressed or implied as a result of various risks, uncertainties and important factors, including those discussed in the Risk Factors, MD&A and other sections of our Form 10-K and the Form 10-Q. We disclaim any duty to update or revise such forward-looking statements, whether as a result of future events or otherwise.
I will now turn the program over to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everybody, and thanks for joining us as we review our fiscal 2012 fourth quarter and our full-year results. As in prior quarters, I'd like to review our business and operating results and then ask Karen to cover a few additional details on
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everybody, and thanks for joining us as we review our fiscal 2012 fourth quarter and our full-year results. As in prior quarters, I'd like to review our business and operating results and then ask Karen to cover a few additional details on our performance. Overall, our results for fiscal 2012 were in line with the economic conditions in the countries in which we operate. Our operations in China and South America are continuing to grow at significantly higher rates than our total portfolio of businesses. And we're excited about the opportunities that lie ahead for these regions. As you would expect, Continental Europe results were more mixed as our operations in Spain and Belgium struggled, while Germany continued to deliver solid performance. Our U.K. and Ireland operations realize the benefit of substantial cost reduction efforts in prior years. In North America, our Higher Education business continues to lead our overall growth.
2012 was a record year for us in terms of new sales across our food facilities and uniform businesses. With the new sales contracted or installed up over 30% over the prior year, providing us with a strong carrying rate of business for 2013. If you see -- as you've seen in the financial statement released earlier today, our free cash flow for the year was also very strong led by our continued emphasis on working capital and earnings growth for the year.
One of our proudest accomplishments this year was our success -- is the exclusive catering provider to more than 15,000 athletes, officials and staff in the Athletes' Village over the duration of the Olympic and Paralympic Games in London this summer. During the games, our staff of over 3,500 on the ground in London served over 1.5 million meals peaking at 65,000 meals per day. London was ARAMARK's 16the Olympic Games.
We were also proud to have hosted delegates and other attendees at the Republican National Convention in Tampa Bay in September, serving nearly 15,000 meals over the span of 5 days. And earlier in the summer, we served baseball fans attending the Major League Baseball All-Star Game in Kansas City. We deeply appreciate the trust our clients place in us to serve at these very important events.
Now turning to the details of our results for the year, I'd like to first take you through our overall financial performance and then I'll discuss our business segments. We reported fiscal 2012 fourth quarter sales of $3.4 billion, up 3% from the prior year quarter. Organic sales growth, which as you know excludes the impact of currency translation and acquisitions and divestitures, was 4% in the quarter. Adjusted operating income was $206 million, up 5% versus the prior year. For the full fiscal year 2012, sales were $13.5 billion, up 3% over the prior period on a reported basis and 4% on an organic growth basis. Our adjusted operating income of $750 million was up 4% for the prior year.
Now turning to our North American Food and Support Services segment, fourth quarter reported sales were up 3% to $2.4 billion led primarily by growth in the Higher Education business and our Business & Industry sector. Organic sales growth was 3% in the quarter. For the full-year 2012, reported sales were up 4% to $9.4 billion with organic growth of 3%. Year-to-date performance was led by solid growth in all sectors and particularly strong growth in our Higher Education sector. 
Now taking a closer look at the sectors within North America, our Business & Industry sector had a high single-digit sales increase for the quarter and for the full-year, reflecting the positive impact from the Filterfresh acquisition which, as you may recall, closed in early October of 2011, so the very beginning of this -- of fiscal year 2012.
Growth in the quarter was supported by improved base business growth in our Refreshment Services business, while our B&I facilities business also contributed to the increase in both the quarter and for the full year, primarily due to strong growth in our remote services operations in Canada. Our business operations Dining divisions experienced a slight sales decline versus the prior year for both the quarter and the full fiscal year. The Education sector had low single-digit sales growth for the quarter and mid-single digit sales growth for the fiscal year, primarily driven by higher growth in the average -- in our Higher Education food business, resulting from a combination of base business growth and very solid new sales from contract wins in prior periods.
In our Healthcare sector, we experienced low single-digit sales growth in the quarter and for the full year. The sales growth in the quarter was a result of base business growth and our Healthcare Technologies business, as well as new business growth in Healthcare Hospitality. The growth of the full-year fiscal 2012 was primarily a result of base business growth and the acquisition in March of 2011 of Masterplan within our health care technologies business.
Our Sports & Entertainment sector had a low single-digit sales increase for the quarter and for the full year. For the quarter, we reported good growth in our amphitheater business, somewhat offset by the timing of Major League Baseball gains in the early effects of the NHL lockout, which the defect September. Our growth for fiscal 2012 was negatively affected by the NBA strike earlier in the year, but that impact was offset by solid results during the NHL season last year and the strength in Major League Baseball.
Adjusted operating income in the North American Food and Support Services segment increased by 7% in the quarter to $153 million, led by profit growth in our Business & Industry and Sports & Entertainment sectors. Profit for the fourth quarter included recognition of approximately $7 million of income related to a compensation agreement signed with the National Park Service, under which they paid down a portion of our possessed reinterest of one of our terminated client locations.
For fiscal 2012, segment adjusted operating income grew 5% to $541 million, led by strong profit growth in our Higher Education business and the Healthcare sector. Results for fiscal 2011 included the recognition of approximately $8 million of income in the first quarter, also related similarly to a compensation agreement signed with the National Park Service, under which they paid down a portion of our possessed reinterest at one of our concession contracts.
Turning to the International Food and Support Services segment, fourth quarter reported sales of $699 million were up 3% on a reported basis and 11% on an organic basis. Sales growth for the quarter was due to positive growth in Ireland, South America and China, as well as the sales impact from our role as the exclusive food service provider in the Athletes' Village for the London Olympics games. This growth was partially offset by sales decline in the U.K.-based business and Spain. 
For the fiscal year 2012, our reported sales of $2.7 billion were flat compared to the prior year on a reported basis primarily due to the impact a the stronger dollar. Organic growth was 6%, again led primarily by the Olympic Games, but also due to growth in Germany, Ireland, South America and China, which more than offset the sales decline in the U.K.-based business, in Spain and in Belgium.
Fourth quarter adjusted operating income was $27 million, which was down about 3% when compared to the prior year quarter, with currency translation negatively affecting profit growth by approximately 4 percentage points. Results in the quarter primarily reflect improving profit performance in the U.K. and in Ireland, of which I think is particularly admirable in a very difficult economic environment, which was offset by a profit decline in Continental Europe.
For the first -- for the full fiscal year of 2012, adjusted operating income was $100 million, up from $91 million in the prior year. Growth was driven by the U.K., Ireland, Germany, Chile and China, and partially offset by Belgium and our AIM joint venture in Japan. Currency translation also negatively affected profit growth by about 4 percentage points.
 
In our Uniform and Career Apparel segment, fourth quarter sales of $342 million were up 3% from the year-ago quarter on both a reported and an organic basis. Improving organic growth rates in the uniform rental business, which in the fourth quarter were in the mid-single digits, were offset by softness in our direct sale business. For the fiscal year 2012, segment sales of $1.4 billion were up 2% from the prior year on both a reported and organic basis. 
We're continuing to invest in additional rental sales personnel resources to support accelerated new sales growth. We're gaining improved traction in our new sales efforts as wear [ph] accounts continue to grow. Our new business installed in 2012 was up over 20% for the full year as a result of both a larger sales force and increased sales productivity. And, of course, we're paying the price of that a bit on both our sales expense and our merchandise amortization.
The segment's fourth quarter adjusted operating income was $38 million. This compares to fourth quarter of 2011 adjusted operating income of $34 million. Results from 2011 included restructuring expenses following our divestiture of our Galls subsidiary in September of 2011. Excluding these costs from the prior year, adjusted operating income in the fourth quarter of 2012 would've been up in the mid-single digits, which is an improvement from recent quarters. 
For the full fiscal year, adjusted operating income was $145 million, down slightly from the $146 million of the prior year. And as I mentioned, increased sales cost of the expansion of the sales force and a significant increase in our merchandise amortization cost associated with substantially higher levels of new business have had a negative impact on profit growth in the year. But we firmly believe that over the intermediate term, these efforts are leading to both improving rental sales and profit growth as we look further into 2013.
Corporate expenses, which exclude the items Karen mentioned earlier, were $11.5 million in the quarter compared to $8.5 million a year ago. And for the fiscal year 2012, expenses were $36.4 million compared to $32.2 million in the prior year. Now let me turn it back over to Karen from some additional details in the quarter and the fiscal year.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Fred. I'd like to comment on our financing, capital structure and cash flow. Our adjusted EBITDA for the trailing 12 months ending September 28 was $1.136 billion, equal to the figure we reported as of June 29, 2012, and up from the $1.1 billion a
componenttext:
Thanks, Fred. I'd like to comment on our financing, capital structure and cash flow. Our adjusted EBITDA for the trailing 12 months ending September 28 was $1.136 billion, equal to the figure we reported as of June 29, 2012, and up from the $1.1 billion as of September 30, 2011. Interest and other financing costs were $87 million for the fourth quarter compared to $111 million in the prior year. Our interest expense in the quarter was lower primarily as a result of a number of interest rate swaps that matured at the end of March 2012. 
For the fiscal year 2012, interest and other financing costs were $402 million, down from the prior year's expense of $426 million. In the second quarter of 2012, we reported approximately $11 million of expenses related to the term loan extension we completed during the quarter. In 2011, we had interest income of approximately $14 million recorded that was related to the settlement of U.K. VAT claims from prior periods. Including the impact of interest rate hedges, approximately 50% of our total debt portfolio is at fixed interest rates, and our overall weighted average cost of debt is approximately 5.1%.
Total reported debt at the end of fiscal year 2012 was $5.413 billion. Our secured debt, as defined in our credit agreement, totaled $3.602 billion, including a term loan balance of $3.289 billion and a revolver balance that was 0. In June 2012, we amended our accounts receivable securitization facility, increasing the maximum amount from $250 million to $300 million and extending the maturity date to January of 2015. That facility had $264 million utilized at year end. We also had approximately $649 million of available capacity under our revolving credit facility as of year end. Based on our trailing adjusted EBITDA, our secured debt ratio was 3.11x as of September 28, which is down from the 3.41x we reported as of June 29, 2012, and that 3.17x we reported that the end of September 30, 2011.
During 2012, we utilized $250 million of free cash flow to fund the repayment of our 5% notes. Without this maturity, we would've utilized free cash flow to pay down secured debt, and we would've seen a more substantial improvement in our secured debt ratio, consistent with our strong cash flow performance for the year. Our ratio of total debt to adjusted EBITDA at end of fiscal 2012 was 4.76x, and this compares to 5.09x at the end of the third quarter and 5.13x as of the end of fiscal 2011. Overall, we're pleased with our EBITDA growth and our ratio momentum, and we anticipate further ratio improvement over time. 
Net capital expenditures for the quarter were $124 million compared to $92 million in the prior year quarter. For the fiscal year, net capital expenditures totaled $343 million compared to $272 million in the same period last year. This higher level of spending reflects planned investment in our infrastructure, as well as our sales growth objectives.
Consistent with our expectations and historical patterns, working capital was a significant source of cash for us during the fourth quarter. We ended the year with working capital as a relatively moderate source of cash overall for the year. We would anticipate that we will return to a more typical pattern in fiscal 2013, with working capital requiring a modest level of investments.
For the year, we're very pleased with our free cash flow performance before acquisitions and divestitures as we generated approximately $403 million of free cash flow in fiscal 2012, a total that exceeded our plan and reflects our growth in operating income and continued strong focus on working capital this plan.
For the fiscal year, we spent a total of $152 million on acquisitions compared to $167 million in the prior year period. This year's spending, related primarily to the acquisition of Filterfresh and our North American Refreshment Services business, which closed in October of 2011. We continue to evaluate and seek to make strategic investments in certain sectors and geographies, but we plan to be prudent and disciplined in the pursuit of these opportunities. 
Now let me turn the call back over to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Karen. So summing up our performance for this fiscal year, our global Food and Support Services business has delivered solid organic growth, with slightly stronger profit growth. Our uniform rental business is gaining traction from the significant
componenttext:
Thanks, Karen. So summing up our performance for this fiscal year, our global Food and Support Services business has delivered solid organic growth, with slightly stronger profit growth. Our uniform rental business is gaining traction from the significant investments we've made over the past several quarters and accelerating new sales. 
As we look forward, we have strengths that we need to leverage. We have strong positions and attractive sectors, great people with pride and passion, strong values and the desire to do the right thing and a focus on client service. We believe there are many attractive growth opportunities in front of us despite the economic clients -- the economic climate, as many of our sectors remained significantly under-penetrated. We remain excited about pursuing those opportunities. We need to create growth-relating [ph] positions as we strive to become the most valued partner to our clients and consumers.
And on the cost side, we see additional opportunities to improve our performance. In late 2011, we embarked on a number of internal initiatives aimed at delivering improved organic growth and continued margin improvement in the coming years. These activities have already delivered benefits in 2012, but we are committed to continue to improve our standards, processes and systems, bringing efficiencies and improved effectiveness to how we serve our clients and customers everyday around the world. During 2013, we're planning to further accelerate this process standardization, which we believe will help us drive ongoing margin improvement. 
So thank you again for your time this afternoon and for your support of ARAMARK. And we'd be now happy to take your questions.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And the first question will come from Bryan Hunt with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And the first question will come from Bryan Hunt with Wells Fargo.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012

componenttext: This is Kevin standing in for Bryan. Fred, you mentioned NHL impacted the Sports & Entertainment business segment. Can you remind us how many stadiums you service? And what the potential impact of a season-long strike would have on your business?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, we -- we provide service at 9 NHL arenas. The fall season impact on us on the top line would be somewhere in the range of $100 million, and this would be the fall season plus our budget for the playoffs, because we do budgets on playoff games. And th
componenttext: Yes, we -- we provide service at 9 NHL arenas. The fall season impact on us on the top line would be somewhere in the range of $100 million, and this would be the fall season plus our budget for the playoffs, because we do budgets on playoff games. And the drop through on that would be somewhere in the range of 20%. So it's certainly not 0, but it's not material in the overall scheme of things.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay and pivoting to just -- looking at your mix of part-time versus full-time employees with the election behind us and the coming implementation of the Affordable Care Act, can you give us any insight into your discussions about any -- how you w
componenttext: Got it. Okay and pivoting to just -- looking at your mix of part-time versus full-time employees with the election behind us and the coming implementation of the Affordable Care Act, can you give us any insight into your discussions about any -- how you would plan to implement that legislation, whether that means changing the mix of employees, changing your benefits offerings? What type of -- can you quantify the impact of this legislation on your business at this time?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's difficult to really quantify the impact. We were, as we looked at the legislation as it stood, one of our concerns was whether this -- the requirement of at least 30 hours a week to qualify for health care benefits, how that would apply to seaso
componenttext: Yes, it's difficult to really quantify the impact. We were, as we looked at the legislation as it stood, one of our concerns was whether this -- the requirement of at least 30 hours a week to qualify for health care benefits, how that would apply to seasonal workers. And because we have, particularly let's say in Sports & Entertainment and our Higher Education operations, we have lots and lots of seasonal workers, and so we had some concern about that. On average, they work less than 30 hours a week, but they don't work less than 30 hours every week. There's new regulations that have just come out on that and it appears that our concern about having a huge increase in eligibility as a result of seasonal workers who average over below 30 hours a week being eligible is not found -- or is not founded, so we're heartened by that. And as a result, the impact on us is less significant than we feared that it might be. So we're still working through all the details. As you know, there's still regulations, clarifications coming out as we speak. There are clearly other actions that we can take that some other companies have started to do or talked about, which is changing the mix between part-time and full-time workers. So it's difficult to quantify the impact. I guess, I would say, it's not insignificant but it doesn't rise to the level of potentially a major EBIT impact, as we had been a little bit concerned about it as looked at it a year ago. So we're looking at something that's in the tens of millions before mitigation.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then on the other hand, with the potential for increased hospital visits from expansion of coverage, do you see an opportunity to gain incremental business with hospital systems as a result of this legislation?
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then on the other hand, with the potential for increased hospital visits from expansion of coverage, do you see an opportunity to gain incremental business with hospital systems as a result of this legislation?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure that -- we're not sure really that the legislation itself will drive incremental growth in health care. It certainly puts a lot of additional strains on the system and some of those follow-on contract service providers to hospitals. I guess o
componenttext: I'm not sure that -- we're not sure really that the legislation itself will drive incremental growth in health care. It certainly puts a lot of additional strains on the system and some of those follow-on contract service providers to hospitals. I guess our -- having said that, our view is that health care is clearly a growth market. As you know, it's one that's relatively under-penetrated by contractors. We have a very full offering there across the food service traditional facilities and clinical equipment, maintenance spectrum, so we have a very full offering in that market. And we view that as a very attractive growth market and expect that over time, that business will grow higher than the average for us.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great. Okay. And one last final question from us, I'll hand it off. Are you still content with your current capital structure? Are you in active discussions to possibly refinance the bonds that are callable and push out maturities further? How do you thin
componenttext: Great. Okay. And one last final question from us, I'll hand it off. Are you still content with your current capital structure? Are you in active discussions to possibly refinance the bonds that are callable and push out maturities further? How do you think about your capital structure entering the new year? And also, addition to that question, are you happy with the way your business looks today? Are there other incremental acquisitions that you could pursue or businesses that you may consider non-core? Just trying to get a feel of how your business will look like for the next couple of quarters.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'll handle your question with respect to the capital structure. I mean, I think general speaking, we're always looking at the market. Clearly the leveraged finance markets are extremely strong right now, which does provide plenty of opportunities to look
componenttext: I'll handle your question with respect to the capital structure. I mean, I think general speaking, we're always looking at the market. Clearly the leveraged finance markets are extremely strong right now, which does provide plenty of opportunities to look at different refinancing alternatives and we continue to look at those. Historically, I think we've always been very prudent and conservative in terms of aggressively refinancing our debt well in advance of maturity. We've pushed a lot of our debt out already. And I'm sure, as we get into early 2013, we'll be continuing to look at the market and look for opportunities to further push out some of those maturities.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think on the M&A front, I think it's fair to say that there are no businesses we're in that we're not pleased with and think have potential over time. So I think, as you know, over the last couple of years, we repositioned our Uniform business, I t
componenttext: Yes, I think on the M&A front, I think it's fair to say that there are no businesses we're in that we're not pleased with and think have potential over time. So I think, as you know, over the last couple of years, we repositioned our Uniform business, I think we're very comfortable with that. On the acquisition side, I think we'll continue to look for bolt-on acquisitions. Those could be to expand our services not way off of where we are right now but in some adjacent areas in either food service or facility services. And the other -- the other opportunity I think for acquisitions is to look at some of the faster growing economies in the world. As I mentioned, when we started out, we're growing at mid-teens to high-teens rates in certain markets in Asia and South America. And certainly, we don't have full coverage in those regions of the world. So I think we'll selectively look there as well.

componenttext: Can you just talk about overall -- you mentioned in some of your segment comments, contract wins and losses. But in general, how are you tracking on contract wins and losses versus the last year?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, our -- the annualized -- the way we look at it sort of at the forefront of how we're doing, is the annualized value of contracts that we signed up and the annualized value of contracts that we've lost. Now those are not -- those are reflected in our
componenttext: Yes, our -- the annualized -- the way we look at it sort of at the forefront of how we're doing, is the annualized value of contracts that we signed up and the annualized value of contracts that we've lost. Now those are not -- those are reflected in our P&L over time as the contracts are actually come out or as contracts are added and we start to operate them. And for 2012, as I mentioned briefly in my opening remarks, we had a pretty strong performance overall, and this is both the North American food service business -- food facilities business, the International business and the Uniform business, and the annualized value -- the annualized sales value of new contracts that we were awarded sometime during the year was up around 20% or so. And that of course is something that will roll into the financial statements as those contracts are started off. And our -- the dollar value of the contracts that we lost during the year was down I think about between 5% and 10%. So the net new business, as a result since the new business was up and the loss business was down, the net new business was up a fair amount. And so we were fairly pleased on that. We've been --  we're so focused particularly on adding new business. We've been adding sales resources, standardizing some of our sales processes, and we are pretty encouraged by the results we saw in 2012. The client retention rate -- our client retention rate in 2012, I think, was right around 95%.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're at the office in Midtown. So the Downtown operations suffered even more. So we did feel an impact from Sandy. Some of those operations are still not open or still not fully operational. We had some impact on the Uniform Services business. We h
componenttext: Yes, you're at the office in Midtown. So the Downtown operations suffered even more. So we did feel an impact from Sandy. Some of those operations are still not open or still not fully operational. We had some impact on the Uniform Services business. We have our plant, our Uniform Services plant that services the New York metropolitan area, is located in Newark, and we have a depot in Long Island and we have another satellite in Union, New Jersey. And those were -- the Newark plant was without power I think for 5 or 6 days. We also lost power in Cherry Hill and in Reading, Pennsylvania. So we anticipate, clearly, that there will be some impact on the first quarter of Sandy. It's not -- I think the revenue was in the tens of millions of dollars and I think the EBIT is in the maybe $10 million or less range as we see it right now. And hopefully beyond the first quarter, there won't be any lingering impact. I guess on the upside, we're -- although this is a very small offset, we're feeding at Citi Field, that's one of the staging areas for utility crews from outside of the area and we're feeding them, because we have a contract at Citi Field.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: And our risk management group, as well, is in the process obviously of going through location by location, seeing what business interruption claims might be out there for us as well.
componenttext: And our risk management group, as well, is in the process obviously of going through location by location, seeing what business interruption claims might be out there for us as well.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. Do you typically have loss of sales type or loss of business claims? Are they typically just that facilities that are damaged?
componenttext: Okay. Great. Do you typically have loss of sales type or loss of business claims? Are they typically just that facilities that are damaged?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: No, we have business interruption insurance. So we have property insurance and we have business interruption insurance. And often, when -- whether it was Katrina or other disasters, often our claim on the business interruption side is higher than our clai
componenttext: No, we have business interruption insurance. So we have property insurance and we have business interruption insurance. And often, when -- whether it was Katrina or other disasters, often our claim on the business interruption side is higher than our claim on the asset side, because JPMorgan, for example, we don't really have any assets other than if there would be inventory spoilage then we would have that. But often its business interruption.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: So on the Europe business, you seem to indicate little weaker trends in Spain, but seemingly roughly unchanged trends in the other countries, in your European operations, is that about accurate?
componenttext: So on the Europe business, you seem to indicate little weaker trends in Spain, but seemingly roughly unchanged trends in the other countries, in your European operations, is that about accurate?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: I guess I'd expand on that. I mean, we're clearly struggling in Spain, and that's pretty much the economy. Now having said that, as I think you know or as we said before, our mix of business in Spain is more favorable. We have a relatively low percentage
componenttext: I guess I'd expand on that. I mean, we're clearly struggling in Spain, and that's pretty much the economy. Now having said that, as I think you know or as we said before, our mix of business in Spain is more favorable. We have a relatively low percentage of our business in Spain that's Business & Industry focused business clients, so we're focused mostly in health care, which is frankly not without some challenges just in terms of being paid because many of them are connected with the government. And -- but we also have a pretty good position in the education market there. So there's -- and those markets is not so much demand problem, it's just being sure that you're going to get paid for the service you provide. But Spain is a challenge. Belgium, we have relatively small operations in Belgium, that's been a challenge. Germany, as you picked up from the prepared remarks on the fourth quarter, did okay. I mean, that it's -- the economy has cooled off in Germany and so it's a difficult environment going forward. In the U.K., as I mentioned, we did actually quite well in the profit side, because the management there has been pretty aggressive in repositioning the business given some of the economic issues. But we're not growing in the U.K. And the in Ireland, where we have a very good position and a very balanced mix of food and facilities, we've actually come back pretty well. We're fortunate that we're not -- we don't have a significant amount of our -- either our European business or our total business along the southern -- in the southern part of Europe.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, as it relates to the U.S. business, the USFS business, your organic sales growth was fairly close to what you posted in the last couple of quarters. Is the business roughly sequentially stable or have you seen any change in the tone of b
componenttext: Got it. And then, as it relates to the U.S. business, the USFS business, your organic sales growth was fairly close to what you posted in the last couple of quarters. Is the business roughly sequentially stable or have you seen any change in the tone of business, whether its in terms of traffic or mix?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think if you break the -- we're pretty consistent between the third quarter and the fourth quarter. So over that period, we haven't seen much. If you look at the first half of 2012 versus the second half, our growth is a bit lower. And I'd say we're cau
componenttext: I think if you break the -- we're pretty consistent between the third quarter and the fourth quarter. So over that period, we haven't seen much. If you look at the first half of 2012 versus the second half, our growth is a bit lower. And I'd say we're cautious about 2013. Given the impacts -- the unemployment rate doesn't seem to be going down. Like obviously, the fiscal cliff is an issue. The various projections being banded about the potential impact, how many dollars its going to suck $600 billion out of the economy, increase unemployment by 1 percentage point. So hopefully, the government will model their way through that. I guess I'll just summarize by saying the business, as we look into '13, the business is certainly not stronger going into '13 that it was going into '12. If anything, it's a little bit weaker. So while we think we're in a good position for 2013, we're cautious.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Right. And then as far as productivity and other the cost savings, do you have initiatives to generate some cost savings in general to improve margins but also to offset potential labor cost headwinds perhaps in 2014?
componenttext: Right. And then as far as productivity and other the cost savings, do you have initiatives to generate some cost savings in general to improve margins but also to offset potential labor cost headwinds perhaps in 2014?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: We do. Most of those initiatives are centered around 2 big buckets of cost, food cost and unit labor cost. And we have programs in both areas in the food side. It's around standardizing menus, standardizing the products, the items that we have on our stab
componenttext: We do. Most of those initiatives are centered around 2 big buckets of cost, food cost and unit labor cost. And we have programs in both areas in the food side. It's around standardizing menus, standardizing the products, the items that we have on our stable, providing our front-line with better and more automated tools to manage food production and minimize waste. In labor, it's providing our front-line with better tools to do appropriately schedule labor and manage labor to a schedule to become more efficient. And those are multiyear programs. It just -- it takes quite a while to roll these programs out literally to thousands of individual units that operate in nonstandard physical locations. So we have very specific programs that are in rollout. Benefits are identified by location and are built into our expectations, and are in there really, certainly, to try to improve the overall profitability of the business, but also to make sure that to the extent that we see some drop in base business growth, which is possible, that we've got some contingencies.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it. And Karen, did you mention what the CapEx outlook looks like in 2013?
componenttext: Got it. And Karen, did you mention what the CapEx outlook looks like in 2013?

componenttext: I did not mention the outlook. I think what we would generally say is that in 2013, we'll continue to be probably spending at a slightly higher rate in '13 versus what we did in '12, kind it's similar to what we saw from '11 to '12. I think there's a fair bit of new business growth in 2013, it's going to require some capital spending along with some additional infrastructure spending.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go to Pat DiMeglio with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go to Pat DiMeglio with Deutsche Bank.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just on the cost saves that you mentioned, can you give any more color around a target you have for the year and going forward? And then how much spending you're going to have around that? So is it going to be a large upfront cost or is it going to be spr
componenttext: Just on the cost saves that you mentioned, can you give any more color around a target you have for the year and going forward? And then how much spending you're going to have around that? So is it going to be a large upfront cost or is it going to be spread out over the next year or so as far as implementing the cost saves?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, we typically haven't [ph] expressed a target on prudent labor savings. But there is a multiyear benefit. Our food costs generally run in the low 30% of our sales. Our labor costs run in the 40% range of our sales. And we're looking to, over time, ove
componenttext: Yes, we typically haven't [ph] expressed a target on prudent labor savings. But there is a multiyear benefit. Our food costs generally run in the low 30% of our sales. Our labor costs run in the 40% range of our sales. And we're looking to, over time, over a multiyear period, have a meaningful impact on those costs. So we view it as something that's meaningful in the context of our overall P&L, I mean, given that we're essentially in a 5.5% to 6% margin business. The costs associated with it, there are really 2 buckets of costs. One is we're, as Karen alluded to, we need to increase our IT and infrastructure spending. So some of it is systems, there's a capital expenditure that's got some P&L applications and depreciation. It's not something that just drastically changes our overall capital budget, so it's not of that order of magnitude. And then there's an ongoing P&L component as well as we standardize and centralize some of these processes, you just need people to be able to execute that and roll that out across literally thousands of units, so there are period costs associated with that. It's a net positive. It's meaningful for 2013 and we expect to continue to reap benefit from it year-after-year for at least the next 2 to 3 years.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then just lastly, do you have a target leverage number for the business? I know you said kind of comfortable with the capital structure, you'd look to take advantage of the market maybe early next year. But do you have a target ratio in m
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then just lastly, do you have a target leverage number for the business? I know you said kind of comfortable with the capital structure, you'd look to take advantage of the market maybe early next year. But do you have a target ratio in mind?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: We don't have a target. We finished the year at just over 5x, as Karen mentioned, I think 5.3x. We started at 6.5x, 6.6x. As you saw in a normal year where we make some modest acquisitions, our debt ratio tends to go down by 0.3 or 0.4 as a function of gr
componenttext: We don't have a target. We finished the year at just over 5x, as Karen mentioned, I think 5.3x. We started at 6.5x, 6.6x. As you saw in a normal year where we make some modest acquisitions, our debt ratio tends to go down by 0.3 or 0.4 as a function of growth in EBITDA both and free cash flow which reduces debt. So absent in higher-than-normal acquisitions, I think it's reasonable to expect that -- that's what would happen. We don't target a particular debt ratio, but we look to improve our debt ratio over time. But we've also been very clear that if we have the right acquisition that we think strategically is important, these are moved into a fast-growing region of the world or to expand our service capability to make us a stronger player in the market, we will do that. But as you've seen over the last 5 or 6 years, we've done that in the context of maintaining a sound capital structure.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012

componenttext: Okay. So basically flexible if you see an acquisition that you think makes sense?

componenttext: That's right, that's right. I mean, within the context of making sure we don't -- that we maintain a capital structure that's -- it's going to be leveraged. But we want to make sure that it's reasonable, right? And the management here -- again, we've got a broad group of management that owns a lot of stock. So this company has lived with high leverage for decades, but we're prudent about it.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to the ARAMARK Corporation Fourth Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]. At the request of the company, we will open the conference for questions after the presentation. I will no
componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to the ARAMARK Corporation Fourth Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]. At the request of the company, we will open the conference for questions after the presentation. I will now turn the call over to Karen Wallace, Vice President and Treasurer.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Danielle, and welcome, everyone, to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our operations for the fourth quarter and full year fiscal 2012. Here with me today is Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Finan
componenttext:
Thanks, Danielle, and welcome, everyone, to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our operations for the fourth quarter and full year fiscal 2012. Here with me today is Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fred and I will present an overview of our fourth quarter and full-year results and business operations, after which, there will be an opportunity for phone-in participants to ask questions.
I would like to remind you that any recording or other use or transmission of this audio may not be done without the prior written consent of ARAMARK. As we discuss the results, you may want to refer to the Form 8-K we filed earlier today, which contains our fourth quarter and full-year results for fiscal '12. This Form 8-K can be found on our website at www.aramark.com. In today's discussion of results, we mention certain non-GAAP financial measures and as required by SEC rules, reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most comparable GAAP measures are available on our website.
Our discussion of operating income during today's call will, in each instance, exclude the incremental intangibles amortization and property and equipment depreciation expense resulting from the going private transaction, the impact of stock option expense and the impact on the change in fair value related to our gasoline and diesel fuel agreements. All of these items are detailed in the schedules posted to our website before this call. In addition, the prior year period results have been restated to present the results of the Galls business as a discontinued operation as we sold it in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011.
Various remarks that we may make in this call relating to matters that are not historical facts, including remarks about future expectations, anticipations, beliefs, estimates, plans and prospects constitute forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from those expressed or implied as a result of various risks, uncertainties and important factors, including those discussed in the Risk Factors, MD&A and other sections of our Form 10-K and Form 10-Q's. We disclaim any duty to update or revise such forward-looking statements, whether as a result of future events or otherwise.
I will now turn the program over to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everybody, and thanks for joining us as we review our fiscal 2012 fourth quarter and our full-year results. As in prior quarters, I'd like to review our business and operating results and then ask Karen to cover a few additional details on
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everybody, and thanks for joining us as we review our fiscal 2012 fourth quarter and our full-year results. As in prior quarters, I'd like to review our business and operating results and then ask Karen to cover a few additional details on our performance. Overall, our results for fiscal 2012 were in line with the economic conditions in the countries in which we operate. Our operations in China and South America are continuing to grow at significantly higher rates than our total portfolio of businesses. And we are excited about the opportunities that lie ahead for these regions. As you would expect, Continental Europe results were more mixed as our operations in Spain and Belgium struggled, while Germany continued to deliver solid performance. Our U.K. and Ireland operations realized the benefit of substantial cost reduction efforts in prior years. In North America, our Higher Education business continues to lead our overall growth.
2012 was a record year for us in terms of new sales across our food facilities and uniform businesses. With the new sales contracted or installed up over 30% over the prior year, providing us with a strong carry-in rate of business for 2013. If you see -- as you've seen in the financial statement released earlier today, our free cash flow for the year was also very strong led by our continued emphasis on working capital and earnings growth for the year.
One of our proudest accomplishments this year was our success  as the exclusive catering provider to more than 15,000 athletes, officials and staff in the Athletes' Village over the duration of the Olympic and Paralympic Games in London this summer. During the games, our staff of over 3,500 on the ground in London served over 1.5 million meals peaking at 65,000 meals per day. London was ARAMARK's sixteenth Olympic Games.
We were also proud to have hosted delegates and other attendees at the Republican National Convention in Tampa Bay in September, serving nearly 15,000 meals over the span of 5 days. And earlier in the summer, we served baseball fans attending the Major League Baseball All-Star Game in Kansas City. We deeply appreciate the trust our clients place in us to serve at these very important events.
Now turning to the details of our results for the year, I'd like to first take you through our overall financial performance and then I'll discuss our business segments. We reported fiscal 2012 fourth quarter sales of $3.4 billion, up 3% from the prior year quarter. Organic sales growth, which as you know excludes the impact of currency translation and acquisitions and divestitures, was 4% in the quarter. Adjusted operating income was $206 million, up 5% versus the prior year. For the full fiscal year 2012 sales were $13.5 billion, up 3% over the prior period on a reported basis and 4% on an organic growth basis. Our adjusted operating income of $750 million was up 4% for the prior year.
Now turning to our North American Food and Support Services segment, fourth quarter reported sales were up 3% to $2.4 billion led primarily by growth in the Higher Education business and our Business & Industry sector. Organic sales growth was 3% in the quarter. For the full-year 2012, reported sales were up 4% to $9.4 billion with organic growth of 3%. Year-to-date performance was led by solid growth in all sectors and particularly strong growth in our Higher Education sector. 
Now taking a closer look at the sectors within North America, our Business & Industry sector had a high single-digit sales increase for the quarter and for the full-year, reflecting the positive impact from the Filterfresh acquisition which, as you may recall closed in early October of 2011, so the very beginning of this -- of fiscal year 2012.
Growth in the quarter was supported by improved base business growth in our Refreshment Services business, while our B&I facilities business also contributed to the increase in both the quarter and for the full year, primarily due to strong growth in our remote services operations in Canada. Our business operations Dining divisions experienced a slight sales decline versus the prior year for both the quarter and the full fiscal year. The Education sector had low single-digit sales growth for the quarter and mid-single digit sales growth for the fiscal year, primarily driven by higher growth in the average -- in our Higher Education food business, resulting from a combination of base business growth and very solid new sales from contract wins in prior periods.
In our Healthcare sector, we experienced low single-digit sales growth for the quarter and for the full year. The sales growth in the quarter was a result of base business growth in our Healthcare Technologies business, as well as new business growth in Healthcare Hospitality. The growth for the full-year fiscal 2012 was primarily a result of base business growth and the acquisition in March of 2011 of Masterplan within our health care technologies business.
Our Sports & Entertainment sector had a low single-digit sales increase for the quarter and for the full year. For the quarter, we reported good growth in our amphitheater business, somewhat offset by the timing of Major League Baseball games and the early effects of the NHL lockout which did affect September. Our growth for fiscal 2012 was negatively affected by the NBA strike earlier in the year, but that impact was offset by solid results during the NHL season last year and the strength in Major League Baseball.
Adjusted operating income in the North American Food and Support Services segment increased by 7% in the quarter to $153 million, led by profit growth in our Business & Industry and Sports & Entertainment sectors. Profit for the fourth quarter included recognition of approximately $7 million of income related to a compensation agreement signed with the National Park Service, under which they paid down a portion of our possessed reinterest at one of our terminated client locations.
For fiscal 2012, segment adjusted operating income grew 5% to $541 million, led by strong profit growth in our Higher Education business and the Healthcare sector. Results for fiscal 2011 included the recognition of approximately $8 million of income in the first quarter, also related similarly to a compensation agreement signed with the National Park Service, under which they paid down a portion of our possessed reinterest at one of our concession contracts.
Turning to the International Food and Support Services segment, fourth quarter reported sales of $699 million were up 3% on a reported basis and 11% on an organic basis. Sales growth for the quarter was due to positive growth in Ireland, South America and China, as well as the sales impact from our role as the exclusive food service provider in the Athletes' Village for the London Olympics games. This growth was partially offset by a sales decline in the U.K.-based business and Spain. 
For the fiscal year 2012, our reported sales of $2.7 billion were flat compared to the prior year on a reported basis primarily due to the impact of a stronger dollar. Organic growth was 6%, again led primarily by the Olympic Games, but also due to growth in Germany, Ireland, South America and China, which more than offset a sales decline in the U.K.-based business in Spain and in Belgium.
Fourth quarter adjusted operating income was $27 million, which was down about 3% when compared to the prior year quarter, with currency translation negatively affecting profit growth by approximately 4 percentage points. Results in the quarter primarily reflect improving profit performance in the U.K. and in Ireland, of which I think is particularly admirable in a very difficult economic environment, which was offset by a profit decline in Continental Europe.
For the first -- for the full fiscal year 2012, adjusted operating income was $100 million, up from $91 million in the prior year. Growth was driven by the U.K., Ireland, Germany, Chile and China, and partially offset by Belgium and our AIM joint venture in Japan. Currency translation also negatively affected profit growth by about 4 percentage points.
 
In our Uniform and Career Apparel segment, fourth quarter sales of $342 million were up 3% from the year-ago quarter on both a reported and an organic basis. Improving organic growth rates in the uniform rental business, which in the fourth quarter were in the mid-single digits, were offset by softness in our direct sale business. For the fiscal year 2012, segment sales of $1.4 billion were up 2% from the prior year on both a reported and an organic basis. 
We are continuing to invest in additional rental sales personnel resources to support accelerated new sales growth. We are gaining improved traction in our new sales efforts as wear [ph] accounts continue to grow. Our new business installed in 2012 was up over 20% for the full year as a result of both a larger sales force and increased sales productivity. And, of course, we're paying the price of that a bit on both our sales expense and our merchandise amortization.
The segment's fourth quarter adjusted operating income was $38 million. This compares to fourth quarter of 2011 adjusted operating income of $34 million. Results from 2011 included restructuring expenses following our divestiture of our Galls subsidiary in September of 2011. Excluding these costs from the prior year, adjusted operating income in the fourth quarter of 2012 would've been up in the mid-single digits, which is an improvement from the recent quarters. 
For the full fiscal year, adjusted operating income was $145 million, down slightly from the $146 million of the prior year. And as I mentioned, increased sales cost of the expansion of the sales force and a significant increase in our merchandise amortization cost associated with the substantially higher levels of new business have had a negative impact on profit growth in the year. But we firmly believe that over the intermediate term, these efforts are leading to both improving rental sales and profit growth as we look further into 2013.
Corporate expenses, which exclude the items Karen mentioned earlier, were at $11.5 million in the quarter compared to $8.5 million a year ago. And for the fiscal year 2012, expenses were $36.4 million compared to $32.2 million in the prior year. Now let me turn it back over to Karen for some additional details in the quarter and the fiscal year.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Fred. I'd like to comment on our financing, capital structure and cash flow. Our adjusted EBITDA for the trailing 12 months ending September 28 was $1.136 billion, equal to the figure we reported as of June 29, 2012 and up from the $1.1 billion as
componenttext:
Thanks, Fred. I'd like to comment on our financing, capital structure and cash flow. Our adjusted EBITDA for the trailing 12 months ending September 28 was $1.136 billion, equal to the figure we reported as of June 29, 2012 and up from the $1.1 billion as of September 30, 2011. Interest and other financing costs were $87 million for the fourth quarter compared to $111 million in the prior year. Our interest expense in the quarter was lower primarily as a result of a number of interest rate swaps that matured at the end of March 2012. 
For the fiscal year 2012, interest and other financing costs were $402 million, down from the prior year's expense of $426 million. In the second quarter of 2012, we recorded approximately $11 million of expenses related to the term loan extension we completed during the quarter. In 2011, we had interest income of approximately $14 million recorded that was related to the settlement of U.K. VAT claims from prior periods. Including the impact of interest rate hedges, approximately 50% of our total debt portfolio is at fixed interest rates, and our overall weighted average cost of debt is approximately 5.1%.
Total reported debt at the end of fiscal year 2012 was $5.413 billion. Our secured debt, as defined in our credit agreement, totaled $3.602 billion, including a term loan balance of $3.289 billion and a revolver balance that was 0. In June 2012, we amended our accounts receivable securitization facility, increasing the maximum amount from $250 million to $300 million and extending the maturity date to January of 2015. That facility had $264 million utilized at year end. We also had approximately $649 million of available capacity under our revolving credit facility as of year end. Based on our trailing adjusted EBITDA, our secured debt ratio was 3.11x as of September 28, which is down from the 3.41x we reported as of June 29, 2012 and that 3.17x we reported at the end of September 30, 2011.
During 2012, we utilized $250 million of free cash flow to fund the repayment of our 5% notes. Without this maturity, we would've utilized free cash flow to pay down secured debt and we would've seen a more substantial improvement in our secured debt ratio, consistent with our strong cash flow performance for the year. Our ratio of total debt to adjusted EBITDA at the end of fiscal 2012 was 4.76x, and this compares to 5.09x at the end of the third quarter and 5.13x as of the end of fiscal 2011. Overall, we're pleased with our EBITDA growth and our ratio momentum, and we anticipate further ratio improvement over time. 
Net capital expenditures for the quarter were $124 million compared to $92 million in the prior year quarter. For the fiscal year, net capital expenditures totaled $343 million compared to $272 million in the same period last year. This higher level of spending reflects planned investment in our infrastructure, as well as our sales growth objectives.
Consistent with our expectations and historical patterns, working capital was a significant source of cash for us during the fourth quarter. We ended the year with working capital as a relatively moderate source of cash overall for the year. We would anticipate that we will return to a more typical pattern in fiscal 2013, with working capital requiring a modest level of investments.
For the year, we're very pleased with our free cash flow performance before acquisitions and divestitures as we've generated approximately $403 million of free cash flow in fiscal 2012, a total that exceeded our plan and reflects our growth in operating income and continued strong focus on working capital discipline.
For the fiscal year, we spent a total of $152 million on acquisitions compared to $157 million in the prior year period. This year's spending, related primarily to the acquisition of Filterfresh and our North American Refreshment Services business, which closed in October of 2011. We continue to evaluate and seek to make strategic investments in certain sectors and geographies, but we plan to be prudent and disciplined in the pursuit of these opportunities. 
Now let me turn the call back over to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Karen. So summing up our performance for this fiscal year, our global Food and Support Services business has delivered solid organic growth with slightly stronger profit growth. Our uniform rental business is gaining traction from the significant
componenttext:
Thanks, Karen. So summing up our performance for this fiscal year, our global Food and Support Services business has delivered solid organic growth with slightly stronger profit growth. Our uniform rental business is gaining traction from the significant investment we've made over the past several quarters in accelerating new sales. 
As we look forward, we have strengths that we need to leverage. We have strong positions and attractive sectors, great people with pride and passion, strong values and a desire to do the right thing and a focus on client service. We believe there are many attractive growth opportunities in front of us despite the economic clients -- the economic climate, as many of our sectors remained significantly under-penetrated. And we remain excited about pursuing those opportunities. We need to create growth-relating [ph] positions as we strive to become the most valued partner to our clients and consumers.
And on the cost side, we see additional opportunities to improve our performance. In late 2011, we embarked on a number of internal initiatives aimed at delivering improved organic growth and continued margin improvement in the coming years. These activities have already delivered benefits in 2012, but we are committed to continue to improve our standards, processes and systems, bringing efficiencies and improved effectiveness to how we serve our clients and customers everyday around the world. During 2013, we are planning to further accelerate this process standardization, which we believe will help us drive ongoing margin improvement. 
So thank you again for your time this afternoon and for your support of ARAMARK. And we'd be now happy to take your questions.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And the first question will come from Bryan Hunt with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And the first question will come from Bryan Hunt with Wells Fargo.

componenttext: Yes, we -- we provide service at 9 NHL arenas. The fall season impact on us on the top line would be somewhere in the range of $100 million, and this would be the full season plus our budget for the playoffs because we do budgets on playoff games. And the drop through on that would be somewhere in the range of 20%. So it's certainly not 0, but it's not material in the overall scheme of things.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay and pivoting to just -- looking at your mix of part-time versus full-time employees with the election behind us and the coming implementation of the Affordable Care Act, can you give us any insight into your discussions about any -- how you w
componenttext: Got it. Okay and pivoting to just -- looking at your mix of part-time versus full-time employees with the election behind us and the coming implementation of the Affordable Care Act, can you give us any insight into your discussions about any -- how you would plan to implement that legislation, whether that means changing the mix of employees, changing your benefits offerings? What type of -- can you quantify the impact of this legislation on your business at this time?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's difficult to totally quantify the impact. We were, as we looked at the legislation as it stood, one of our concerns was whether this -- the requirement of at least 30 hours a week to qualify for health care benefits, how that would apply to seas
componenttext: Yes, it's difficult to totally quantify the impact. We were, as we looked at the legislation as it stood, one of our concerns was whether this -- the requirement of at least 30 hours a week to qualify for health care benefits, how that would apply to seasonal workers. And because we have, particularly let's say in Sports & Entertainment and our Higher Education operations, we have lots and lots of seasonal workers and so we had some concern about that. On average they work less than 30 hours a week, but they don't work less than 30 hours a week every week. There's some new regulations that are just come out on that and it appears that our concern about having a huge increase in eligibility as a result of seasonal workers who average below 30 hours a week being eligible is not -- is not founded. So we're heartened by that. And as a result the impact on us is less significant than we feared that it might be. So we're still working through all the details. As you know there's still regulations, clarifications coming out as we speak. There are clearly other actions that we can take. Some other companies have started to do or talked about, which is changing the mix between part-time and full-time workers. So it's difficult to quantify the impact. I guess, I would say, it's not insignificant but it doesn't rise to the level of potentially a major EBIT impact, as we had been a little bit concerned about it as we looked at it 1 year ago. So we're looking at something that's in the tens of millions before mitigation.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then on the other hand with the potential for increased hospital visits from the expansion of coverage, do you see an opportunity to gain incremental business with hospital systems as a result of this legislation?
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then on the other hand with the potential for increased hospital visits from the expansion of coverage, do you see an opportunity to gain incremental business with hospital systems as a result of this legislation?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure that -- we're not sure really that the legislation itself will drive incremental growth in health care. It certainly puts a lot of additional strains on the system and some of those fall-on contract service providers to hospitals. I guess our
componenttext: I'm not sure that -- we're not sure really that the legislation itself will drive incremental growth in health care. It certainly puts a lot of additional strains on the system and some of those fall-on contract service providers to hospitals. I guess our -- having said that our view is that health care is clearly a growth market. As you know it's one that's relatively under-penetrated by contractors. We have a very full offering there across the food service traditional facilities and clinical equipment, maintenance spectrum, so we have a very full offering in that market. And we view that as a very attractive growth market and expect that over time that business will grow higher than the average for us.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great. Okay. And one last final question from us and I'll hand it off. Are you still content with your current capital structure? Are you in active discussions to possibly refinance the bonds that are callable and push out maturities any further? How do y
componenttext: Great. Okay. And one last final question from us and I'll hand it off. Are you still content with your current capital structure? Are you in active discussions to possibly refinance the bonds that are callable and push out maturities any further? How do you think about your capital structure entering the new year? And also, addition to that question, are you happy with the way your business looks today? Are there other incremental acquisitions that you could pursue or businesses that you may consider non-core? Just trying to get a feel of how your business will look like over the next couple of quarters.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'll handle your question with respect to the capital structure. I mean, I think general speaking, we're always looking at the markets. Clearly the leveraged finance markets are extremely strong right now which does provide plenty of opportunities to look
componenttext: I'll handle your question with respect to the capital structure. I mean, I think general speaking, we're always looking at the markets. Clearly the leveraged finance markets are extremely strong right now which does provide plenty of opportunities to look at different refinancing alternatives and we continue to look at those. Historically, I think we've always been very prudent and conservative in terms of aggressively refinancing our debt well in advance of maturity. We've pushed a lot of our debt out already. And I'm sure, as we get into early 2013, we'll be continuing to look at the market and look for opportunities to further push out some of those maturities.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think on the M&A front, I think it's fair to say that there are no businesses we're in that we're not pleased with and think have potential over time. So I think, as you know, over the last couple of years, we repositioned our Uniform business, I t
componenttext: Yes, I think on the M&A front, I think it's fair to say that there are no businesses we're in that we're not pleased with and think have potential over time. So I think, as you know, over the last couple of years, we repositioned our Uniform business, I think we're very comfortable with that. On the acquisition side, I think we'll continue to look for bolt-on acquisitions. Those could be to expand our services. Not way off of where we are right now but in some adjacent areas in either food service or facility services. And the other -- the other opportunity I think for acquisitions is to look at some of the faster growing economies in the world. As I mentioned, when we started out, we're growing at mid-teens to high-teens rates in certain markets in Asia and South America. And certainly, we don't have full coverage in those regions of the world. So I think we'll selectively look there as well.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 14, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, our -- the annualized -- the way we look at it sort of at the forefront of how we're doing, is the annualized value of contracts that we signed up and the annualized value of contracts that we've lost. Now those are not -- those are reflected in our
componenttext: Yes, our -- the annualized -- the way we look at it sort of at the forefront of how we're doing, is the annualized value of contracts that we signed up and the annualized value of contracts that we've lost. Now those are not -- those are reflected in our P&L over time as the contracts are actually come out or as contracts are added and we start to operate them. And for 2012 as I mentioned briefly in my opening remarks, we had a pretty strong performance overall, and this is both the North American food service  facilities business, the International business and the Uniform business. And the annualized value -- the annualized sales value of new contracts that we were awarded --  so at sometime during the year was up around 20% or so. And that of course is something that will roll into the financial statements as those contracts are started off. And our -- the dollar value of the contracts that we lost during the year was down I think about between 5% and 10%. So the net new business as a result since the new business was up, the lost business was down, the net new business was up a fair amount. And so we were fairly, fairly pleased on that. We've been --  more so focused particularly on adding new business. We've been adding sales resources, standardizing some of our sales processes and we were pretty encouraged by the results we saw in 2012. The client retention rate -- sorry, our client retention rate in 2012, I think, was right around 95%.

componenttext: Okay. Great. And then on the organic -- did you give an organic number? Organic sales excluding  kind of the wins and losses?

componenttext: And -- that's right. That's right. And we also have operations Downtown. As you know, Downtown was out of power longer than -- you're located in Midtown, right?
